It is indeed a pity that we were not able to obtain, and the Government was not able to provide, the costings—which very obviously, as Mr Lacey indicated, were made available to the Government—as part of the earlier considerations of this Bill when Mr Smith was seeking them for the debate in the House of Representatives. As Senator Lees said, it is an important issue that should be read with this. All of the normal exemptions will be available to Telecom to argue in other and appropriate ways, and we will be supporting the amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I briefly add my voice in support of these amendments, largely on the basis that the reasons given by the Government during the progress of this legislation, in which I have taken some interest, having regard to negotiations being undertaken with the introduction of competition in telecommunications in this country, fall rather flat in 1992. Those reasons may have had some validity at the beginning of the process of consultation surrounding the lead-up to this Bill because that did coincide with the earlier period of negotiations on the opening up of Australia's telecommunications. That was a fairly controversial move in any case, but it was one of the good economic rationalist moves to which this country has been subjected over the life of this Government and one strongly supported by the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: In that process it was always important to ensure that the universal service obligation of telecommunications carriers up until that point met by Telecom Australia, and met well by international standards, should not be diminished. The strongest evidence of all to those of us who were concerned about reduction in the universal service, about haziness over what constituted community service obligations by the telecommunications carriers, is this piece of legislation. The Disability Discrimination Bill having come forward in 1992, after the introduction of competition and the Telecommunications Act of 1991, the Government should have much more readily moved in the direction that these amendments moved the legislation.

As Senator Lees said, they do not go all the way. Those of us in this chamber who are concerned about both the rights of the disabled in our community and also the obligations of our telecommunications carriers with regard to universal service must keep an eye on developments with regard to public and pay phones. Certainly I commit myself, along with others in this chamber, to that process. So it is on that basis in particular that I speak briefly in support of these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the range of disabilities we come across, one of the most difficult to comprehend and to imaginatively sympathise with—to put oneself in the position of a person with such a disability—is the world of the deaf, the world of those who are very severely impaired in their hearing capacity, and to an extent those who have a speech impediment or difficulty which prevents them from communicating in a normal way. But it is those who are severely impaired in hearing who inhabit a world that most of us cannot imagine.

PARA.TAB: I have had my education in this matter primarily through my acquaintance with the Tasmanian Deaf Society, and particularly in recent times with Mr Peter Cipollone, the executive director of that society, who has been a tireless worker on behalf of the Tasmanian community. He invited me during Deafness Awareness Week to launch the funding proposal that came out of the Budget, which was designed to improve dramatically communication for Australia's profoundly deaf and speech impaired. I am referring to the $300,000 pilot program for extending the benefits of the telephone typewriter system. The Commonwealth funded pilot project is to test a relay service arrangement.

For those who do not know how this facility would work, a person who is deaf or severely impaired in normal speech or hearing would be able to communicate by telephone typewriter. They type in their message, which is relayed by the phone system. In this particular project, the typewritten message would be received by the interpreter service already conducted by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. The person in that service would then relay the message on to a person who has full hearing, receive a message back, and then type the message back to the deaf person. It is amazing technology and it is a wonderful way in which those who have this disability can engage not only in ordinary social intercourse with their friends and relatives and associates but also in business and other activities.

I mention that project because I believe that it is a demonstration of the good faith of the Federal Government in relation to these matters. Indeed, it is only a foundation for the sorts of assistance we wish to encourage—the dismantling of the barriers, the removal of impediments to the full participation of those with disabilities in Australian society, in this case particularly those with severe hearing impairment.

For that reason, having held discussions with Mr Howe and Mr Collins over the last few hours, the Federal Government is prepared to accept these amendments. We believe that it is an absolutely vital breakthrough on the part of those suffering from these disabilities. We believe that it is the only proper response we can require as an Australian community of those who are vested with the tremendous privilege, commercially but also socially, of providing telecommunications services for all Australians. We have come to the view that, building on the goodwill and good faith already demonstrated in the pilot program I have outlined and keeping in mind the general social purpose of this Bill, it would be proper to bring within the Bill the providers of telecommunications services in the way suggested in the amendments.

What that means has to be understood. It will mean that a person who considers that he or she has been discriminated against on the grounds of the disability, in this case severe deafness or a speech impediment which prevents them from ordinary and normal use of the telephone, would be able to approach the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and lodge a complaint if a facility had not been provided to enable that communication to take place across the telephone wires.

It has to be emphasised, as I did before the Standing Committee on Community Affairs last Friday, that Telecom, for example, as the provider of the service could argue unjustifiable hardship. The figures, of which we have had only an indication, and not in a formal way and not under the pressure that Telecom would certainly be under in that formal setting of the Commission, would be presented. As I have said in previous contributions to this debate, Telecom or any other provider of services would have to indicate that indeed there was unjustifiable hardship—make it a live issue; give credibility to that assertion—and that would be a proper discipline on the organisation concerned.

Of course, I would imagine that, with the passage of the legislation in the form from which it will emerge from this Committee and then from the Parliament, it would be sensible for the provider of the telecommunications service to take advantage of those provisions of the Bill which enable the organisation, as a service provider, to put forward action plans which include provisions relating to the devising of policies and programs to achieve the objects of the Act; the communication of these policies and programs to persons within the service provider; the review of practices within the service provider with a view to the identification of any discriminatory practices; and the setting of goals and targets, where these may reasonably be determined against which the success of the plan in achieving the objects of the Act may be assessed; and so on.

What the Committee has achieved during the course of this morning's deliberations and on this particular matter is indeed very noteworthy. It is compassionate, but by that I do not want to say that there is not an issue of justice involved. It is not simply a matter of sentiment; it is a matter of ensuring that those who would otherwise be in a most isolated situation within the Australian community are able to take advantage of that which so many of us take for granted as a matter of course—that is, communication through the telephone system.

It has given me great pleasure to be able to inform the Committee of this very recent decision by the Government. On the part of both Mr Howe and Senator Collins, there has been a full understanding of the arguments as they have unfolded, properly, over the last several weeks. I want to pay particular tribute to Miss Heather Butow who, I think, has done a tremendous job, not only in this particular matter, but in relation to the construction of this Bill, together with Kym Duggan from the human rights area of the Attorney-General's Department. But, principally, in this matter, Miss Heather Butow has achieved a great deal for the disabled throughout Australia and I believe it ought to be recorded in the annals of the Senate today.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to thank the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) for his support for this amendment. It certainly is a matter of justice and it is one that will mean a great deal to all of those Australians who have a significant hearing loss. We may find that Telecom is in fact quite pleased that it will have the opportunity to corner a section of the market before any other player takes an interest in this particular type of service because, as has been found overseas with similar legislation, it actually generates income for the provider and it spreads throughout the community a service in which many people previously would not have been involved and to which they would not have had access. So I hope it is the general feeling of the telecommunications providers that they will in fact be keen to be involved now in the provision of these services.

—I was not going to speak during this committee stage of the Bill, as I had the opportunity, as a temporary member of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs for two weeks, of participating in the hearings last Friday. But I want to put on the record the fact that it is another example of the new committee procedure of the Senate working to ensure that legislation is looked at very carefully and that due consideration can be given by the Opposition and the Democrats, and also by the Government to re-examine its own legislation.

PARA.TAB: It is nice to see that we do not have to divide on this clause. As the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, has said, if it is due to the work of the staff of the Minister—and also the Minister himself—that we can achieve that, then I think it does reflect well on the processes of the Senate. It emphasises the importance of the Senate in being able to review legislation in a more cooperative manner than may sometimes happen in the other place. It shows that we can work together to achieve something that, basically, we all believe is just and fair and which does have checks and balances built into it for Telecom, as the Minister has said. It also gives people with disabilities an opportunity if they believe they have been discriminated against on this basis.

I wanted to say that because I think so often we do not see that sort of cooperation, or it is not reported. It might seem a very minor thing to someone sitting in the press gallery, for example, but for people with a hearing loss it could be a very major thing.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I also want to join in the important recognition that these successful amendments will bring to a very wide range of people in the community, particularly those in the deaf community. I am pleased that all parties—in fact, I think it will probably be a unanimous decision of the chamber—recognise this very important initiative.

PARA.TAB: However, I must express my disappointment—certainly, the Government can count; it knows that the amendments would have been carried in light of the political pressures that were going to be brought to bear on these amendments—that similar weight has not been afforded to the other important submissions that were made as part of this important legislation. I would argue that groups such as the Confederation of Australian Industry, the Australian Medical Association and the Association of Surgeons have raised equally important and fundamental issues that would have assisted a very wide range of members of the community.

As I said in my preliminary remarks today, whilst the Government has certainly had a very fixed agenda on this matter, I can accept that. I imagine that there would have been many in the Government, in the bureaucracy and probably in the Minister's office who may have argued very strongly for this provision never to have been in the legislation anyway, and it was only a matter of costing and finances of various people that probably meant that it emerged in the first place as a sort of budget check and balance.

There are still a number of very important reservations with regard to this legislation. Whilst we will certainly be supporting the passage of the legislation today, I think the legislation will have to be monitored very carefully in its implementation. As to how it changes so many fundamental things in Australian society, it is all about attitudinal change. In fact, many people have argued about the unfortunate situation that arises that means that the legislation is necessary at all. I think my colleague Senator Patterson importantly referred to that in her speech on the second reading.
I acknowledge that this amendment is vitally important. I just express my concern that the Government did not give equal weight to the consideration of other fundamental issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise simply to indicate that I am supporting the amendments. I have spoken about this previously, and there is no point in my going over that. I simply indicate my support for the amendments, which I think makes the support unanimous.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask the Minister a question about clause 3. It is my understanding that a result of the passage of the Bill will be that people who are partially mentally incapacitated can bring an action if they feel that they have been prejudiced in any way as a result of their disability. Is that the meaning of disability in clause 3 of the Bill?

—We have to go back to fundamentals. I imagine that the definition of disability would embrace the sort of incapacity from which the person described by Senator O'Chee would be suffering. But that, in itself, does not give rise to any ability to approach the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. What then has to be done is to link that to an act of discrimination on the part of a person, which discrimination is related to that particular disability. It is only then that one gets into the stage of a determination by the Commission that such discrimination is unlawful. It is very hard to know what particular case the honourable senator has in mind but that would be a case which, if it resulted in discrimination in the provision of housing or accommodation, for example, could result in a successful application by the person to the Commission for a determination that such discrimination was unlawful.

—I would be very concerned about cases under existing Commonwealth legislation where, for example, there may be a criterion in certain types of Commonwealth employment that one not be mentally incapacitated. Would that be overridden by this Act?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator O'Chee would know, there are specific exemptions in the Bill, for example, to deal with the armed forces in combat related duties, just to give a broad category of activity where that is permitted. In relation to other matters, it is expressed in terms of the inherent requirements of the job. For example, the disability may make it impossible for a person to become a driving instructor with the Commonwealth car fleet. If someone could not tell the difference between red and green he would probably be something of a failure as an instructor. Where the inherent characteristics of the job require a certain capacity, that has to be given precedence, although it would also be true to say that, with the modern technology and devices and aids of a therapeutic kind that are available, that area might be narrowing.
—I thank the Minister for his assistance.

PARA.TAB: Bill, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the second reading debate on the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation Amendment Bill I informed the Senate that I intended to move an amendment to the Bill in order to put an end to the discrimination inherent in the ban on homosexuals in the Australian Defence Force. I have now decided not to proceed with those amendments at this stage. I have been informed by what I believe to be reliable sources that a Government decision on this question is imminent, so I believe that to move today as I had intended would be inappropriate. There will be other opportunities to pursue the question when we return for the November sittings. I devoutly hope that that will not be necessary and that the matter will have been resolved satisfactorily by that time.

PARA.TAB: Bill agreed to.
Disability Discrimination Bill 1992 reported with amendments and Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 reported without amendment; report adopted.
Bills (on motion by Senator Tate) read a third time.
Motion (by Senator Tate, on behalf of Senator Bolkus) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 and the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984.
Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum, and move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows —

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill contains a number of proposed amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 and the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984, which are necessary in order to respond to certain recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters and the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, and to resolve various practical problems which have arisen in the course of electoral administration. It also repeals the requirement introduced last year for the distribution of a `handbook' containing information about candidates and their policies.

The Bill will repeal the requirement that documents containing information about candidates be delivered to all households prior to the next election. Section 386a of the Commonwealth Electoral Act was inserted last year as a result of an amendment moved by the Australian Democrats during debate on the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill.

The Government supported the amendment because it formed a part of what may be seen as a package of measures, which included freetime broadcasts, designed to ensure that the electorate was informed in the absence of political advertising of candidates' policies in the election. With the disallowance by the High Court of the legislation to ban political advertising, the case for the candidate booklet no longer exists.

The Commonwealth Electoral Act already provides for a free issue of the electoral roll, in computer format if required, to senators, members, registered political parties, and other persons and organisations deemed appropriate by the Electoral Commission, after each general election. This Bill will allow for the free, regular provision of supplements to the roll, in computer format, to all senators, members, and registered political parties which have parliamentary representation. Other groups will be able to obtain these supplements at cost. Habitation indexes are already issued free of charge by the Electoral Commission to registered political parties once in the life of a parliament. The Bill will allow for additional issues of the habitation index to registered political parties at cost.

Mr President, in response to current concerns about privacy issues, this Bill will also provide that where computerised roll information on names and addresses is provided by the Electoral Commission to senators, members and registered political parties, that information must only be used for purposes related to enrolment and to elections and referendums. Penalties are provided for the misuse of the information.

In its report on the 1990 Federal election, the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters recommended that scrutineers be permitted to examine a `two-candidate preferred vote' in order to ascertain the likely outcome of the election on polling night. For various reasons relating to the integrity and efficiency of the scrutiny process and to facilitate equal access by all observers on election night, the Electoral Commission concluded, and the Government agrees, that it is more appropriate for Electoral Commission officers rather than scrutineers to conduct an indicative distribution of second and later preference votes for the House of Representatives on election night. This will provide the public on that night with an early indication of the two-candidate preferred result in most electorates. This legislation will provide a mechanism for the Australian Electoral Commission to conduct such an indicative distribution of preferences.

In its May 1991 report entitled United Nations Peacekeeping and Australia, the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade recommended that an explicit function be conferred on the Australian Electoral Commission to provide assistance to foreign countries and international organisations in the conduct of elections and referendums in cases where such assistance is approved by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. The Bill will confer such a function.

The Bill will also empower the Australian Electoral Commission to provide goods and services to members of the public and organisations in a manner not inconsistent with the performance of its primary functions. Such goods might include the provision of public roll information, and such services might include providing a roll scanning service to State electoral authorities. In the light of the recent report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters which recommended greater cooperation between Federal and State and Territory electoral authorities, legislation to permit the Electoral Commission to provide goods and services to those State and Territory electoral authorities is desirable.
In accordance with the Government's commitment to the `user pays' principle, the Bill will also empower the Australian Electoral Commission to impose charges for the provision of goods and services.

The Bill also provides for a new system of automatic enrolment of new citizens. At the time of applying for citizenship, a person will be able to make a provisional claim for electoral enrolment. The provisional claim for enrolment will be activated once the person concerned has been granted citizenship.

Finally, the Bill includes a number of proposed minor amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act and the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act to improve the efficiency of the electoral process and to resolve certain practical difficulties in electoral administration.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.
Debate resumed from 14 October, on motion by Senator Button and Senator McMullan:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —When we interrupted the debate last night, I was examining the Government's overall track record in the 2 1/2 years since our last Federal election, an overall track record that does not give anyone—any sane, rational person in this place or any other place—reason to have confidence in the performance of this Government; nor does it give any sane or rational person reason to have confidence in the capability of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to perform his job.

PARA.TAB: I recounted yesterday how Mr Keating, shortly after becoming Prime Minister, said that he had a vision for Australia and that his vision included a more independent Australia. Yet this is the same Prime Minister who goes to Japan but a month ago and says to the Japanese, `We will not enter into any trade agreement which is detrimental to Japan's interests'. Is this the idea of independence that Mr Keating has for this nation? I should hope not, because that is not independence. That is merely swapping one set of values based on adherence to a particular nation's interests with another set of values based on adherence to another nation's interests. What this nation needs is a government that will act in the interests of this nation—in the interests of Australia.

This Government needs a sense of duty to the future of Australia and to the future of our economy. Yet we have seen no evidence of that sense of duty in the Budget the Government has brought before Parliament. We have seen no evidence of that sense of duty in the way in which it has conducted its economic program. We have this year in the Budget, on the Government's own figures, a deficit projected to be $13.4 billion. How much is $13.4 billion? That amount, if paid for in $1 coins laid end to end, would go around the world 8 1/2 times. That is the deficit for just this financial year, on the Government's own figures.

We all know that the financing requirement—the obligation of the Commonwealth to borrow—will exceed that amount of money. It will go as high perhaps as $18 billion or more. Where is this money coming from? Where is the Government going to source this money? It is going to be sourced, if one looks at how the Government intends to go to the markets, in the largest ever bond raising program in the history of Australia. The Government is going to source the money by going out and borrowing more in bonds in one year than has ever been done in one program in the entire history of this nation.

If that is the sort of achievement of growth that the Government wants, then yes, it has got it. It has managed to help our foreign debt grow and our public debt grow more than any other government has in the history of this nation. That is great growth! It is great growth for the bankers and great growth for the speculators, but not great growth for the future of our economy. It is not great for the next generation of Australians, who will be expected to bear the financial burden of this Government's economic neglect.

I do not need to remind the chamber that it is the people who are currently at school, who will be leaving school this year, who have, hopefully, 40 years of working life ahead of them, who will pay the taxes to support this Government's profligate borrowing. They are the people who will live with the consequences, not the tired old Ministers on the other side of the Senate chamber, nor the tired old Ministers on the Government's front bench in the other place.

It is the young people of Australia, the people with their working lives ahead of them, who will bear the cost in the higher government taxes that will be necessary under this Government to repay the debt it has clocked up just this year. It is the young people of Australia who will bear the consequences of this Government's economic mismanagement through its failed industrial relations policy, the young people of Australia—like my brother, like my sister—who face the prospect of leaving education or universities with no guarantee of employment; and not just no guarantee of employment next month or next year, but no guarantee of employment maybe for years to come.

This Government's failed policies have condemned a generation of Australians to a future without the dignity of work and to a future without the dignity of their own financial independence. When one looks at this Government's track record in that sense, one must ask: does this Government deserve the money it asks Parliament to give it? I think one could very reasonably be excused for thinking that it does not. Yet it is the Government. It comes before us and says, `We need more money for this program. We need more money for that program'. We on this side of the chamber say to the Government, `Why do we need a Budget deficit this year of $13.4 billion? Why do we need a financing requirement this year in excess of $18 billion?'. I note the entrance into the chamber of my learned colleague Senator Watson. Senator Watson knows full well the full extent of the financial profligacy of this Government. When this Government comes here and asks for that money and we query it, it says time and time again, `This is the money we need to spend to create jobs'.

I ask the question: does the spending of money by the Government necessarily create jobs? Even if it does create jobs, is it the best way to create jobs? This is what the debate is really about. Those of us on this side of the chamber believe there is a better way to create jobs and that is by taking taxes off individuals, by taking taxes off employers, and by giving ordinary working men and women the opportunity to work for their own benefit and, as Senator Watson says, to give them an environment in which they can flourish. That surely must be the best policy for government. The policy that is espoused says tthat only the Government can create jobs and that the only way in which the Government can create jobs is by spending taxpayers' money or, in this case, borrowed money—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a bandaid.

—It is a bandaid. But more than that, it is fundamentally flawed because it is based on the assumption that the Government is the best deliverer of jobs. If that were the case, why have we seen the collapse of socialist countries behind the Iron Curtain over the last five years? Why have we seen, even in China, the bastion of Marxism, a movement away from a controlled economy and towards a free enterprise economy? The answer is that even in China, even the tired old men in the Forbidden City, recognise that one cannot put a yoke on the aspirations of ordinary people for a better existence. Rather than try to constrain the aspirations of ordinary people, the best thing a government can do is take advantage of the aspirations of ordinary people, take advantage of their desire to increase their individual wealth, and recognise that, if 17 million Australians are given the opportunity to increase their individual wealth, they will, of course, increase the common wealth of this nation.

PARA.TAB: That is what we on this side of the chamber say. We say there is an alternative, an alternative based on hope instead of an alternative based on a government that can only tax and borrow. We say that there is an alternative based on private enterprise instead of an alternative based on stimulating the economy by spending more money in the public sector, as this Government has tried to do. The money it spends, even if it is spent as efficiently as the money that the private sector could spend, does not create any extra jobs. With the money the Government takes out of the economy, be it through taxes or be it through soaking up the money that the banks would have lent to small businesses around the country, what it spends is merely money that others could have spent themselves.

The real problem with high taxation policies such as we see from this Government, and have seen from this Government for the whole nine years it has been in office, is that taxation is nothing other than government ownership of an individual's labour, or of the profits of a business. But it is government ownership of one's labour without the Government making a contribution to assist the individual. Instead, the Government's economic policies are policies that are designed to restrict, rather than to assist, the individual. That is why one has to have doubts about whether this Government really does deserve the money which it will now undoubtedly get.

I wish to raise a couple of particular points because it is appropriate, in discussing the appropriations, to look at some of the wasteful ways in which this Government has spent the money. They are ways which I hope we will not see in future governments, ways which I am sure we will not see in the government that will be returned after the Federal election, because it will be a government formed from the people who currently sit on this side of the chamber. Look at the way in which the Government has thrown money willy-nilly at this lobby group and that lobby group to buy their votes. We have seen in the State of Western Australia—and I note the presence in the chamber of Senator Knowles and Senator Crane—how the Government gave last year, from the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, $19,700 to the Manungka Manungka women's cooperative. Why? To fund a program to train Aboriginal women in the art of fabric making in the hope of establishing a fabric making industry in the Kimberley desert—in the Kimberley desert!

TALK.START.PARA: —It's called votes.

—It is called votes, as Senator Knowles says. Quite rightly it is called votes, because I do not believe that any reasonable person would think that a $19,700 grant is going to encourage the establishment of a fabric making industry in the Kimberley desert. Nor do I think a reasonable person would believe that a fabric making industry in the Kimberley desert would necessarily be successful.

PARA.TAB: We saw this Government provide $18,000 or more last year to the Vehicle Builders Union in Victoria to put together a tape in English and Vietnamese to distribute to its union members—on the benefits of belonging to a union. Of course, this is but part of millions and millions of dollars that this Government has wasted in propping up its mates in the trade unions. Mr Howard is quite right in saying in the other place that this is the sort of repugnant and immoral misuse of taxpayers' money that must be brought to an end. It is the sort of immoral and repugnant use of taxpayers' money that will be brought to an end by a coalition government that recognises that every single cent that is wasted in that fashion is money that is taken from other working men and women through the taxes that they pay.

What we on this side of the chamber are saying in our Fightback package is that we will reduce the taxes Australians will pay, we will reduce the tax burden of this nation by over $4 billion in total and we will reduce the tax burden that the low income earners in this nation will pay. Whilst the Prime Minister looked after his yuppie friends of the ALP's Right in New South Wales with tax cuts for the people who earn over $20,700, he did not have the capacity to do as we on this side of the chamber will do—to reduce the tax for people who earn under $20,700. Yet he claims to be the friend of the working man and woman. He is in fact quite the opposite: a man who has lost touch with his roots and lost touch with the reality of Australia today.

A group of people in north Queensland are very much in touch with the reality of what this Government has done to them. They are a group of people around the town of Ravenshoe who are still owed money from a timber mill that this Government said it was going to support—a group of people around Ravenshoe who are still wondering what happened, as many Australians are wondering what happened, to over $7.5m that was siphoned out of the Ravenshoe timber mill and sent to Kyogle, much of that being taxpayers' money. Yesterday we had the absurd spectacle of the office of the Director of Public Prosecutions telling ABC radio that no prosecution in relation to any companies offences would be made in Ravenshoe by the Director of Public Prosecutions. This story ran on the news. Yesterday afternoon, the Director of Public Prosecutions felt obliged to produce a press statement which I will read into Hansard:

SPEECH.PARA: On 14 October 1992 an item was broadcast by the ABC in Cairns to the effect that the DPP had decided not to lay charges in relation to alleged misuse of funds in connection with the Ravenshoe Timber Mill.
This item was prompted by incorrect advice provided to the ABC by the DPP.
The information provided to the ABC related to another case.
It is inappropriate to discuss the matter further given that an investigation is still in progress and that may result in criminal charges being laid.
The DPP regrets any inconvenience caused.
This is an inquiry that has been going for two years—

TALK.START.PARA: —And they still got it wrong.

—Yes, they still got it wrong. This is an inquiry that has been going for two years, when the normal period of time taken by the DPP to deal with a brief is 19 weeks. This press release is really saying, `Even if the Government tells it to you, don't believe it because we might change our mind later on in the afternoon'. We have some fool running around north Queensland who purports to be the local member for Kennedy—I do not believe he can be the local member for Kennedy because he is too stupid to be the local member for Kennedy—saying that it is inappropriate—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—Order! I do not think it is parliamentary language to refer to a member of the House of Representatives as a fool. The honourable senator will withdraw that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will withdraw, Madam Acting Deputy President. I was merely giving him the benefit of the doubt. I did not believe that the local member could be a fool.
—The honourable senator will withdraw unconditionally.

—I did withdraw, Madam Acting Deputy President. But there is this man running around Kennedy saying that it is improper for members of parliament to be concerned that an investigation can go two years and that it is improper for members of parliament to ask the Director of Public Prosecutions to justify having taken two years to investigate the matter. He is saying that it is improper for members of parliament to say in this place that the Government needs to pull its finger out and get on with the case.

PARA.TAB: The reason he gives for saying that is that it is contrary to the separation of powers. This is a man who purports to be a lawyer. As such he ought to know better. He ought to know that the true role of Parliament is to make the Government accountable; the true role of Parliament is to ensure not only that justice is done but that justice is seen to be done. That is what is not happening in this case. The more the Government tries to hide, the more I can assure it that honourable senators on this side of the chamber will continue to pursue this matter until it is properly concluded.

It is incumbent upon this Government now, in the light of this press statement, to make in the Senate a full and proper explanation of the investigation and to make available all the secret papers which it has been hiding and which the receivers prepared in the investigation of that mill. As a general principle, I state again that it is important not only that justice be done but that justice be seen to be done. The one million Australian unemployed want a chance to do some justice to this Government and they want a chance to be seen to do some justice to this Government. They and the other 16 million Australians say, `Bring on the Federal election'. Bring on the chance for them to have their say so that they can throw out this profligate Government once and for all and put Australia once again on the track to economic recovery and a sound future for the next generation of young Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the third time since I have been in this Parliament that a Budget has been brought down and I have spoken on the Appropriation Bills. Each time I have said that I hope things will look a little better next time.

PARA.TAB: I am going to do what I have done before, that is, do what I call a business analysis of how Australia is travelling. I believe that the Budget should be a business plan; and the intention of any business plan should be to have that business—in this case, Australia—in a better position than it was in at the time of the previous Budget.

What has occurred during the period of those three analyses and, obviously, before I became a member of the Senate? We see a debt ridden nation. We see a nation ridden with unemployment. We see business bankruptcies higher than they have ever been before. We see a regulation ridden nation with little or no chance of lifting itself out of the mire under the present Government, and particularly the present Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

What are the options, the alternatives, that we on this side of the chamber have put on the table? We have put a business plan on the table for Australia. We put that business plan on the table over 12 months ago; and it has been open to scrutiny, analysis and a whole range of comments. What do we get from the Government about that? We get a range of scare tactics, because it cannot put in place anything that matches the vision or the wisdom of that particular plan. What does that plan give? It gives hope. It gives freedom.

I particularly want to mention freedom—and I am going to relate to New Zealand later in my speech. In this country, an employer cannot even come to an agreement with his employees, or vice versa, without having unions and the Industrial Relations Commission involved. That is a fundamental breach of the freedom of the rights of individuals. The freedom to come to such agreements gives incentive. The coalition's business plan gives personal income tax cuts. It gives business tax cuts. It gives individuals the right to accept how they manage and run their affairs. It gives them the right, in fact, to control their own destiny.

In doing a business analysis of Australia and asking the question, `How are we travelling?', this time I am going to summarise the position rather than go into detail, because there are a number of other matters that I wish to raise. It really can be summed up in one word—`disastrously'. Our foreign debt continues to grow. Our current account is out of control. Unemployment is over one million. As Senator Jim McKiernan said prior to the backstabbing exercise by Paul Keating on the previous Prime Minister, Mr Bob Hawke: `There are one million reasons why Paul Keating should never be the Prime Minister of this country'. And he got it right.

I also want to refer to what has happened in New Zealand because I think the New Zealand experience, while not being necessarily a blueprint, presents some guiding ideas for what has to be done, and can be done, in Australia to put us back on the road to economic recovery—to put us back to where the vast majority of Australians can go to work every day if they choose; to put us in a position where, if someone wants to make an employment contract with his boss or his employee, he can do so without interference from anybody else. He can make his own arrangements, in a way that suits him, to get the job done and to suit his aspirations. I want also to talk about the lack of courage of this Government to address the real issues and to say that it has devastated the aspirations of so many Australians.

To sum up, in this country we need real tax reform, not artificial tax reform; we need real industrial relations reform, not artificial industrial relations reform; and we want real infrastructure reform. I am heartily sick and tired of hearing this Government continually blaming everybody else but itself, blaming all the nations of the world. Nobody is going to deny that there are problems in other countries of the world. But why, when there are troubles in the rest of the world, can we not address the fundamental problems and the fundamental issues that exist in Australia?

I am going to venture into an area that I do not usually venture into, and I do so because I was incensed by the remarks of Senator Crowley last night, and the propaganda and misleading comments she put forward in her speech. The area I speak of is health. I am going to take what I say from an independent source, because I believe that source puts the health policies of the Government and of the Opposition in their proper context. The document I have here is the Contributor, the newsletter of the Australian Health Insurance Association.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very objective source!
—It is a very objective source and it is independent—completely independent. The honourable senator does not like it.
—Independent of whom?

—Of the honourable senator's Party and us. Let us look first of all at health as it relates to the Government's tax policy: the Medicare levy will go up to 1.4 per cent; under the Liberal Fightback policy, the Medicare levy will be held at 1.25 per cent. I suppose that Senator McMullan is going to deny that. Under Fightback, there would be tax rebates for incomes up to $30,000; under Labor, there are no tax incentives for insurance. For the elderly, there would be no assistance for insurance; there would be longer queues; higher insurance premiums would be likely as young people were encouraged to drop insurance. We all know that not only will that happen, it is happening now. Under Fightback, there would be direct payments of up to $800 per pensioner couple and lower health insurance costs via $565m support for a reinsurance scheme.
—What does it say about doctors' fees?

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I shall make my speech. No doubt Senator McMullan will have his turn in a little while, but he does not have a very good story to tell. This is the Government that has virtually bankrupted this country. Senator McMullan has been part of that process, and he should remember that. It will not only be my children who suffer from that: it will be his children and his grandchildren. They are the ones that are going to have to pay back the debt—not us. To return to health, for those on low incomes the Government policy will provide no assistance and the levy will be up by 81 per cent; under Fightback, tax rebates will be targeted to income groups.

PARA.TAB: I would now like to move on to the next part. It refers to high incomes and also to the Medicare levy, which has gone up by $2.88 a week for a single person on $100,000 per annum. The document also states that under Fightback there will be a penalty if one is uninsured. One can go on through this particular document and look at all of the aspects of it that have been balanced. Senator McMullan has obviously seen this. It also clearly points out that there are significant benefits under the health policies of the coalition that will improve the health position of many Australians. I am heartily sick and tired—when I go to places such as Bunbury, Esperance, Albany and Port Hedland, and elsewhere—of hearing about the long waiting lists that people have to put up with to get into hospitals. It should be the right of every individual to get into hospital quickly and efficiently. Under this Government, the health system is really in a mess.

It is worth noting that the Government has spent an additional $9 billion this year. This roughly represents an increase of 6 per cent in real expenditure. There is a deterioration of $6 billion in the Budget deficit; it has gone from around $9 billion to around $15 billion. The gross Commonwealth public debt interest increases by 26 per cent over $1 billion in 1992-93 and by 33 per cent, around $1.6 billion, in the following year. The Government has abandoned its previous commitment to return the Budget to surplus by the middle of the decade. Do honourable senators remember what Mr Keating said some years ago about balanced budgets? Even with the indications of increased taxation, the Budget will remain significantly in deficit until 1995-96. The total deficits from 1991-92 to 1995-96 will be over $50 billion. That should be compared to the One Nation estimate of $18 billion for deficits over that period.

It is a little less than six months since the One Nation statement came out. The Government said then that the Budget deficit would blow out to about $18 billion over that four-year period. If one can believe the Budget that was brought down, we now find the Government has adjusted that by another minus $32 billion, in just six months. One is entitled to ask who does its number crunching, who does its accounting and how can it get things so wrong. These mistakes come from the Government's own paper. How can it get it so wrong?

There are two people principally responsible for this—one is our bankcard Prime Minister and the other is our shop until you drop Treasurer (Mr Dawkins). Do honourable senators remember when Mr Dawkins came out and said, `Go out and spend, spend, spend'? After the Government had driven everybody into the ground and almost destroyed them with high interest rate regimes, he comes out and tells us to spend instead of telling us to reduce debt. I say to people who have a mortgage or a business debt that if they get the opportunity to reduce that debt, they should make it their top priority. I say that from bitter personal experience.

There are people sitting on both sides of this chamber who know that my family and I have been farming for a long time. We expanded our operation in 1984. The high interest rates of the Government—the people who sit on the other side—almost destroyed us. I can understand why people who have put their life savings into trying to do something for this nation get very upset when they see their life savings go down the drain because of government policy, government lack of understanding and because of a government that does not really care about a number of things. And there are many Australians who have had their life savings go down the drain during this period of time.

Let us, for a moment—because I raised it earlier on—look at the changes we intend to make in the tax scales in lowering personal income tax. We are giving people the opportunity to make a decision about what they do with their money, rather than ripping it off them and saying that we as a government can spend it better than they can because we know how to manage it. We are not going to say, `We know how to manage your affairs better than you do'.

It is worth noting some of the changes that are going to occur. Let us look at phase 1 under our policies in terms of the tax cuts which will exist. First of all, we see that those people who have an annual income of $7,000 presently pay $320 tax; they will pay none so the gain per year will be $320, or 100 per cent. I will not read all of these out because of time. We go up to $15,000 and we find that the present tax is $1,920; that will be cut to $1,296, a saving of $624 per annum or a cut of 32.5 per cent. We look at people earning $25,000 and we find that currently they are paying $4,694; under our proposals it will be $3,509, a saving of $1,185 or a cut of $25.20 per week. One can go through the list—and it is all here for everybody to see—and one will find there are very significant tax cuts which will put dollars and cents back into people's pockets and give them the opportunity and the incentive to manage their own financial affairs and not have the Government managing them for them.

If we move to business, we see the removal of the wholesale sales tax and payroll tax. Did not Senator Button get himself into a little bit of a mix yesterday on payroll tax? The removal of the fuel excise will save $11 per tank every time a motorist fills up the tank of an average sized car. But the real benefit from fuel excise is that it will be part of the measures that have to be taken to give our transport industry, whether it be rail or road, the opportunity to get somewhere near being internationally competitive.

I believe that is one of the most important infrastructure reforms required in Australia. We do not have a competitive transport system and one of the principal reasons is we almost tax them off the road or off the rails. It is the highest taxed sector in this country of Australia which is so large and is populated in half a dozen places around the coastline, and yet its wealth basically comes from inland. Our producers pay an enormous penalty for this high taxing government and the level of tax that is paid, whether it be in the wholesale sales tax area, the flow-on effects of payroll tax or the fuel excise.
Debate interrupted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., we will now move to matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address some things that have been taking place in the Parliament in Victoria. By and large, members of the Commonwealth Parliament do not comment on what happens in State parliaments but I want to address them from the point of view of how things that are proposed down there can affect the nation as a whole. Chapter V of the Constitution sets out a series of matters in respect of the States. Section 106 reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Constitution of each State of the Commonwealth shall, subject to this Constitution, continue as at the establishment of the Commonwealth, or as at the admission or establishment of the State, as the case may be, until altered in accordance with the Constitution of the State.

It is proposed by the newly elected Government in Victoria that a series of things should happen. I have here some information obtained from the Australian news service. The first thing is that in Victoria there is to be a new tier of apprentice Ministers or, in effect, Parliamentary Secretaries. At the same time as there is to be a cut to the politicians' support staff there is to be an increase in the amount paid to the people who will become Parliamentary Secretaries. There is also the suggestion that, if the occasion for a by-election occurs, that not take place but that there be simply a filling of that seat by a person from the party that the previous member had represented.

PARA.TAB: My concern is that these changes reduce the ability of parliamentarians, as parliamentarians, to do their job. This is a move to increase the power of the executive and to reduce that of the legislature, and it shows scant regard for the constitutional position and responsibility of parliament, as opposed to the executive. Mr Kennett is quoted here as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: If you come into parliament, you are ultimately left there and you wait simply until you become a minister.
It is a matter of concern that the attitude should grow—and, may I say, it is not an attitude that is exclusive to Mr Kennett—that we come in here simply to provide a reservoir for the Ministry.

PARA.TAB: There have been great contributions made to this Parliament and to other parliaments by people who are not Ministers. I refer to Senator Watson, who has done great work on parliamentary committees, particularly the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. I refer to Senator Knowles, who has carried out the duty of Deputy Whip in great style.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Senator McMullan.

—I do not include Senator McMullan because he is very much on his way to the Ministry, but I do include Senator Foreman, who has carried out his duties quite outstandingly as a Deputy Whip. I am not alone in expressing my concern about the problems that we, as parliamentarians, face. I see in the chamber Anne Lynch, who is a great Deputy Clerk. She would understand the points I am making here.

TAB.TAB: It would be a happy state of affairs if someone could speak to Mr Kennett and point these matters out. I do not think my advice from this side of the chamber would readily find favour with him, but I am not alone in pointing out these matters, and there are people on the other side who may well take it up with him. I refer, for example, to statements from Senator Short, made on 16 September 1987, when the Ministers of State Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Administrative Arrangements Bill 1987 were being debated in this chamber. We on this side were proposing to increase the Ministry from 27 to 30. In the Victorian situation it is proposed to increase the Ministry from 18 to 22 and to appoint seven Parliamentary Secretaries. Senator Short had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: As my leader, Senator Chaney, has said, the Opposition will be opposing the Bill for one very good reason: at a time when the Government is talking about, and the community is demanding, smaller government, to expand the Ministry by three seems to run absolutely contrary to the theme that that would imply. If we really believe in smaller and more efficient government, there is no way that this is compatible with an expanded Ministry.
He says further on:

So there is no earthly justification for an expansion of the Ministry from 27 to 30. It will lead to bigger government, not smaller government. It will lead to less efficient management of government activities. It will lead to a further lessening of the role of the Parliament relative to the Executive, a constant trend for far too many years now. If we really believe in a parliamentary democratic system, it is about time we took it seriously and considered limiting the size of the Executive Government, and not continually expanding it.

It is on that basis, amongst others, that Senator Short opposed it. He reflected the position taken on that occasion by the coalition. It would seem appropriate, therefore, that the coalition, having adopted that view then and, I believe, still adhering to it, might raise in the forums of the Liberal Party the need for the Premier of Victoria to have another look, and a very close look, at the proposals that are being put there.

PARA.TAB: I notice another statement here from Senator Short on a different but related issue. In Victoria a number of permanent heads have been stood aside and others brought in on the basis of a contractual arrangement. Senator Short, in his speech on 16 September 1987, again says something here that is worth noting in that respect:

SPEECH.PARA: The only sure and certain protection against authoritarian rule in Australian Government is a professional, competent, career Public Service, independent of the favour of Ministers and conscious of its one specialised role in the conduct of public affairs.

The theme I am talking on today is not new. It is one that people opposite are very conscious of. I invite them to take up with the Premier of Victoria the expressions of their outrage—perhaps that is an adequate word—at what was happening, or what they saw was happening, in any event, in 1987.

PARA.TAB: One of the problems in this place is that we are members of parties—that is how we are voted in—and that makes it very difficult for us to act always as parliamentarians. But if, on issues such as this, we can put those party constraints aside in the interests of the parliamentary process, then some good may be done, and we may, in some way at least, act as we are supposed to. So I invite Senator Short, and any others who care to join him, to take that theme up. It was a theme that was accepted also by former Senator Chaney, the Leader of the coalition in the Senate at that time. On the issue of the Public Service, Mr McGauran, the honourable member for Gippsland in my home State, had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The Public Service will always let the Government think it has control, but whether, in reality, it has is a different matter. So the Government should not insult the intelligence of Opposition members by asserting in this Parliament, without any evidence, that because it will increase the size of the Ministry it will have greater control over public servants.In fact, I could assert just as easily that the reverse applies—the more Ministers there are, the less control the Government has, because there is more hiding away in all the corridors of our Public Service.

Mr McGauran is a distinguished representative of an electorate in Victoria. His party, the National Party, is now in coalition with the Liberal Party in Victoria to form a government. It may well be that he will take this matter up with his Party down there to see whether this considerable threat to the parliamentary system is turned aside.

PARA.TAB: Where the facilities of the executive, of Ministers, are increased, and the facilities of those parliamentarians who are not Ministers or Parliamentary Secretaries are decreased, it symbolises the problem that faces Australia so much today; that is, the concentration is upon the executive and the legislature is devalued, or its contribution is devalued. It is proper for us as parliamentarians on both sides of the House to indicate in proper terms—let us not go into hyperbole—our disappointment, our concerns, perhaps even our outrage at what is happening there.

As I say, it is less easy for us to do this than the Opposition, whose parties are in power in Victoria now. Nevertheless, Opposition senators are already on the record as taking this approach, having so strongly expressed their points of view in 1987. I suppose it is simply a matter of honourable senators opposite referring their Victorian colleagues to what they so stoutly said in 1987. Let us hope there is a blow struck in the near future on behalf of all parliamentarians.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon I speak on the process of the appointment of the new Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner. The Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, during its wide-ranging inquiry into superannuation, was able to make an assessment of the ISC and make recommendations about its corporate capacity to cope with the ever increasing demands that it will face in the context of a rapidly growing superannuation industry. We know that as the industry grows, so will the scope for fraud, malpractice and inefficiency grow. Fundamental economics says that excessive growth can result in managerial diseconomies that can arise in large, fat bureaucracies. It is possible that if the industry is not properly regulated, negative influences can increase at a greater and disproportionate rate and ultimately cause harm to a substantial number of superannuants. These points highlight the need for a highly effective and efficient Insurance and Superannuation Commission.

PARA.TAB: The Committee found widespread dissatisfaction with the way the ISC was discharging its duties. Some of the complaints were systemic, that is, they were a product of the ISC's legislative charter, which was found to be limited and restrictive. Other complaints pointed to managerial and operational deficiencies. The consumer groups which came before the Committee saw the ISC as a captive of the industry, not prepared to intervene to correct injustices and excesses but rather eager to uphold the principle of caveat emptor—let the buyer beware—which in superannuation can work only to the detriment of the consumer. The inability of the ISC to handle RBL determinations and answer consumer inquiries in a timely way was also a major point of contention.

The Committee's recommendation that a panel of commissioners be appointed was designed to ensure that the ISC has a policy formulation body that will make certain that the interests of all the key players in the superannuation game have their views taken into account and that the ISC's managerial output is monitored and given an element of quality control not previously evident. A related recommendation of the Committee was that the ISC embark on a program of retraining, staff development and recruitment, so that it could properly discharge its responsibilities, as we envisaged in our report, Safeguarding Super. We know that the ISC was given a real boost in resources in the last Budget. We commend the Treasurer for that. But I am very worried about how those resources might be deployed.

I believe very strongly that the position of the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner should have been advertised. I do not believe it is good enough simply to give it to somebody in Treasury. This allows people to continue to say that the ISC will remain a captive of Treasury. Many expert witnesses have appeared before our Select Committee. These witnesses have not had the opportunity to apply for the position. If we look at relatively recent comparable positions and appointments, we see that Mr Tony Hartnell, an expert corporate lawyer, was appointed to the Australian Securities Commission; and Professor Alan Fels, an experienced consumer advocate, was appointed to the Trade Practices Commission. There are excellent people available outside Treasury, well qualified to fill this position. I think it is absolutely regrettable that they have been denied the opportunity at least to apply for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday, Senator Button attempted to use and abuse Question Time to continue a debate that began in this chamber last week. He got Senator Bryant Burns to ask him a dorothy dixer relating to the automotive industry and attempted then to debate figures that I had used in speaking on the omnibus Bill entitled the Industry, Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Bill 1992, which related to, among other things, extending the life of the Automotive Industry Authority.

PARA.TAB: I said to Senator Button during Question Time, on a point of order, that I was more than happy to debate him any time, anywhere, any place, if he liked, to debate the use of the figures that I had used together with his figures and see where the actual debate really lay, but that I would not stand for Question Time being abused in that manner. So I have chosen today simply to refute the propositions that he put forward.

Senator Button spoke after me in the debate on that Bill last week and had every opportunity to dispute the figures I had used in my speech. He chose not to do so. Presumably, somebody must have got upset, or he must have got upset, about the fact that I said that his personal Button car plan had been a failure, that it had simply resulted in Australians paying more for their motor vehicles, and that the degree of efficiency in the industry had indeed been hampered by his policy and not assisted by it. So I thought that today we might go through some of his debating points one by one.
Firstly, he said that the figures I had used were out of date and that I had used them selectively. He said that I was wrong in my statements concerning the age of Australian motor vehicles. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: That again, appears to be based on a dubious statistical method.

The source of the figures I used was officers from the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, his own Department. I will quote from the answers given to questions that I asked in the Estimates Committee in April this year. This answer was given by his Department to my questions relating to the age of motor vehicles:
Evidence provided to the Industry Commission Inquiry into the Automotive Industry in 1990 indicated that the passenger motor vehicle replacement cycle is now in excess of 17 years in Australia.

In the additional information supplied, there was no hint that those 1990 figures were in any way challenged by the Department or that there were better figures that ought to have been used. His Department put forward that statement.

PARA.TAB: He also sought, by implication, to criticise the competency of my staff, something to which I take singular exception. My staffers, of whom there are three full time, work hard. They put in enormous effort, and I appreciate the effort that they put in. They are also exceedingly competent. I would perhaps draw the analogy between me and my staff and Senator Button and his entire Department. The interesting thing is that my staff and his Department agree on the figures I used. It seems that he is the one out of step.

With regard to the question of competitiveness of the Australian motor industry, I cited figures comparing the Australian industry, in terms of numbers of defects, with those of Japan and the newly industrialising economies. Senator Button might be interested to learn that a report on the industry, published the day after the debate took place last week, put out by the very reputable Centre for Policy Studies, used exactly the same figures as I had chosen to use in the debate. Of course, I had not had the opportunity of seeing the report because it was published the day after that. So much for the figures being out of date.

But the Minister was not satisfied with doing that and he did not cease there. He went on to mislead the debate by claiming that the automation in Australian plants is no different from that in the newly industrialising countries. Next time the Minister might like to tell us the whole truth, reveal it, as did that report by the Centre for Policy Studies, and say that Australian plants have a low level of automation compared with overseas plants.

Perhaps he would like to use the figures that show that the average productivity of Australian assembly plants in 1989 was 39 hours per vehicle compared with an average of only 16 hours in Japan and 25 hours in North America. Perhaps Senator Button would like to use the words he used back in 1984 when he hailed his car plan and the policy initiative that would provide ordinary Australian families with affordable Australian cars. That simply has not proven to be the case and indeed that is why sales are down.
Perhaps Senator Button may remember his exchange with Warwick Beutler on the ABC on 29 May 1984. Warwick Beutler said:

SPEECH.PARA: Well what does the consumer get out of this—
that is, the Minister's car plan—
Does he get a cheaper product? Are you guaranteeing this?
The good Senator and Minister replied:
Yes, in real terms the consumer will get a cheaper product over the life of this plan.
Beutler then asked, `When?' and Button replied:

Well I think the effect of increased efficiencies in the industry and longer volume runs and so on will be seen in three or four years. And certainly by 1992 the consumer should be getting a much better deal in real terms from Australian manufactured cars.

The Minister set the standard for 1992. One can play with the figures all one likes, but at the end of the day the Minister fails his own test. The Minister's own Automotive Industry Authority—that is the one whose life we just extended—admitted the failure of this simple test in March this year. At page 57 of the report on the state of the automotive industry in 1991, the Authority states:

In December 1984 the purchase of a typical Australian produced six cylinder automatic sedan priced at approximately $13,000 required 33 weeks full-time gross earnings. In December 1991 a typical large car with a recommended retail price of $24,600 required just over 40 weeks of earnings.

At the end of the day this is what counts. The Minister has attacked my figures; he has attacked my staff. He set the standard back in 1984 and his own industry authority says he failed. As I said, I would be delighted to debate this matter with the Minister at any time, any place.

PARA.TAB: If I might just put an addendum: in the Senate the other day the Minister sent across to me his equivalent of a sealed envelope. He sent me a large, sealed, brown paper envelope. When I opened it, it was full of things which presumably the Minister thought were fit and able for him to throw away. Perhaps he should have checked first. One of the things he sent me was a briefing note. It was a briefing note relating to a Customs matter and particular criticisms relating to the Compile system. I am very pleased to tell the Minister that this particular note has been of great use and interest to me and he can send me a sealed envelope any time he likes.
The one thing I would say is this: would the Minister mind checking his facts and, please, when he has got a whole department to do it for him, would he mind getting them a little more accurate?

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Parliamentary Delegation to the European Parliamentary Institutions

TALK.START.PARA: —In September last I was a member of the Australian parliamentary delegation to visit the European parliamentary institutions. It was led by Mr Peter Morris and the deputy leader was Mr Bruce Reid. Also accompanying us were Mr John Langmore, Mr Peter McGauran and Mr Gary Punch. I pay tribute to those members of the delegation for their company and for the stimulating debate we had on that trip.

PARA.TAB: The visit was to the European Parliament, the OECD and the Council of Europe in Strasbourg; the Netherlands Parliament in The Hague; and the European Commission, the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation, the North Atlantic Assembly and the Belgian Parliament in Brussels. On one weekend the delegation went to Ypres and laid wreaths at the Commonwealth war graves. It was quite a touching occasion as we viewed the thousands upon thousands of crosses on the Australian war graves. I pay tribute to the Office of Australian War Graves for the manner in which those graves are tended. On the Saturday night we were at a ceremony in Ypres itself, which one of the British delegations also attended.

On my own initiative I had discussions with the chief executive officer and the chief medical officer of the British National Health Service in London and I investigated the health services in France and the Netherlands. I think it is appropriate that I report today on the visit because on the news this morning we heard that French farmers are demonstrating yet again to preserve the common agricultural policy that is being pursued in Europe.

From the information we were given on that trip, I believe it highly unlikely that the US and the European Community will reach agreement on farm subsidies. As honourable senators know, high EC subsidies are paid to European farmers; and that has been the main stumbling block in the six-year-old efforts to reach comprehensive world trade reform under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

It was interesting to be there and see the emotional manner in which the arguments were discussed. One of the points made was that there has been an enormous drift of farmers off the land in France, from nine million down to four million, within the previous five years. The people of France believe that it is cheaper to subsidise production and thereby keep the farmers on the land, both from the aspect of tending the land—because there is no cheaper way of tending the land than having farmers work it—and from the aspect of preventing the drift of youth leaving the farms. France has the same problem that we in Australia have—a drift to the cities. I do not see that there is going to be any change in that attitude, particularly as we are not regarded, in their context, as being of any importance whatsoever.

The European Parliament is powerless in that it reports back to member countries and does not have legislative power. Hence, the total lack of response to the Yugoslavian conflict. Of course, European unity has been attempted many times in the past. This time the stimulus was the outbreak of two world wars in Europe this century, which in turn led to the Treaty of Rome in 1957. Recently, the second revision of that Treaty, on 7 February this year, was completed in Maastricht in Holland. The Maastricht Treaty was a leap forward in European integration because, unlike the Treaty of Rome, it does not restrict itself to promoting closer relations between individual member states but sets out, instead, a firm schedule of union of these individual states. The Maastricht Treaty embodies three so-called pillars: firstly, European monetary union, which schedules adoption by 1999 of a single European currency and establishment of one central bank; secondly, a common foreign and security policy; and, thirdly, European political union.

As honourable senators know, there was a referendum in France as to whether or not to support the Maastricht Treaty. We were very privileged to be there for the debate before the referendum was held and for the debate that was held thereafter. It is a matter of history now that that referendum was carried by a narrow majority. Earlier this year, on 2 June, a referendum was held in Denmark and it was narrowly rejected. At the time that I was in London there was considerable turmoil within the British Parliament as to what the position of the British Parliament was on this aspect. The Tory Party there is divided on it, although it is supported by the Government, and the Labor Opposition supports the Maastricht Treaty as well. There is discussion about whether a referendum will be held in Britain, but it had not reached the stage of final debate.

The most immediate implication for Australian interests is the risk that the crisis over the Maastricht Treaty may in some way distract the Community from pressing on with getting a successful outcome in the Uruguay Round and proceeding with genuine reform of the common agricultural policy and completing the single market.

On a lighter note, we visited the Dutch Parliament and, to my complete surprise, I discovered that we had no problems with communication in that all school children in the Netherlands are taught English at school and English is the common parlance. We attended the Netherlands Parliament, in the public gallery, and, again to my complete surprise, when it was announced that the Australian delegation was there—and I might mention that it is the first delegation to the Netherlands Parliament—we were applauded by the public gallery. I did not realise the implications of that until I went back to my hotel that night and turned on television, to discover that the top rating television programs in the Netherlands were Neighbours, A Country Practice, The Flying Doctors and The Bush Tucker Man. I then understood the relevance of our visit and why our presence was recognised.

It was also significant in terms of trade—30 per cent of coal imports to the Netherlands come from Australia. Rotterdam is the largest port in Europe and accommodates 32,000 seagoing vessels every year. Although we continue to run a large deficit, the European Community was Australia's second largest source of imports and the second biggest market for our exports in 1990-91. However, I should warn that economic activity in Europe is sluggish, as it is in the rest of the world. The EC is the biggest source of direct foreign investment in Australia and the second largest investment destination for Australia.
