The common agricultural policy is the major perennial irritant in our relations with the EC. Import protection, or export subsidisation, costs Australia up to $2 billion annually in lost income.

It was interesting to note that the occupational backgrounds of the majority of parliamentarians, in each of the parliaments that I visited—I checked this with at least two or three parliamentarians in the European, Belgium and Netherlands parliaments respectively—were firstly, public servants and, secondly, teachers. I found it interesting that there was only one farmer in the Netherlands Parliament. I was told that there was a committee looking at trying to attract people with other occupational backgrounds into the Parliament, particularly businessmen. I think this explains the tendency for decision making to be done by the bureaucrats, rather than politicians, in the European Parliament.

Another thing worth learning about was the principle of subsidiarity. During our one-hour discussion with the Prime Minister of the Netherlands, Prime Minister Lubbers, he emphasised the importance of the principle of subsidiarity, which is the basis of the Maastricht Treaty. The principle is that decisions should be made at local, regional or national level as far as possible, rather than by referral to the European Commission. It was felt that this should be the basis of all decision making; the lower the level that it could be achieved at, the better for the community as a whole.

Although our delegation was from three different political parties, I think it is important to note that, even behind the scenes, here in this Parliament, and while we were overseas, we were far and away Australians first. We acted in complete harmony in the interests of our country. I believe much good was obtained by those who went on the visit, both in an educative sense and in a bilateral sense, for the information that we were able to give the various parliaments that we attended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been some extraordinary activity in the last day or two relating to the disappearance of some money in Ravenshoe. It occurred so many years ago now that it is almost ancient history. Honourable senators will recall that between June 1988 and April 1990—which is when the timber milling company in Ravenshoe went into liquidation—the Government paid some $7.5m of taxpayers' money in a loan and subsidy agreement to Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd to retool its sawmill at Ravenshoe so that it could maintain its work force of 40.

PARA.TAB: The Minister wrote to the company on 19 June and again on 14 September 1990 seeking details of how the $7 1/2m of taxpayers' money had been spent, and some incomplete reports were received from the receivers. The question remained of whether the loan and subsidy assistance had been applied in accordance with the original agreement, so the Minister referred the matter to the Attorney-General on 16 October 1990. Since then we have been led on a merry chase around this Parliament trying to get some information on what happened to $7 1/2m of taxpayers' money. I think it instructive to run, as quickly as I can, through the chronology of what has happened in the last couple of years in an attempt to find out what has happened to that money.

On 16 October 1990, Mrs Kelly referred the matter to the Attorney-General's Department for investigation. In December 1990, the Attorney-General's Department and the Environment Minister's Department briefed senior counsel. In January 1991, further information was sought from the receivers. In February 1991, it became apparent that the receivers were unable to provide the information sought, and the Environment Minister's Department commissioned Price Waterhouse to review the company's records. In March 1991, the Price Waterhouse report was sent to senior counsel. On 26 March 1991, senior counsel reported to the Attorney-General's Department. On 9 April 1991, in response to a question on notice about the investigation, Senator Richardson said:

SPEECH.PARA: I will keep the Senate advised of progress on this matter, as appropriate.

On 10 April 1991, Senator Richardson told the Parliament that the Australian Securities Commission and the Australian Federal Police were continuing to examine the legal issues and that it would not be appropriate for him to comment on the matter until those investigations were completed. He said:
Similarly, it would not be appropriate to release the information provided by the receivers, senior counsel or Price Waterhouse because possible Commonwealth legal action might be prejudiced.

PARA.TAB: I understand that some recommendations on this matter will be going to the Attorney-General within a matter of days.

SPEECH.PARA: This is on 10 April 1991. He went on to say:
I can assure . . . the Senate that we will endeavour to make the information public at the earliest possible opportunity.

On 10 May 1991, Mrs Kelly's office advised a television journalist in north Queensland, in relation to the Ravenshoe investigation, `Charges are imminent'. That was in May of 1991, some 18 months ago. On 29 May 1991, Senator Richardson admitted that $1m intended as part of the assistance package to the Ravenshoe timber mill had been sent by his Department to the wrong company. On 30 May 1991, Senator Richardson told me in the Senate that he would be asking the Attorney-General what action was to be taken. He said:
Certainly on Monday or Tuesday I will tell Senator Macdonald what the Attorney-General tells me that I can make public.
It was at about this time that Senator Richardson was censured by the Senate for the atrocious way he had handled the whole Ravenshoe matter. On 4 June 1991, Senator Richardson told the Senate:

. . . I have a meeting this evening with the Attorney-General . . . on this question to try to sort out how far I can go in informing the Senate of the progress of Commonwealth action. I will attempt to report tomorrow if the Attorney-General tells me whether there is anything that I can usefully add in that way.
We heard nothing until 18 June 1991, when Senator Richardson handed me a handwritten note saying:
I can't report yet—Duffy . . . is still finalising his position.

On 9 August 1991, the Australian Securities Commission commenced an investigation into the Ravenshoe case. It wrote to me on 3 October confirming that. On 13 August 1991, Senator Richardson told the Senate:
The Australian Securities Commission has . . . commenced a section 597 examination—
it turned out that that was wrong, but it was some sort of examination—
and it may well be that at the end of it there will be some more evidence available upon which the Government might seek to take civil action or criminal action, or both.
He went on to say:

I do not believe—the decision to begin the examination having been taken—that a timetable has yet been laid out. But when it is, and subject to the agreement of the ASC . . . I shall inform the Senate.

On 4 September, answering further questions in the Senate, Senator Richardson told me, `. . . the first minute I can I will be on my feet telling you all about it'. That was more than a year ago now. On 3 October 1991, the Australian Securities Commission wrote to me saying:

On the basis of inquiries at this stage, the Australian Securities Commission is not optimistic of successful civil redress in relation to the application of Government funds by Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd. However the ASC is continuing inquiries into other allegations of misconduct. As such, it is not possible to reach any firm conclusion as to the liability of the directors, nor whether they have assets available to meet creditors' claims in the event that civil redress is sought. You can be assured that the interests of the local Ravenshoe creditors will be addressed as the investigation continues and it is possible that they will be contacted by the ASC investigators.
On 5 November 1991, Senator Tate, who had then become the responsible Senate Minister, said:

It is not expected that the investigation will be completed until after December 1991. . . But it is hoped that at least one brief will be available by 31 December 1991; that date has been aimed at. I will not go into the details on the public record but, if Senator Macdonald wished, I could indicate what that brief might be about. . .

PARA.TAB: It may be that some other briefs will not be completed until March 1992. If it proves that that timetable is able to be modified in some way, I will let Senator Macdonald know. I will instruct officers to keep him informed as to whether that timetable looks like changing.

SPEECH.PARA: On 5 November 1991 Senator Tate, again in answer to a question on notice, said:
As far as the ASC's investigation into the Ravenshoe Timber Mill is concerned, it would not be appropriate for me to make any further comment.

On 6 May this year, Senator Tate told the Senate that briefs had been delivered to the Director of Public Prosecutions. On 8 October, just a few days ago, I gave notice in the Senate of a motion demanding that the Government report progress.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday, the Director of Public Prosecutions advised the ABC radio office in Cairns and also my office that the Ravenshoe investigation was dropped `some time before July'. That is what the Director of Public Prosecutions office told not only the ABC radio in Cairns but also my office yesterday afternoon—that that investigation into Ravenshoe had been dropped `some time before July'. That was particularly interesting information. I understand that the ABC in Cairns then got onto Mrs Kelly's office to find out what this was all about. It transpired that the DPP issued a press release early yesterday evening saying that it was wrong in what it had told the ABC earlier and that it was referring to another case about Ravenshoe which it had dropped. That is rather strange when yesterday afternoon the Director of Public Prosecutions office told my office that the investigation in Ravenshoe had been dropped some time ago.

I do not know of there being more than one investigation into the matters at Ravenshoe. It makes me very, very suspicious as to just what is going on. There have now been seven separate occasions when we have been assured by the relevant Government Minister that this Senate would be told what was happening and that it would be kept informed on Commonwealth investigations and attempts to recover that $7m of taxpayers' money which had been misappropriated through this Government's inexcusable mismanagement of the whole affair.

It is very important for the Parliament and the people of Australia to say to this Government, `Just what is going on?'. It is over two years since this money was misappropriated. How long do we, as the parliamentarians of this country, have to wait to find out what happened to that money? Who is this Government trying to protect? Is it trying to protect anyone? If it is not, why will it not tell us something about it? Surely the investigation cannot go for two years without there being something tangible that can be reported to the Parliament.

The longer the Government leaves it before making some report to the Parliament on what happened to $7m of taxpayers' money, the more the Parliament and the people of Australia will be entitled to believe that the Government is covering something up. If there is no cover-up, if there is nothing that needs to be hidden, why can it not tell us what is happening? It was, after all, $7.5m of taxpayers' money, sent for a particular purpose, that was misappropriated, yet we cannot find out any answers in spite of all of those questions. I have been through a lot of them but that is only a fraction of what has happened in relation to this matter.

It is a disgrace, it is a scandal and I repeat the demand I made last week: the Minister must tell us just what is happening. Someone seems to be being protected. It is certainly not the people of Ravenshoe and it is certainly not the taxpayers of Australia. Again I plead with the Government. I was in Ravenshoe last weekend, at a festival the people are having up there. They have tried to forget this terrible period in the history of their town. They are getting on with their lives but they are still very anxious to know what happened to that money. Where is the compensation to which they are entitled as a result of the Government's mismanagement of this whole affair? I ask the Minister yet again: what is happening in relation to that investigation? When is he going to come clean to the Parliament of Australia on what has happened to that money and where the investigation is at?

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AMENDMENT BILL 1992SOCIAL SECURITY AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 17 September, on motion by Senator Tate:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will not be opposing either the Social Security Amendment Bill 1992 or the Social Security Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992. The amendments to the Social Security Act contained in the Social Security Amendment Bill 1992 emanate from the Labor Government's Youth Summit last July. This Bill relaxes the education leaver deferment period in four ways, with a financial impact of $3.5m in 1992-93 and $3.1m in the following financial year. Each of these four initiatives will commence on 2 November 1992, in time for the end of the current school and tertiary year.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, the calculation of the education leaver deferment period will take into account part time and casual work undertaken following cessation of study. Any reductions in the deferment period will be calculated by converting the number of hours worked to a full time equivalent, based on a working week of 35 hours. The coalition supports this initiative on the grounds that it will encourage young people to seek out casual and part time work at a time when, as we all know in this chamber, there are reduced opportunities for full time work for this age group and also the older long term unemployed.

Secondly, this Bill will mean that Job Search and sickness allowance applicants will become eligible for benefit 13 weeks after leaving school or from 15 February in the subsequent year, whichever is the earlier. Currently the deferment period commences from the date on which a claim is lodged with the Commonwealth Employment Service. The coalition supports this initiative at a time when at least 600,000 Australian children are living in poverty, and we all remember the promise of the previous Prime Minister about that. However, we will review this proposal when we win government to ensure that it does not encourage school leavers to seek Job Search allowance prior to seeking employment or training.

Thirdly, this Bill waives the education leaver deferment period when a person returns to income support within 12 months of leaving it. This will mean that people who have served a deferment period and then undertake a training or education course will not have to serve a second deferment period if they re-claim benefits upon completion of the course. Again, this ostensibly seems to be a sensible initiative, given the absolute dearth of jobs available to young people and the growing importance of education and training in developing worthwhile career opportunities. The coalition does not oppose this initiative.

Finally, the Social Security Amendment Bill will waive the waiting period for Job Search allowance if the person is eligible for special benefit during the education leaver deferment period. This will allow people to move straight onto Job Search allowance rather than remaining on special benefit during the waiting period. Again, the Government's rationale for this initiative is that it will provide greater incentive to undertake casual and part time work because of the less stringent test under the Job Search allowance.

While the coalition does not oppose this initiative and will ensure that it is reviewed after we win government, personally I remain concerned that this initiative will provide a means whereby young people will be able to circumvent the education leaver deferment period. There appears to be no provision in the Bill to ensure that someone whose deferment period has been waived must continue to satisfy the more stringent special benefits eligibility tests during the remainder of the 13-week post-education period.

Before moving on to the second Bill, it is necessary to point out that none of these initiatives will create one extra job for young people who are currently seeking employment. Youth unemployment remains at over 30 per cent nationally, while in Victoria it is well over 40 per cent. These figures do not include the significant number of young people who would prefer to be working but who have remained in education because there are no work opportunities. When underemployment and disillusioned job seekers are taken into account, it is not at all unreasonable to assert that the actual rate of youth unemployment could be at least double the official figures.

The Government remains preoccupied with expensive, public sector based, marginal seat targeted, make-work schemes. In stark contrast, the coalition parties have a comprehensive plan which will provide real jobs, real training and real career opportunities for young Australians. Our minimum youth training wage proposal, announced in July, will create at least 100,000 jobs for young people in the first two years of government. In other words, it will virtually solve the chronic youth unemployment problem in one swoop.

The minimum youth training wage acknowledges the fact that the abolition of junior rates from awards has priced young people out of the labour market. Anyone who would like confirmation of this fact has only to ask any employer or small business. Mutterings from trade unions that the minimum trade wage will result in slave labour and the replacement of incumbent workers are hypocritical, given that it is the union movement that has single-handedly removed young people from the primary labour market by abolishing junior rates. As in so many other areas, undoubtedly the electorate will be subjected to a Labor scare campaign. The one that was undertaken during the State campaign in the area where my office is situated had to be seen to be believed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a good result though, wasn't it?

—Senator Ray might think it was a good result, but when he scares people by telling them they are going to starve to death under us and write it in their own language, I find that absolutely appalling. When people get letters that say `You will starve to death under the Liberals', that is appalling and disgraceful, and the Government ought to be ashamed. All honourable senators on the other side ought to be ashamed at writing to people in their own language, with no translation in English, and telling them, `If the Liberals get in, you will be left to starve to death'. It is absolutely appalling.
—The bourgeois shouldn't be let into the electorate of Clayton!
—Senator Ray is chatting away there like a parrot because he does not like to hear that.
—I was just saying that—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Order! I would like the debate to be conducted through the Chair, please.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister is prattling away there; that is what people were told in their own language. They were scared witless. They were told they would starve to death under the Liberals and that was on letterhead from one of their candidates. It is appalling, absolutely appalling. Why do they have to scare people? I cannot believe it. If the Australian public is hoodwinked into thinking these people are honest and care about people then it has got a lot to learn, because that is the sort of stuff they were engaging in during the campaign. That is why they lost; that is why we had a resounding victory in Victoria. And it did not scare them, there were other things that happened. Mr Halfpenny and his mates were floating around and scaring union people in that area as well.

PARA.TAB: The Minister has no solutions. There are no plans whatsoever to resurrect Australia. There are no plans to resurrect us from the worst recession in 60 years. The Minister and I grew up in the boom times in Australia and what he has done is let the next generation down. That is what he has done and he ought to be ashamed of it. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has been totally cornered by his own failed economic policies. The Prime Minister has quite obviously decided to ignore the pain and suffering that he has inflicted on Australians, on the jobless people in Australia and has sunk to the level of totally negative scare campaigns about Fightback. We have a plan and they have not and the public knows that. We have a plan. Where is their plan? They plan for more of the same—more unemployment, more youth unemployment, more kids who have no jobs and no future and no hope. That is what their plan is.

For the record, it is worth pointing out the major facets of the coalition's minimum youth training wage initiative. These are the basic points. The youth training wage of $3 per hour for 16- and 17-year-olds and $3.50 for 18- to 20-year-olds is a minimum wage. It assumes no qualifications and no prior work experience. It will rise with experience and the acquisition of skills. Youth who have higher qualifications or previous experience will expect to receive a higher starting wage. Anyone who is employed for 20 hours or more on the youth training wage will be given a youth training voucher—

TALK.START.PARA: —As soon as you get those skills the employer will bump you off.

—If the Minister wants to have a say, let him do so and get up and speak, not keep interjecting. The youth training voucher will entitle them to train for up to two days per week, with training in an approved program for one year. This way young people will be able to receive invaluable on the job training as well as access to a wide range of off the job training options, according to their particular needs.

PARA.TAB: The second Bill before the Senate is the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992. This Bill provides for a six-monthly lump sum advance payment of family allowance at the first child rate. At the current Government's family allowance rates, this amounts to a six-monthly advance of $135.85. These lump sum payments will commence in January 1993. Having been provided with a copy of the pamphlets and brochures which will be used to promote this initiative, one could be excused for smelling a degree of political bribery in this initiative as well.Of course, originality has not been one of this Government's strong points and a similar pre-election bribe was to provide the people of Wills just before the by-election—and it was for all families, but it was focused, I guess, on those families—with a one-off lump sum family allowance additional payment. But it did not work there. The result was Phil Cleary—most probably an ex-Labor member, but Phil Cleary. It did not work there and it will not work in the next election either.

In the current dire economic circumstances the coalition does not oppose this initiative. To do so would be niggardly when so many families are struggling to survive with their primary breadwinners out of work. However, it must be remembered that family allowance was never meant to be a lump sum payment; it was always meant to be a supplement to wages and salaries and wages and salaries are not paid to employees in six-monthly lump sum amounts. Accordingly, the coalition will not support any future extension allowing access to larger lump sum payments of family allowance.

Finally, this opportunity should not pass without pointing out the coalition's financial commitment to the importance of the family unit. This is another thing that the Ministers on the other side forget. Time and time again they get up during Question Time and bag us for one aspect of our tax reform without looking at the other parts of the Fightback package, and this is one of them: the next coalition Government will double the family allowance for low income families with incomes under $30,000 a year. This would mean that, if this Bill were under a coalition government, the maximum six-monthly lump payment would be $271 compared with the $135.85 they would be getting under Labor. Middle income families with incomes between $30,000 and $40,000 in a year would receive a 50 per cent increase in the family allowance, meaning the maximum lump sum payment under a coalition government could be as high as $203. Finally, all families with incomes between $40,000 and $50,000 a year would receive a 6 per cent increase in family allowance, which is more than the estimated percentage increase in prices resulting from the goods and services tax.

I reiterate that the coalition supports both of these relatively minor social security Bills. However, as the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, so eloquently pointed out last night in the Alfred Deakin lecture, the coalition remains very concerned that the current Australian Labor Party Government seems content with servicing this country's chronic problems rather than taking the measures that are needed if we are actually going to solve the problems.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief. The Australian Democrats support both the Social Security Amendment Bill and the Social Security Amendment Bill (No. 2), but I cannot let this opportunity pass without reminding the Senate that the Democrats have been trying for quite some time—for over 12 months—to reduce not only the education leavers waiting period but all waiting periods. We attempted to reduce the education leavers waiting period for both the Job Search allowance and the sickness allowance.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats have repeatedly called upon the Government to end all waiting periods. While we acknowledge that it has at last moved in this direction, we remind the Government that considerable hardship and suffering have resulted from the delay. If the Government had supported the Democrats' very similar amendments last year, we would not have had so many young people having such considerable difficulty in making ends meet.

Indeed, it has been as a result of the pressure from welfare agencies and other groups that the Government has finally acted. It has finally seen the damage that has been caused and the suffering that has resulted from its policies and its tightening of the social security system—or, as we have called it before, the antisocial insecurity system that we now have. So we certainly welcome the move now, but we remind the coalition parties that they supported these waiting periods in the first place. On the two occasions on which the Democrats moved amendments trying to reduce or remove them, we were opposed by the Government and the coalition.

I remind Senator Patterson that the pain and suffering that she talks about and the problems that we now face in this country were brought about because of the continued support for Government economic policies by the Opposition. So, if we are looking at sheeting home blame to anybody, there is no way that the Opposition can back out and suggest that it has absolutely nothing to do with anything. It is the Opposition that has worked with the Government to reduce tariffs and to deregulate this country. For the Opposition to come in here and suggest that somehow its hands are clean and that it has solutions is something that I cannot let go without some comment.

Finally, in commenting on what Senator Patterson said about the youth wage, I remind her that there are no youth prices in supermarkets; there are no youth prices when we are looking at buying clothes and other necessities; there is no youth rate for the basic transport needs or any sort of entertainment; and there are certainly no youth rents. When I look at some of the proposals of the Liberal Party of Australia, I wish that they would go into more detail of some of the ramifications of those policies particularly for young people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank both the coalition and the Australian Democrats for supporting the Social Security Amendment Bill and the Social Security Amendment Bill (No. 2). Not much of the debate today has been about these pieces of legislation and therefore I will not spend much time, if any, on the detail of the Bills.

PARA.TAB: Senator Patterson, like many other coalition members, comes into the chamber and espouses the virtues of Fightback, but the Opposition is very sensitive to criticism of Fightback. Senator Patterson, very sensibly, moved her electorate office down to Clayton because if one moves into marginal territory one is much more likely to be preselected. That is why my electorate office is in Nunawading. It used to be very marginal. I regret that it is not so marginal these days. Apparently she takes some exception to the fact that the Australian Labor Party won that seat with a substantial majority. I hope she does not draw from that the conclusion that it reflects badly on Senator Patterson having her electorate office there. What it reflects well on is the intelligence of the electors of Clayton and the quality of the candidate that we ran. So she should not feel too sensitive about the fact that the Liberals did not win that seat.

I really think it is a bit of cheek to say that we ran a scare campaign in Victoria. The Melbourne Herald-Sun, one of the most sleazy newspapers ever produced in the world, ran a campaign against the Labor Party for a year. So it is a bit hot for someone in the Opposition to complain about campaigns.

In relation to the more substantive issues, I found it very interesting that, when Fightback was first received in the conservative party room, only three people knew the details of it and yet everyone in the room stood on the chairs and cheered it, without having seen it. Senator Patterson reflected on that today. In fact, she was reflecting on an absolute need to believe in something, no matter what the content of it. Members of the Opposition are extremely sensitive when the content of that document is put under the microscope as they do not want to be disillusioned. They do not want to have their beliefs shattered as they have to believe in something.

The Opposition has gone to four elections and it has been defeated, having had weak leadership and no ideas at all. Members of the Opposition are now embracing a set of right wing ideological ideas and they want to believe in them for the sake of believing and no more than that. Nothing could espouse that attitude more than the Opposition's naive suggestion that as soon as the skills of people on the $3 an hour wage level are enhanced that wage will go up. We all know from experience that the moment the skills of those people are slightly enhanced, and the cost of labour goes up, they will be shed and another lot will be brought in at $3 an hour. It has been happening in fast food chains and one or two emporiums for a number of decades now and it will continue into the future. I thank all honourable senators for their support for these two Bills.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, departed for London late yesterday on Government business and will be absent from Question Time today. During Senator Evans's absence, questions relating to his portfolio should be directed to the Minister for Defence, Senator Ray.

—I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to today's release of the National Australia Bank business survey results and the comments of the Bank's chief economist, Mr Alan Oster, this morning that unemployment will remain at around the current 11 per cent rate throughout this financial year and therefore fail to meet the Government's projected rate of 10 per cent by the end of the year 1992-93. Does the Minister accept the findings of this survey? If he does not, how is it that the 750 businesses surveyed are wrong? When is the Government going to address the failures of its economic program, which is resulting in this ongoing tragedy?

—The National Australia Bank survey has been drawn to my attention. The great bulk of available evidence is that the economy is recovering. Honourable senators opposite select the most pessimistic thing they can find, of course, because they have a vested interest in that. The Dun and Bradstreet survey for the December quarter was also published today. Let me spell out the pattern which it shows. The net figure for businesses as an expected increase in their sales was constant at 17 for the first two quarters of 1992. It improved to 25 for the third quarter and has surged to 35 for the fourth quarter. That shows a clear improvement in business short term expectations.

PARA.TAB: The National Australia Bank survey also shows an improvement in the September quarter and expectations of an improvement in the December quarter. The National Australia Bank survey outlook for the next 12 months deteriorated marginally but firms still expect an improvement in business conditions. That is a correct reading, I believe, of the survey. The survey's negative picture for employment is not supported by the facts or by other indicators for the labour market. The NAB survey shows a negative net balance for employment growth in the September quarter, but the facts do not support that conclusion because the ABS figures show that employment grew in that quarter. This suggests that the NAB survey is overly pessimistic.

There are all sorts of comments from various sectors. The NAB survey is an important one, just as the others to which I have referred are important. One source of the pessimism may be the bias of the NAB survey in that it ignores small business. It covers businesses with 50 or more employees.

The Bureau of Industry Economics has published work showing that employment in the small business sector was much more resilient through the recession than employment in larger firms. That is because of business conditions generally but also because of the substantial restructuring of the operation of major firms which has been taking place in the past few years.

The most recent data from the BIE shows small business employment growing faster than large business employment. Other leading indicators of employment are more positive than the NAB survey. The Australian Bureau of Statistics vacancies figures rose in the September quarter; private sector job vacancies rose 24 per cent in the year to September; and the ANZ job vacancies and the DEET skilled vacancies are also showing slight improvements in trend terms. All I am seeking to do is to put the NAB survey in the context of a number of other important surveys which happen to have been published at the same time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister clearly dismisses the National Bank's concerns, but also he does not answer my question relating to whether the Government sees a need to address the causes of this ongoing tragedy. In other words, as I put to him in the question, will the Government now address the failures of its economic model, its economic program, that is resulting in these terrible figures?
—If anybody had listened to the answer I gave, they would have known that I do not dismiss the NAB survey.
—Yes, you do.

—I do not dismiss the NAB survey. I sought to put it in the context of the Bureau of Industry Economics, Dun and Bradstreet and ANZ surveys. I am not dismissing the NAB survey, and to say that is a misrepresentation of what I said.

PARA.TAB: On the question of addressing the problems with which we as a country are confronted, we have been through this issue over and over again, but let me say it again. In the Budget of last August, the Government initiated some very significant expenditure programs directed to the issue of employment creation. I think that was an important thing to do. It is an important response to cyclical conditions and I assume and hope that in the next month or so when those systems are in operation there will be an alleviation of some of those problems. That is what the Government did about it.

I just make the point again that the Opposition's alternative model—the Opposition has referred to our model—is evidenced by the fact that the Opposition and its Leader opposed every one of the first six interest rate reductions that this Government brought about and opposed the fiscal stimulus in the Budget. As the Governor of the Reserve Bank said, it ill-behoves anybody who takes that course of action to be the first to criticise the levels of unemployment. That is a statement on which the Opposition is stuck and from which it cannot escape.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. What progress has there been in the Government's waterfront reform program? How do these achievements compare with other countries? Will he inform the Senate what will be the Government's future role in waterfront reform?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a good news question for all Australians. The good news is that the back of waterfront reform in this country is now broken, and significant new efficiencies exist on the Australian waterfront. That is good news for anyone exporting or importing. It is the end of this phase of a significant round of micro-economic reform, and it has been reform achieved in the Labor way. The reform has been achieved without disputation, harmoniously, without any industrial relations big bangs and without, as Dr Hewson said at the Press Club, `putting troops onto the waterfront' in order to bring about the reforms. This was done by consensus and the achievement is substantial.

PARA.TAB: I will outline the detail of that achievement. Productivity on the Australian waterfront has now doubled. The work force on the Australian waterfront has been reduced by 56 per cent—more than halved. Industrial disputation on the waterfront is at absolute minimal levels. The container terminal performance is comparable with that of our major trading partners. In bulk grains, the Australian Wheat Board is achieving massive savings and massive labour reductions in the movement of the wheat crop. It is, by any test, a significant outcome and one that should be applauded by all Australians for the benefit it brings to the economy through this significant micro-economic reform.

We have now put in place a competitive framework for stevedoring companies. There is now no longer the pool system of employment. People have to hire from the central labour pool. Labour is dedicated and employed directly by each company. There are now something like 70 enterprise agreements on the waterfront, providing enterprise agreements for those companies and those ports, ensuring competitiveness between stevedoring companies and thus a normal or more typical market and, therefore, using the engine of competitiveness, continuing an ongoing reform on the waterfront without the Government having to be there as a stimulator or as the catalyst for that reform.

We have reinvented the Australian waterfront so we now have an efficient, modern, up-to-date and world level waterfront. To put it in pictorial terms, it is like the `before' and `after' ad one sees in weight loss clinics. Before the waterfront: fat, pudgy and unhealthy; now: slim, taut and terrific. That is the Australian waterfront. The old allegation, `Blame it on the waterfront for shipping delays', now no longer applies.

There are a number of prominent Australians who need to be congratulated—Richard Setchell of P&O; Ken Urry and Col Coventry of AEWL; Brian Squire of Strang; Tas Bull and John Coombs of the Waterside Workers Federation; Mike Chapman of the supervisors; Ministers Willis and Collins for the work that they did; and former Prime Minister Hawke—for putting together this package which helped achieve this reform. It would be a slight on this country and our international position if anyone tried to decry these achievements. It is in everyone's interests to proclaim them in order that commercial people dealing with shipping companies renegotiating their rates are assured of receiving the full reductions because of the efficiencies of the waterfront.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister to inform the Senate what the Government's future role will be in waterfront reform.
—Don't run that Jenny Craig line again.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —It is unashamedly and unabashedly a trim, taut and terrific waterfront we have in this country now. The Government's future role will be the subject of a report to me at the end of this month by the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority. But it is clear now that since the back of reform has been broken the high profile role of the Government can be diminished. We can look forward to the time when we can consider the abolition of the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority so that there is not an ongoing government authority. It has come into existence, has spent three years doing a job and achieving the result, and we can now consider taking it out of existence. The reason we can do that is that we have restructured the waterfront so that the competitive and competition ethic applies. Competition between companies with their own labour and not drawing from a pool will be such as to ensure ongoing parity with the world's best.

PARA.TAB: The significant point about this that I want to make—and it is a significant point, given the findings of the Prices Surveillance Authority—is about the gains achieved at the port not reaching the pockets of the users because some shipping companies have pocketed those gains and not passed them on. One of the reasons everyone should know the extent of these reforms is that, if they do negotiate their contracts with the shipping companies, they should ensure that they get in their new contracts the full measure of price reductions that have been achieved on the waterfront. Already price reductions of between 20 and 25 per cent are common on renewed contracts. But there is more there, according to Professor Fels, and those negotiating commercially should see that they get the full measure.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations and follows on from the answer he just gave to Senator McKiernan. The Minister would have to agree that the major purpose of any waterfront reform was to reduce the cost of using the wharves. In view of his remarks that the waterfront was trim, taut and terrific, how does he reconcile that with his remarks on the ABC's AM program this morning that costs had not reduced for users of the waterfront? Has the Government's generous $430m expenditure on so-called waterfront reform just been a windfall gain to the stevedoring companies and, of course, the retired wharfies while the end users of the wharves, to whom the reforms should have been directed, have received no benefits whatsoever?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Parer gets a proper transcript of what I said on AM, he will see that I have said that the cost reduction—as I just said a moment ago—to users is between 20 and 25 per cent. Senator Parer would also see that I said that Professor Fels's inquiry had found that not all of the real cost reductions had been passed on. But let us not diminish what has been achieved; a 20 to 25 per cent cost reduction is significant in anyone's language. Prices tend to go up, not down, and if we can get a 25 per cent cut, that is good. But what we are saying is that there is more there or, at least, Professor Fels is saying that there is more there—not that nothing has been done, but that there is more there.

PARA.TAB: What I have just finished saying—and what Senator Parer may not have been listening to because he may have been concentrating on how to try to ask his question—is that it is now a commercial issue. We should proclaim what the achievements and efficiencies are, so that people who are using the waterfront can negotiate commercial contracts to ensure that the full measure of gain is passed on to them; so there is a community of interest among waterside workers, stevedoring companies and the users to see that the links in the middle of the chain perform to pass the real gains through. That is what I have said, and that is an important operation of the market—which is something that Senator Parer may pretend to know about but on this occasion appears not to know anything about.

Then Senator Parer had a snide and I might say somewhat sneaky dig, unfairly, about what has been the cost. Of course there has been a cost. But I ask Senator Parer to put against the cost the cost of the alternative model espoused by his esteemed leader, Dr John Hewson. What did he say at the National Press Club? Let me remind honourable senators what he said: he would achieve waterfront reform by, if necessary, putting troops into the Australian waterfront to do the work of waterside workers. That is what he said.

Let us for a minute talk about cost. These significant gains have been achieved harmoniously and without any real dispute, and they have left a legacy of a committed work force determined to do better, working in cooperation with the companies. If those opposite want to put the troops in and take jobs away from people who are standing on some principle because they resist force, the cost will be massive industrial disruption, a work force that is demoralised and uncommitted to making world best practice gains and a huge cost to the users of the waterfront if, indeed, they can have access to the waterfront.
All of us in this country know that the model of those opposite is for massive industrial

ANSWER.PARA: disputation because they hold up to their prejudices a mirror and what they see is an industrial relations policy. Their prejudices are reflected in their policy views. They want disruption, they hate unions and they would like to make war on them. Okay, they can have their ideological predilections, but for God's sake I ask them not to wreck the economy because of them, and not to let their ideology get in the way of good economic management. This is a fine example and a good outcome of good economic management.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister: having spent $430m on reform over the past couple of years—and he does not have to ask Senator Collins—what have been the savings per container in Australia compared to the savings per container in New Zealand? The Minister should know the answer to this question because I asked him some weeks ago and he said he would check it out.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I am now asked a question concerning the comparative savings per container. I have answered this, but the savings overall in terms of the cost to users are between 20 and 25 per cent. The savings in terms of efficiency gains are to move container movement rates to the level of the best in the world, and in the case of the ports of Sydney, Fremantle, Brisbane and Melbourne to have a more efficient container handling operation than the port of Auckland in New Zealand.

PARA.TAB: This morning I was talking to a number of stevedoring companies, and I will not name them and embarrass them here. What they said to me was—and these people are employers—`We have done it better in this country. We Australians have got it right'. If we did it the New Zealand way, one would end up with the sort of attitude that is on the New Zealand waterfront. This would ensure that temporary gains might be made, but long term costs would be incurred because people do not accept the way in which it was gone about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Defence inform the Senate whether he has discussed the future of the F111 fleet with United States officials?

—I did foreshadow in an answer to a question by Senator MacGibbon in a Senate Estimates committee on 23 September that I would have a discussion about F111s with senior officials of the US Administration while I was in Washington for the Australia-United States ministerial talks.

PARA.TAB: I did raise with the Deputy Secretary of Defense, Mr Atwood, and the Under Secretary of Defense Acquisition, Mr Yockey, the possibility of Australia acquiring additional F111 aircraft from approximately 250 being taken out of service by the United States. The reaction from the United States was positive. Since my return there have been further discussions within Government and a team will be sent to the United States to negotiate the purchase of up to 18 F111 aircraft.

There are clear advantages in purchasing these additional aircraft. Not only will this ensure that the integrity of the F111 fleet is maintained throughout its planned life of type; it will also provide for F111 aircraft to be deployed beyond the current target of the year 2010. This latter point is particularly important, given the likelihood that there is no replacement for the F111 currently on the drawing boards.

The Government's action will ensure that we retain superior strike and interdiction capability in our sea-air gap. Our strategy of defence in depth demands that we have sufficient capable assets for surveillance, strike, interdiction and air defence. It is intended that the additional F111 aircraft will be purchased and stored. They will be upgraded and introduced into service as required to meet attrition or to extend the length of service of the fleet.

Given our current and foreseeable strategic circumstances, the Government sees no requirement for any further upgrade of F111 strike capability beyond the current program. The acquisition of these aircraft represents a unique force in regional terms.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I ask: has the Minister seen the article in yesterday's Australian which reports that, in the view of Australia's Ambassador to Burma, recent reforms by Burma's State Law and Order Restoration Council could lead to a review of Australia's policy on Burma? Does the Government accept that there is no justification for giving heart to a regime which continues to deny the will of the people who overwhelmingly rejected it at democratic elections, and will the Minister rule out any relaxation of Australian policy on Burma until there has been a full transition to democracy in that country?

—I am aware of the report in the Australian of the comments by Ambassador Allen. The Australian Government is closely monitoring the situation in Burma with a view to seeing, by the latter part of this year, where developments are leading. These developments include the release of political prisoners and progress in the State Law and Order Restoration Council's implementation of steps it announced as its timetable for political change.

PARA.TAB: As foreshadowed by Senator Evans, the Government will have to make a decision on whether there is anything of substance in the SLORC's announcements or whether the whole thing is just devoid of content. If this is the case, that is that it is devoid of content, consideration will be given to what further steps of a more direct kind are appropriate. As has been previously made clear, until such time as there is significant improvement in the situation in Burma, Australia will maintain the pressure on the SLORC to effect an early and meaningful political change.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. I refer the Minister to an Australian missionary couple, born and bred in Australia, who have returned to Australia for seven months after three years missionary work in Papua New Guinea. Their second child will be born in January next year. The Australian Taxation Office considers them as Australian residents and therefore liable to pay Australian taxes and the Medicare levy. The Department of Social Security considers them as Australian residents and will issue them with health care cards. Despite this, the Health Insurance Commission says that they are not Australian residents and refuses them access to Medicare benefits. I ask the Minister: is this not contrary to his claim that all Australians can get access to Medicare and how does he expect them to pay the medical and hospital costs for the baby's birth?

—There is no doubt whatsoever that it is the intention of the Government's programs—it has been manifested in Medicare and supported for that reason by the Australian people time after time—that Australians ought to have ready access to hospital and health care. Medicare is the structure that has been devised in order to ensure that that should take place.

PARA.TAB: The particular circumstances which Senator Herron has brought to the Senate's attention obviously have some elements which are unusual, but I quite frankly do not understand, if everything Senator Herron has said is correct—and I accept that what he has said is correct—on what basis or foundation the Health Insurance Commission might have made this particular decision. I will ensure that within a few hours that decision is reviewed by the highest authorities within the Health Insurance Commission.

I think we would all hope that Australians in this position, particularly those who obviously are giving such tremendous service overseas, ought to be able to look forward to the birth of their children without any financial trauma or difficulty overwhelming them at a time which should be one for great happiness.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Government considered the French taxation quotient system which reduces the tax liability of an income earner according to the number of persons dependent on his or her income? Would this not be a means of redressing to some extent the problem that is experienced in Australia whereby the income of that person is taxed at the same level, apart from the dependent spouse rebate, as a single person?

—I am not familiar with the French tax quotient system and I am not aware of whether the Treasury and the Taxation Office have examined such a system. I will make inquiries about that and provide Senator Harradine with an answer.

PARA.TAB: On the question of lower income earners with dependants, I did look the other day at an Australian Bureau of Statistics publication on household incomes. I am happy to provide Senator Harradine with a copy of it, but it simply makes the point that the best method of delivery, essentially, of additional household income to lower income families is through targeted mechanisms such as the family income supplement and so on. I am not able to quote precise figures from that document off the top of my head, but I will make that available to Senator Harradine because I think it is an interesting analysis which in some ways is directed at the same point. In so far as Senator Harradine's question is concerned, I will ask the Treasurer to provide me with an answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a very brief supplementary question. The matter to which Senator Button referred is a question of vertical taxation equity. My question—I expect that he will take it on notice—relates to horizontal tax equity.
—Yes.

—My question is also directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In a recent press release from the Treasurer concerning claims for tax losses on the disposal of traditional securities, the Government announced its intention to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act to ensure that a capital loss on the disposal of a traditional security would be excluded from the operations of section 70B. Is the Minister aware that there will be a lack of symmetry in the treatment of traditional securities in that gains will be assessable under section 26BB yet losses of a capital nature will be quarantined losses? For example, a superannuation fund investing solely in fixed interest securities will be fully assessable on the gains yet will have a quarantine capital loss which will never be utilised. Is this not in direct contravention of section 303 and section 304, which are intended to stop this operation?

—I am sufficiently understanding of the question to say that I regard it as an important one. I will direct it to the Treasurer in order to obtain an answer. I do not spend much time reading the tax Act in bed at night; I am an avid student of Hansard.
—You ought to read the Companies Act.
—Senator Baume reads other people's business files every night, but I do not do that. I will get an answer for Senator Watson as soon as possible.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Seriously, does not the Minister's personal tax section within the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce brief him on significant tax changes, particularly ones that fundamentally alter the structure between capital gains and losses and income gains and losses?
—I have not been briefed on this issue. I will obtain an answer for the honourable senator as soon as I can.

—Has the Minister for Industrial Relations seen an article by Shane Green in today's Australian which says that the coalition is intending to announce a minimum wage for workers forced out of the award system that is based on the minimum hourly rate in awards? Does the Government plan to force workers outside the award system, in which case the workers would then be protected by only their minimum hourly award rate? Can the Minister advise of the effect of such a policy on vulnerable workers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —On 30 December last year, 3 January this year and 10 May this year and, in sequence, on the 7.30 Report, in the Australian and on the Sunday program, Mr Howard indicated that there would be a flat minimum wage which, in some cases, would be below the award level and above the level of the dole. We now have an inspired leak from the Opposition, which is releasing its industrial relations policy next Tuesday, that it has backtracked. Either Mr Howard has been done over in the party room by Dr Hewson or the Opposition has backtracked because of the electoral sensitivities of its hardline policy. If it is the fact that it has backtracked, it has said, `It is not six now; it is half a dozen of the other that we are proposing to do'. This is a change in presentation rather than a change in fact.

PARA.TAB: Shane Green said in this article that the Opposition intends to announce that the new base rate for workers will be minimum rates in existing awards. The polling that has been undertaken about industrial relations shows that Australians know what an award is, like an award and do not want to lose access to an award, hence the change in language from the Opposition in an effort to pretend that it will stand by the award system.

But if the Opposition follows the Victorian model—and Mr Howard has said that it will—it will tip everyone out of the arbitration system so that people cannot have access to the Commission, unless by mutual agreement. Therefore, they would be frozen out and could not vary their award. The award then becomes fixed and degrades over time with levels of inflation and the imposition of other costs.

We know that the consumption tax package has adverse effects for 70 per cent of Australian families. The impact of a consumption tax, as proposed, adversely affects 70 per cent of Australian families.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr President. Not only is what the Minister saying factually incorrect but also it is not within his portfolio responsibility to speculate upon the Opposition's policy. He should be asked questions relating to the administration of his portfolio and his program—and he has a lot to answer for within that—and not matters that are beyond the Standing Orders.

—Mr President, I wish to speak briefly to that point of order. The question was based on the options that a government could look at. The option that I asked the Minister to look at, to see whether the Government would consider as being feasible, the Minister is now discussing. I believe he is perfectly entitled under the Standing Orders to discuss whether or not the Government would look at some options which are floating around in the community, one of which may be some of the horrendous implications involved in, say, the Fightback package.
—Order! The Minister was asked a question about what the effect would be if the Government implemented a certain policy. I ask him to answer that question.

—I know that the Opposition is running scared on industrial relations and we have just had another example of it. Under the Fightback package the loss per week for two-income families, with both earners receiving about $25,000 a year, is $25.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Kemp

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr President. I put it to you that the Minister is deliberately flouting your ruling. He went back and tried to debate the Fightback document. Standing order 73(4) states:

INTERJECT.PARA: In answering a question, a Senator shall not debate it.
I also put it to you that is exactly what the Minister is now doing. I ask you to exercise your authority and bring him to order or sit him down.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I gave a ruling. I thought the Minister was complying with the third part of that ruling. He uttered a couple of words before a second point of order was taken. I will listen to the Minister and rule accordingly.

—I was saying that if two income earners in a single family were both on $25,000 a year, the impact of the Opposition's consumption tax on that family unit would be $25 a week or thereabouts. Yesterday we saw the modelling by Treasury of the inflationary impacts of this package.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. Clearly, if there is one thing that ought to be blindingly obvious it is that the question was about industrial relations policy and now we are being told about Treasury's assessment of the GST and consumption tax. It has absolutely nothing to do with the question.
—Mr President, it just so happens that industrial relations is about living standards and incomes.
—Are you speaking to the point of order?
—No.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Bishop

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I want to speak to that point of order as well. From time to time I have drawn your attention to your own rulings. This time I would like to draw your attention to one of a former President, the Hon. Doug McClelland, who said on 1 December 1986:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . the honourable senator's question is clearly out of order and not within the ambit of the Minister so far as ministerial responsibility is concerned.

Quite clearly, the point of order as raised by Senator Alston shows that the answer is outside ministerial responsibility in that the GST is not part of his responsibility, Treasury matters being outside industrial relations. I would ask you to rule him out of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order, Mr President: it would be out of order if Senator Cook were asked to comment directly on Opposition policy. The question put to Senator Cook was: would the Government consider these variations in policy? One of these variations happens to be identical, although it is trying to run from it at the moment, to the Opposition's. It is the history of this chamber that it is quite in order to speak on that. We are seeing a series of spurious points of order meant to interrupt the flow of the answer because Opposition senators cannot take it.
—Mr President, I want to ask a supplementary question. Obviously the Minister has only a few seconds left for his reply.

—Order! I have not called for a supplementary yet. On the point of order, I have consistently made the same ruling that Senator Bishop has quoted from. I have given my reasons why I think the Minister is in order and I am asking him to finish.

—Mr President, on the point of order: would you clarify for members of the Senate that you are re-interpreting the ruling—that you are saying that it does not matter what material he uses; that somehow Treasury is now part of Industrial Relations? Could you make that point clear to the Senate so that we will know it for future purposes?

—I am not interpreting the orders at all. The Minister was not asked about Treasury. The type of question that the Minister was asked is repeatedly asked in this chamber. There is a way of asking questions about Opposition policies. If they are asked in a certain way, they are out of order. If they are out of order, I will call them out of order.

—Mr President, with respect, there were points of order before you that related not only to the question but also to the answer. Mr President, I realise that you were listening to the Clerk. Perhaps I should make the point again. There are two parts to the point of order that has been raised—one relating to the question and one relating to the answer. The part that related to the answer has also been ruled upon by you. You have clearly said that when it is outside a Minister's responsibility he is out of order in dealing with that material. Clearly, Treasury—thank goodness—is not part of Industrial Relations and therefore Senator Cook's responsibility. I would ask you to rule his answer out of order.

—Mr President, I would like to speak to that point of order. It is absurd to propose that when a question is in order, one is not entitled to refer to material produced by some other department to supplement an answer relevantly. Otherwise, nobody could refer to the CPI, because that is done by the Treasury. It is an absurd point of order. It verges on being persistent and wilful obstruction of the business of the Senate.
—Order! I regard the question and the answer so far to be in order.
—Thank you, Mr President. What I think is being obstructed here is this: the impact—
—This is what happens when you have a partisan Chair.

—Mr President, I ask that that reflection on your office be withdrawn. Senator Bishop said, `This is what happens when you have a partisan Chair'. That should be withdrawn as it is a reflection on the Chair.
—Order! I did not hear Senator Bishop's comments. If Senator Bishop said that, I ask her to withdraw it.

—Mr President, it was with a great deal of concern that I heard you ignore Senator McMullan's comment that this verged on a vexatious point of order. The matters that I have raised are clearly within your rulings and other previous rulings, and are strictly in conformity with the Standing Orders. I merely asked for a ruling on those Standing Orders. At this stage I have not even raised the point of debate, which is an equally important point to raise. So if you ask me to withdraw the statement that I made that this is what happens if one has a partisan Chair, I will do that. But, Mr President, it is for everyone to judge rulings that are made and to draw conclusions.
—Order! I made a ruling. I am asking you to withdraw and to withdraw unreservedly.
—Mr President, you said that you did not hear what I said. I said, `This is what can happen when you have a partisan Chair'.
—And if you are saying that you said that, I ask you to withdraw it.
—A point of order, Mr President.
—Order! I am asking Senator Bishop to withdraw the statement that she has just acknowledged she has made.

—Thank you, Mr President. The allegation was that I said, `This is what happens when you do have a partisan Chair'. In fact, the distinction is that I said, `This is what can happen if you have a partisan Chair'. I know that those opposite do not have a very good grasp of grammar. However, if you would like me to withdraw the statement, `This is what can happen when you have a partisan Chair', then I will do it, and I do so.

—At the end of the first year, it would cost the family unit I have referred to $115 a week if this policy were implemented, given the calculation of the impact of GST and given the impact of the inflationary effects of the GST on the Treasury model referred to yesterday and based, essentially, too, on the Opposition's own model—the Murphy model. The impact on families of this policy would be $115 a week after the first year.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Has the Government given promoter Michael Edgley permission for a tour of Australia by the great Moscow Circus, commencing on 26 December this year? Is the Government aware that such a tour would devastate the Australian circus industry and, further, that it would be in direct contradiction of an undertaking by the former immigration Minister, Senator Ray, not to allow a further Moscow Circus visit until December 1993? Will the Minister give an assurance that the Government will honour its previous undertaking to the Australian circus industry, and thereby protect the jobs of Australians in this industry?

—I have no particular briefing on this matter. I am sure that the question of the way in which those traditionally associated with the Australian circus and entertainment can continue in that employment is a matter of concern to many Australians. I will ensure that the Minister for Immigration takes into account any previous undertakings given by the Government. I have no particular brief on the matter, and I will ensure that Senator Calvert gets an answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Can the Minister tell the Senate what progress has been made by Optus in establishing itself in competition with AOTC? Is the Government satisfied that the telecommunications reform process is working successfully?

—I am pleased to advise the Senate that the reform process in telecommunications is beginning to show tangible benefits. Customers have already begun to experience improved and cheaper services from AOTC even before Optus enters the market to a significant extent.

PARA.TAB: Optus itself is taking very large strides. On 7 December this year I will officially open Optus's technical centre at Rosebery in Sydney, which will be the focal point for its network. The Rosebery centre will house one of the most advanced switching systems in the world. It will control the whole of Optus's national, international and cellular networks. Rosebery will be the centre for its operational support system which, alone, will have at least $250m spent on developing software over the next three years. The bulk of this money will be for work done by Australians.

I might add that Optus currently employs close to 2,000 people in its operation—I think the figure is between 1,500 and 1,700. In addition, the centre will incorporate a national training and technology laboratory. This will provide training opportunities involving the leading edge technology. The laboratory will simulate the operation of the whole network, ensuring effective transfer of skills to the workplace.

In stating these facts, I have to say that the achievement of building this plant in just 10 months is enormous. It does not just reflect great credit on Optus; it reflects enormous credit on the Australian technicians who put it together. It is a remarkable achievement to put together what has been put together in just 10 months. It is a great indication to the world of what Australian industry is capable of doing.

Optus is growing in other ways. As I said, its total work force is growing. It is estimated that a further 550 jobs have been created by Optus's strategic suppliers as a result of its presence in the marketplace. That employment growth is in the order of the figures that I gave. Six hundred kilometres of optic fibre cable has been laid between Sydney—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the thousands in Telecom who have lost their jobs?

—Does the honourable senator want cheaper telephone services, or not? Optus already has over 20,000 mobile customers, a market penetration of over 5 per cent in four months. All mobile service prices have fallen because of competition between Optus and AOTC. After nine months of operation, Optus has reported spending $121m already on capital expenditure—48 per cent of that on Australian content—$5.5m on research and development and $9.4m on training.

PARA.TAB: I detail these facts not just because they are impressive and indicate that Optus should be congratulated on this achievement, and not just because they indicate that the Government's initiatives have been a success—which they have. The point I want to make is that Optus is a majority Australian owned company which has expressed its confidence in Australia's future by making this significant investment. Optus has taken advantage of the competitive framework established by the Government, it has cooperated with the Communications Workers Union in the spirit of the Government's enterprise bargaining policy and it has drawn on Australia's technologically advanced equipment, industry and skilled scientific community.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Could the Minister please inform the Senate as to the findings of a report on Medicare fraud compiled by Mr Harvey Bates? Would the Minister please table the report?

—I understand that Mr Harvey Bates did undertake an inquiry on behalf of the Health Insurance Commission and reported on the organisational and operational activities within the Commission in respect of the investigation of medical fraud. The Government believes that it would not be in the public interest to release a report of this nature. Rather, if it were released it would probably be in the interests of those who undertake medical fraud, whether they be the public, doctors' employees or medical practitioners themselves. The Health Insurance Commission is continuing to retain the services of Mr Bates to assist in the implementation of the recommendations which he has made with a view to further enhancing the Commission's anti-fraud activities.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Would the Minister be kind enough to give me a definition of what is not in the public interest? Surely if this is about medical fraud, then the public is fully entitled to know, and so is the Senate.

—As I understand the briefing that was given to me just before Question Time, quite clearly what is envisaged is that, if the report made public the various operational and internal methods of investigation of fraud within the Health Insurance Commission, quite clearly that could be of advantage to those who would then be aware of the way in which such investigation operations or weaknesses or vulnerabilities that have been identified by Mr Bates could be exploited. For that reason it would not be wise to put it on the public record.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the Minister to the Prime Minister's recent statement on his visit to Japan, Singapore and Cambodia and ask: firstly, does he agree that the closer relationship with Japan, to the extent that it was initiated by the Prime Minister, offers opportunities to press the United States for better treatment, in particular, on wheat, than Australia has been receiving? Given the tenor of the Prime Minister's statement, it appears that he has ruled out, or at least weakened, such opportunities. Why is the Government forgoing them and not taking a stronger stand against the United States?

—In respect of United States wheat subsidies, as Senator Spindler knows, Australia has taken that issue to a GATT panel for deliberation and adjudication, and that is the first time we have done that. It is important, I think, that that step has been taken. But the burden of Senator Spindler's request is that as our relationship with Japan improves, whether it is as a result of the Prime Minister's visit or not, and it has certainly improved greatly as a result of that visit—
—Rubbish.
—Senator Crichton-Browne thinks that is rubbish, but anybody who knows anything about it both in Australia and Japan says that. Senator Crichton-Browne ought to read the Japanese newspapers.
—He can't read Japanese.
—He cannot read the English ones either, I know, but if he had that facility, that would be very helpful to him.

PARA.TAB: The problem is that in terms of trade friction between the United States and Japan, a lot of that does relate to agricultural commodities. If Australia tried to use the strength of its relationship with Japan to negotiate with the United States on some of these issues, the response to Japan would be that the United States seeks much greater access to the Japanese rice market, and that would become the burden of the debate. It is a real issue on both sides—namely, access to the Japanese rice markets, access of unsubsidised wheat to the world wheat markets. So, with respect, I do not think that is a particularly good idea and that it would advance things very much.

It is too early to say, particularly in the context of a United States presidential election, how these relationships will develop over the next few years. If I might say so with respect, there is not a great deal of sense coming out of the United States at the present time on international trade issues because the presidential election has very much interfered with that process. But we can hope for some further enlightenment on the issue after that issue is resolved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. But in view of the obvious fact that the United States does not pay much attention to persuasion, can the Minister offer any other actual action that would put pressure on the United States to treat our wheat farmers better?

—It would be acknowledged by the Wheat Board and the wheat farming community that every conceivable action which could be taken in the current circumstances has been taken in respect of subsidised wheat exported from the United States. Those are the best opportunities, and the most hopeful thing is the possibility that in negotiations with the European Community the United States may be able to reach some accommodation on farm subsidies. I do not know whether that is possible or not, but we will know the answer to that question in the next six weeks or so.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services.
