Is he aware of the advertisement placed in the Sydney Morning Herald on 30 September last stating that Aged Care Australia no longer has confidence in the Commonwealth Government's implementation of the aged care reform strategy; that Aged Care Australia refutes the notion that the Commonwealth Government has effectively consulted with and listened to this association in the past in implementing the stages of the reform; that Aged Care Australia is committed to the production of alternative policies and procedures for aged care delivery in Australia? As Aged Care Australia is the peak body representing aged persons hostels around the country, is this not a gross indictment of the Government's policies over the past 10 years? Why has the Government not listened to the association? What confidence can older Australians have in the Government's long term care policies when one of Australia's largest aged care organisations has said it has no confidence in this Labor Government?

—I am not aware of the advertisement which Senator Newman purports to quote from. I am not sure whether in fact she just has not taken the opportunity to advertise the claims of Aged Care Australia in this matter. I certainly have not seen the advertisement; she did not give me the courtesy of a glance at it.

PARA.TAB: I believe that Mr Peter Staples, the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, has undertaken a very extensive range of consultations with those responsible for the provision of nursing home and hostel care for the aged throughout Australia. As I go around—as I am sure other honourable senators do—various nursing homes to open extensions and to meet with residents and with staff, one is aware that the programs of the Government have resulted in the provision of a great number of nursing home and hostel beds and various types of accommodation which certainly would not have been there apart from the tremendous program and the personal involvement of the Minister in pressing for funds to be available. I am quite sure from the comments that have been made to me—both by residents and by staff at the various homes and hostels that I have visited—that that sentiment would be shared by many of them; certainly they expressed that to me.

I also do not accept the allegations about lack of consultation or about the supposed deficiencies of the provision of nursing home and hostel care for elderly Australians. It has to be taken as a complementary program with the home and community care program—the HACC program—where the Government attempts to provide for elderly Australians an alternative to having to go into hostel or nursing home care. That is also a most important program, and I know that in Tasmania it is a great success. I believe that would be mirrored around Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Am I to understand from the Minister's answer that he is suggesting that I misled the Senate about the advertisement from Aged Care Australia? That is the implication from the first part of his answer. Also, does he give us to understand that he has no concern for the lack of confidence by a major organisation in the Government's policies, such that it would spend money advertising its lack of confidence? Does he deny that it has reason to have any lack of confidence? Does it not augur very badly for the future of aged care in Australia when the peak body takes this virtually unprecedented step?

—If there has been one feature of this Government's programs over the past several years it has been the provision of very substantial funding to enable proper, decent care to be provided in a proper setting for aged persons in our community when their opportunity to stay within the community with sufficient support—either from friends, relatives or other agencies—has come to an end. If in fact this organisation has passed a vote of no confidence in the Minister, then it has been misdirected.

PARA.TAB: I believe the Minister does have the support of many organisations and certainly of individual residents. That is the point. These programs are directed to provide for the accommodation and care of elderly Australians in their latter years and I am quite sure that they, as individuals and collectively, would give a rousing vote of confidence in the Minister.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister for Justice to a summing up by a judge to a jury in South Australia in August 1992. The case was about rape in marriage. In that address the judge said:

QUESTION.PARA: There is of course nothing wrong with a husband, faced with his wife's initial refusal to engage in intercourse, in attempting, in an acceptable way to persuade her to change her mind, and that may involve a measure of rougher than usual handling.

Is the Minister concerned about such a statement? Does the Minister agree that this statement is out of step with public opinion or community attitudes? Does the Minister agree that this statement is out of step with the intent of family law reform and the campaigns of this Government against domestic violence? Is the Minister concerned at the difference between this statement and public opinion? What steps can be taken to require our judges to keep pace with changing community values?

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I am not into judge bashing or lashing today. In fact, I would be extremely reluctant to answer a question—though I do not doubt the integrity of Senator Crowley at all—based on a judgment I have not read, particularly if the judgment resulted in an acquittal of the accused, in which case, of course, the accused is entitled under our common law system to be regarded as without guilt. Therefore, I would not comment on that particular case at all.

PARA.TAB: It is a fact that sometimes judges, because of their background and because of the somewhat cloistered atmosphere in which they live, do not keep pace with changing community attitudes—even though I think it was in South Australia in the mid-1970s that the inference of consent to sexual intercourse in marriage was first abolished so that one could have rape within marriage. TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I was asked a question by Senator Archer concerning AQIS charges. I indicated at the time that I would supply further details. AQIS has now provided me with a brief which is 1 1/2 foolscap pages long. I wonder whether I could have the permission of the Senate to incorporate that answer in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
The charges quoted by Senator Archer apply to both quarantine charges for imports and export of plant and plant products, which includes non-prescribed grain, but not prescribed grain.
Prescribed grains are those defined in the Grain, Plants and Plant Products Orders, these are: wheat, oats, barley, sorghum, dried field peas and lupins. Other grains are defined as non prescribed.
AQIS reviews quarantine and export inspection charges on an annual basis. Charges are calculated using estimated costs of individual programs and estimated levels of activity.
The half hourly charge of $86 includes the cost of travel to clients and on the export side also includes the issuance of the first phytosanitary certificate.

AQIS charges not only recover the cost of State employed inspectors, but also State support costs and AQIS regional and Canberra office costs. These costs not only include administrative overheads but costs associated with related functions such as pest risk assessment and continuing protocol development for the various imported commodities on the import side and protocol development for continued access to overseas markets on the export side.

From 1 August 1992 AQIS introduced a daily rate of $745. The equivalent fee for service which was applicable before the introduction of the daily charge would be $1,204. The introduction of the daily rate allows clients, who can increase the consignments being inspected at one time, thereby reducing the travelling time of inspectors, to benefit from reduced inspection costs.

The figure quoted by Senator Archer of $55.88 per hour was raised in an article in the Daily Commercial News on 8 October 1992 by the Australian Chamber of Shipping (ACOS). This figure was based on the assumption that AQIS staff/expenditure ratio was 1.92. ACOS's interpretation of the AQIS staff/expenditure was incorrect and the methodology in arriving at the $55.88 hourly charge was flawed.

ACOS's interpretation of the DPIE `Program Performance Statements 1992-93' was incorrect in developing the multiplier. The salary figure used by ACOS only related to staff employed directly by the Commonwealth which are predominantly meat inspection staff. The cost of employing State Department inspectors on an agency basis for quarantine and some export inspection services are reported as administrative expenses.
Similarly the staffing figure reported does not include the State staff employed on an agency basis.

In arriving at the $55.88 hourly charge, ACOS assumed that all AQIS staff, including technical and support staff recovered charges for every hour they are employed, when in fact only inspection staff charge for their services and then only charge for actual inspection time.

On the matter of the costs of inspection in New Zealand, these are currently $NZ66.60 per hour or part thereof for the first hour and $16.65 quarter hour thereafter plus $NZ0.62 per kilometre travelled plus a certification charge of $NZ14.40 per certificate. Note the hourly/quarter hourly charge is also applied to return travel in addition to the kilometre charge. AQIS charges $86 for the first half hour, then $43 per quarter hour thereafter for inspection time only, regardless of distance travelled which can be much more significant in Australia than New Zealand. The first certificate is provided free in Australia.

The majority of inspections are undertaken within the first half hour charge and therefore for comparison purposes there is some legitimacy in comparing the Australian minimum half hour charge ($A86), which is all inclusive, to the New Zealand minimum hour charge plus travel time plus the kilometre charge plus the certificate charge.

The example for a half hour inspection job which requires the inspector to travel 30 kms (1/2 hours travel) to the job ie 60 kms and one hours return travel, the comparative costs would be in Australia $A86 and in New Zealand $NZ151.50.

It is also understood that New Zealand fees do not, in fact, collect the full cost of the inspection service programs to the extent that Australian cost recovery policy requires. The New Zealand charges only recover the direct costs of inspection services and not all the overheads that go into providing the total service. The structure of the New Zealand Department makes a distinction between the policy development group and the service delivery group such that a number of policy development, technical support and other infrastructure costs are not included in the inspection cost base.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 October, Senator Reid asked me a question concerning what steps the Government would take to protect Jervis Bay from ACT Government legislation decriminalising marijuana. I have provided an answer to Senator Reid and seek leave to have the answer incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: ACT DRUGS OF DEPENDENCE (AMENDMENT) ACT 1992: APPLICATION TO JERVIS BAY TERRITORY
On 13 October 1992 Senator Reid asked me a question without notice as follows: `What steps will the Government take to protect Jervis Bay from ACT Government legislation decriminalising marijuana?'
I now provide the following information in answer to that question.

The Drugs of Dependence (Amendment) Act 1992 of the ACT entered into force on 18 September 1992. That Act provides a procedure under which a police officer may in certain circumstances serve an offence notice on a person as an alternative to the prosecution of the person for a `simple cannabis offence' as defined. The offence notice calls for payment of a prescribed penalty for such an offence, being an amount of $100.
By virtue of the Jervis Bay Territory Acceptance Act 1915 s.4A, that change in the law in the ACT has changed the law in Jervis Bay Territory.

However, provision exists in the Acceptance Act for a law in force in Jervis Bay Territory by virtue of s.4A to be amended or repealed by an Ordinance that might be made by the Governor-General in Council.
It is therefore open to the Government to seek the making of an Ordinance that will, in a particular respect, break the nexus between the law in the ACT and the law applying in Jervis Bay Territory.
It can be expected that the Government would do so where it considered that a law of the ACT was undesirable or inappropriate, such as if it attempted to legalise the possession or use of marijuana.

The Government is satisfied that the new provision, being very similar to a provision that has been in force for several years in South Australia, is not inconsistent with Australia's obligations under the various United Nations Drugs Conventions. I draw particular attention to that part of the ACT Amendment which makes it clear that the Amendment does not change the character of a `simple cannabis offence' as an offence.

As a policy consideration, I point out that the Amendment merely provides a procedure that may be used as an alternative to the ordinary prosecution of an offence in the courts. It is therefore a matter of law enforcement policy and prosecuting discretion whether prosecuting authorities use the new procedure rather than institute a prosecution, just as it is a matter for decision by those authorities whether to take any action at all in a particular matter.
The South Australian procedure is compatible with the strategy endorsed by the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy to this point.

The Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy is currently developing a new national strategy on drugs which is to be considered by the Council in April next year. The Government will await the completion of the new strategy before reviewing Commonwealth policy. Accordingly, the Government has made no decision to vary the application of ACT law as affected by the 1992 Drugs Amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator McKiernan on 15 October 1992 relating to waterfront reform.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important that the boasts of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) in relation to the Government's record of waterfront reform be put into context. We are looking at a government that has been in office approximately 10 years but which only now is claiming some achievements out of this critical area of structural reform. At best, it has to be said that the process of reform in this area has been pitifully slow.

PARA.TAB: The second point that needs to be looked at is at what cost. The cost has been some $430m, which is what has been paid to encourage wharf labourers to retire. Half that amount was paid by the Australian taxpayers; over $200m of taxpayers' money has gone in as an incentive to these people. The other half was paid for by the users of these services, therefore adding to the cost of the use of these services and, in turn, resulting in less competitive rates. When we look at Senator Cook's claim of achievement, we have to take into account that $430m of taxpayers' and users' money has been expended to buy the reforms that he is claiming.

The third point that needs to be made is that, contrary to what the Minister said about reductions in costs, it seems that there is considerable evidence to suggest that costs to users have not significantly reduced at all. As my colleague Senator Parer said in his question, that is the critical issue. The whole process is designed to enable Australia to be more competitive, and that is obviously to be measured in terms of costs. As I said, there is evidence to suggest that costs have not come down at all.
I remind the chamber of what Mr Bernie Derikis, the principal consultant to CRA and a member of the Australian Ship Users Group, said a little earlier this year when he was quoted in the Age:

SPEECH.PARA: From the import-export point of view, it—
that is, the reform process—
has had no impact at all.

PARA.TAB: "It's no cheaper today to export a tonne of metal or onions than it was three years ago. The benefits will take some time to drift through and I'm not confident they ever will. It's very disappointing given the time and money spent.
"The beneficiaries of the reform have been the waterside and stevedoring industries. . .

SPEECH.PARA: Of course that is right, because they have not had to pay for these reforms. As I said, they are being paid for by the taxpayer and the users. These industries simply get the benefits. I am not surprised that the Minister gets up and says that they are supportive of the reforms that he has undertaken. I will continue the quote:
. . . but it hasn't helped our export competitiveness in overseas markets.

That is the critical point. If the Minister could come in here today and point to industries that are now more competitive in their exporting as a result of his reforms, he would be making out a better case.

PARA.TAB: The other point we have to consider is that we are not in competition with ourselves. The question now is whether our wharves are more competitive as opposed to the wharves of those with whom we compete. It is true that the rate of turnover of containers per hour has improved under this Government's slow process of reform from 12 to 18. But compare that figure with those of ports in other countries: Yokohama, 29; Everglades, 28; Charleston, 30; Philadelphia, 31; Houston, 27; and New Orleans, 29. The bottom line of that is that we are not doing well enough. Compared with those with whom we are competing, we are not competitive. When this Minister can come in and demonstrate that our wharves are more competitive with the wharves of others, he will better make his case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a sad day for the Senate when a significant achievement—something that was said could not be done but which has now been successfully carried through without disputation and about which we are publishing a document—is denigrated, besmirched and belittled here. When I answered the question that was put to me by Senator McKiernan, I said that this is an occasion for joy and celebration for all Australians.

PARA.TAB: People said that waterfront reform could not be achieved in this country. At the National Press Club, John Hewson said that reform was so difficult that he would be prepared to put the troops on the Australian waterfront and risk what would amount to an industrial civil war in Australia.

The reform that has been achieved has been achieved harmoniously. The Waterside Workers Federation and the Foremen Stevedores Association have worked very closely and cooperatively with the stevedoring companies and with the shipping users, who have just been referred to, and with the Government to bring about the reform. What are the statistics? A work force has been reduced by 56 per cent voluntarily. The workers have mostly gone by redundancy. We now have a work force less than half of what applied previously putting out more production and achieving a doubling of waterfront production. Is that an outcome that we should condemn? Is that an outcome that we should deride? Of course it is an outcome that is a significant achievement.

When I named employers and union people who had worked to achieve this result, I meant for the Senate to recognise that we as Australians ought to pay them due thanks for achieving that. Australian ports are now competitive in the world. A representative of an Australian shipping company said to me, `In the past you could be absolutely sure when your ship would get to Australia, but you could never be sure when it would leave'. Now one can be sure of both. The ports are efficient, the ship turnaround time is much reduced, and the ability to load containers more rapidly is vastly increased. The productivity of the individual worker, because workers are more skilled, have wider training and operate more complicated and sophisticated equipment, is vastly improved as well.

Industrial disputes, the old bete noire of the waterfront in Australia, are at an all time record low. Because the structure of the labour force has now been changed, no longer is it a pool system from which individual employers hire labour when they need it. That has been dissolved. The system that now applies is that waterside workers are employed directly by the companies and there is a competition ethic applying here so the companies compete with each other for the services of would-be contractors. Thus, the competition ensures continuing greater efficiency. They are reasons for Australian pride. They are reasons to say, `We in this country can do things for ourselves and achieve good results'.

I just heard someone say that if I could point to more examples, I would be more convincing. In the grain industry, bulk loading—the Australian Grains Council has commented on this—has improved rapidly and to much acclaim in the rural sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —But not to do with waterfront reform.

—It is due absolutely to waterfront reform. When people in this country do something good, we should applaud them. I know that the Opposition thinks bad news for the economy is good news for Opposition members and good news for the economy is bad news for us.
—The Minister's time has expired.

—I would like to speak to the response given by Senator Cook in Question Time to both the question asked by Senator McKiernan and the question asked by myself. When Senator Cook answered the question, he repeated it. He used phrases such as `joy and celebration for all Australians', `the reinvented waterfront', `productivity doubled' and `trim, taut and terrific'. They were the comments made by Senator Cook. They have all the hallmarks of the comments made by his own boss, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), when he has referred to this economy over the past few years. Do honourable senators remember the terms he used to use, such as `beautiful numbers'? The country was going out backwards and he was talking about beautiful numbers.

PARA.TAB: In a Budget not so long ago the Prime Minister said, `This Budget will bring home the bacon'. He brought home the bacon all right—and very rancid sort of stuff it was. He talked about the recession we had to have, and then said, `The recession has been over for a long time'. One million people are out of work and he is talking about the recession being over. Then, lo and behold, only a week or two ago he actually said that he had saved Australia.

We are getting the same language from Senator Cook. Senator Cook is quite incorrect when he said that we agree there has been some improvement. We are complaining that $430m or thereabouts of taxpayers' money or users' money has been used over the past couple of years to make the waterfront more efficient.

Because we have a foreign debt that is approaching $155 billion, we desperately need to have one of the most efficient waterfronts in the world. It is no good increasing efficiency by 20 or 15 per cent when the rest of the world is increasing efficiency by 80 or 100 per cent. We are concerned that in fact we are going backwards.

In response to me, Senator Cook said that he thought container efficiency had gone up by about 20 or 25 per cent. For the money outlaid, that is a pretty lousy return, particularly when the people who received redundancy pay outs had not worked anyway. In fact, it is probably more correct to say that money was paid to retire people and get them off the payroll. It just shows how the system had been featherbedded over a long period for no other reason than sheer militancy and Mafia-style standover tactics.

What is the real situation? Let me outline our concern—and this is the basis of my question: the real reason for improving waterfront efficiency is to make it cheaper for the users of the waterfront, whether they be importers or exporters. One can go through all the machinations in the world, spend the $400m and double the output, but if the user pays the same amount of money or more than he or she did before, the money will be wasted.

Some months ago I said to Senator Cook, `Give us an idea just how the costs have changed to the user compared with New Zealand'. He should have known the answer but he did not give it to me. The latest figures that I had when I asked him the question show that in New Zealand—which now has a reputation, regrettably, as a place more desirable to make investments than Australia—the cost of moving a 20 foot equivalent unit container has been reduced from $298 to $166; in Australia, it has dropped from $282 to $278, or $4 per container. What an absolute disgrace! Why have we wasted this taxpayers' money to achieve that sort of efficiency increase?

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to support the proposition put by Senator Hill and Senator Parer that the bottom line of waterfront reform must be lower costs to consumers. Members of Importers Against Port Services and Charges said recently in evidence to the Prices Surveillance Authority that they were losing more than $60m annually through unjustified extra charges by shipping companies.

PARA.TAB: I want to touch on another matter which I think really puts this whole matter into perspective. I refer to the case of the Jill Coast in Western Australia last May. I raised this matter in the Senate at that time. I will summarise the situation. Two stevedoring companies quoted $30 a tonne and $36 a tonne plus their additional charges, which amounted to about 50 per cent of both those figures. Ocean Bridge Shipping Pty Ltd, the owners of the vessel called the Jill Coast, believed, on the basis of those quotes, that it would be too costly to ship the 700 tonnes of potatoes it wanted to ship to Mauritius. So the company asked for independent quotes from contractors who were prepared to load potatoes. The company received a quote for $7.50 a tonne—a quarter of the cost. That would have been real waterfront reform. If the company had been allowed to accept that quote, the cost of loading the potatoes would have been reduced to less than 20 per cent of the original quotes.

The Minister comes in here and talks about the waterfront reform process, which has cost us well over $400m. I note that an additional claim of $20m has been made through the Advance to the Minister for Finance. We will be talking about that later on today. Although we will have spent $420m, there have been very marginal drops in the prices of handling goods and services across our wharves.

In the very short time which I have, I particularly want to make reference to the situation with wheat marketing. The drop in the price of moving wheat across our wharves has little or nothing to do with the waterfront reform process.

The waterfront reform process is about those people operating in the stevedoring companies and the excess work force they have, and the $420m has been about making people redundant and taking them out of the work force. In fact, the process in wheat was going on long before the $420m was even thought of, let alone implemented. It is quite inaccurate for the Minister to claim that lower grain freight costs are a result of the waterfront reform process. It was going on, it would have kept going on and it would have happened regardless of that. The principal reason for that was technology—self-unloading ships and self-loading ships which do not require the people that were involved in this waterfront reform process. I find it very disturbing that that is used as one of the claims. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise this matter of public importance to add my voice to the debate about the Australian Catholic bishops' wealth inquiry and its publication Common Wealth for the Common Good. I acknowledge the presence in the gallery of Dr Michael Costigan, who has led this inquiry over the last five years and seen it to its completion. I trust that Dr Costigan and the Australian Catholic bishops will take great encouragement from the fact that there was an hour's debate in the other place on the topic of this statement, and that there is a long list of senators—nine that I know of—who have expressed interest in speaking at this time, even though we have the short time constraint of one hour. I express appreciation to Dr Costigan for his work.

PARA.TAB: It is very significant that the Catholic bishops have produced this major statement on the distribution of wealth in Australia at this time, when there is a growing debate throughout the country on the direction to take to resolve our economic, social and environmental ills. It is also worth noting that in launching this statement, Cardinal Clancy refused to say which political party's policies are favoured and, possibly more importantly, which policies fail to satisfy the tests of that statement.

In fact, the statement says that Australians need to change those attitudes and structures which help to create and maintain serious imbalances in our society. In particular, we need to reform our attitudes towards wealth, poverty, greed and consumerism, and the structures that underlie them, thus putting us all on notice—all Australians—that we need to address those pressing social concerns in our economic planning.
The response from the major parties has not been in the least bit surprising. The labelling of the bishops as `left wing ideologues' by the Opposition will no doubt help to—

TALK.START.PARA: —They were not; that was the Commission!

—All right, the Commission was labelled `left wing ideologues' by the Opposition. This will no doubt help to confirm some people's suspicions that the definition of `ideology' is any world view which does not agree with that of the person using the word `ideology'.

PARA.TAB: Bishop Pat Power, who was quoted in the Australian on Monday of this week, would have found it a novel experience to wear the label of `leftist ideologue'. As he said:

SPEECH.PARA: If standing up for the poor and needy is leftist then I could accept the accusation.

I know from my own work with the Anglican Social Responsibilities Commission in Western Australia how easy it is for political leaders to try to discount and marginalise those who hold opposite views from those of the major parties. So this attempt at discrediting by the Opposition is not a surprise. There have been critiques, not just in the political arena but also in the media, that actually debate whether the bishops' statement represents the views of the Left or of the Right. I cite two very interesting articles, one for each position. In the Canberra Times on Sunday 4 October, 1992 David Kemp, under the heading, `Pope's words apt for Australian economy', analyses one of the Pope's encyclicals of May last year as being very supportive of capitalism. In the National Catholic Reporter of 18 September 1992 there is a very astute and detailed response by Richard McBrien to the sentiments in the encyclical under the heading, `Capitalists should worry about Pope'.

PARA.TAB: The Right/Left debate is an illustration of why I phrased the matter of public importance in the way I did. This statement puts all political parties on notice that we need to address those pressing social concerns in our economic planning. This critique transcends the Right/Left analysis. It addresses a concern that a friend expressed to me recently: that Australia is aching for government to show that it has a heart. A government with a heart has been missing for many years. The Australian community has at last found a voice of challenge through this statement from the Commission regarding the need for those hearts' cries to be heard.

Far from disparaging the Bishops and their inquiry, I believe that this country owes them a debt of gratitude. They have been able to do what no government has dared to tackle. They have set out to investigate the way wealth operates in our society, how it follows certain patterns, how it is held and how it is denied to the most vulnerable people in Australia.

It is important that people should remember when this inquiry began. It was not something thought up on the spur of the moment over a Sunday lunch. The inquiry grew out of a deep concern for the well-being of ordinary Australians during that time when greed was good—the decade of the 1980s. The inquiry began to receive submissions in the aftermath of the October 1987 stock market crash.

It is important to acknowledge here other similar endeavours. I draw attention to a book about the situation in New Zealand entitled Hearts and Minds: A Place for People in a Market Economy, by Richard Randerson, published in 1992. The Right Reverend Penny Jamieson, the Bishop of Dunedin, says that Richard Randerson, in his book, gives us some idea of how to go about building the fence that we need to build at the top of the cliff, rather than at the bottom of the cliff, for people who are suffering through harsh and uncaring economic policies: `It is a question of priorities', he says; `Put the people first, and do the economics to fit, and it is all quite possible. There is an alternative'.

As I said, the inquiry that led to the statement under discussion today began in 1987. The inquiry in New Zealand that I have referred to commenced in mid-1988 as a result of the work of the Anglican Social Responsibilities Commission. The book contains materials from seminars that were run in 1991 for more than 1,200 people all around New Zealand on how local communities could contribute to building an economy with a more human face. The title of the book, Hearts and Minds, is a phrase used by the New Zealand Minister of Finance when she introduced her 1991 Budget. The Minister said that the Government was engaged in a battle for the `hearts and minds' of New Zealanders. Mr Randerson felt that her words were prophetic, for that is precisely the nature of what is going on. And I think this applies to Australia as well:

SPEECH.PARA: There is indeed a battle as to whether New Zealand can retain the reality of community in the face of continuing policies which seek to emphasise the individual. Will there be a warm heart of community, or only the coldness of individuals out to pursue their own interest, with diminished regard for the circumstances of those around them?

PARA.TAB: It is encouraging to see the church enter into this debate. The church's right to voice these concerns has been well covered in the debate in the other place. Later speakers may also address this. The bishops did not set out to use the wealthy in the community as a whipping post. Rather, their concern was that, while enormous personal fortunes had been created during recent years, particularly in the 1980s—the greed is good decade—enormous pockets of abject poverty and misery had been created. Cardinal Clancy, in his foreword to the book, states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . many people have recognised the timeliness of the project and see its relevance to the day-to-day lives of the inhabitants of this country. They consider that the churches are well placed to comment on socio-economic developments, and in particular to call for the insertion of moral values into the debate. . .

I believe that Cardinal Clancy is absolutely right. The climate of economic rationalism, so-called, needs to be changed in this country. The wealth inquiry sets out some steps for a new agenda in the public debate on what makes a country rich. No doubt at some point in discussion about Common Wealth for the Common Good someone from the Opposition parties will want to use that favourite ritualistic phrase so much loved of those who hold the power and the wealth in our society, `You have to create wealth before it can be shared around'. There may even be some rationalisation to support such a notion.

PARA.TAB: I want to ask a question of those who would use such rhetoric. The question is this: why is it that, while personal fortunes were being made during the 1980s and while company profits in all sectors were at record levels, the number of people in poverty in Australia grew enormously and the gap between the wealthy and the poor doubled? The trickle down theory is correct in only one part. Of the wealth that is held by those at the top, there is barely a trickle for those at the bottom. I quote from the book Hearts and Minds, which supports the comments made in this statement:

SPEECH.PARA: This theory is what is known as the trickle down approach and is quite inadequate. Unless human needs are specifically identified and put in place as the goals to which all economic policy must be directed, there is no guarantee at all that people will be central to policy making. People must be the measure of any policy. If tens of thousands are to be made unemployed as a result of economic restructuring, then more thought needs to be given as to the way in which restructuring is carried out and to how the unemployed will be provided for and creatively deployed in the mean time.

This task of looking critically and trying to restructure in a way that respects the dignity of human people is the basis and very important starting point of the statement we are talking about today. Before major political parties start attacking those who call for a different approach to social and economic issues in Australia, labelling them as `leftist ideologues', they need to carefully consider their own world systems, world views and fundamental, not to say fundamentalist, belief systems.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your alternative?
—I suggest that the honourable senator read the statement and then we could have a long discussion about it.

PARA.TAB: We have one major party in government, the one which gave us deregulation gone mad and a recession we had to have, causing misery for hundreds of thousands of Australians. On the other side we have a group which wants to ignore people in its mad pursuit of pure market economics. It is time that they were reminded that it is not markets which buy goods and services, it is people, families—the very ones whose case the Catholic bishops are presenting.

For both major parties the message is clear: misery is not defined by statistics and wealth is not the measure of our society's well-being. It matters not whether people lose their job because of some ideologically pure adjustment to tariffs or because of some twisted thinking about regulation and deregulation. What matters is whether people are able to live in dignity and are able to make that most valuable contribution of all to our society—their happiness and readiness to participate in the daily decision making processes which determine the shape of our society.
This statement presents a diagnosis of our society and its message is:

SPEECH.PARA: The Gospel-based values widely accepted by those who work from a Christian perspective to attain a just society include a recognition of the essential dignity of all persons, the need to work for the common good, and our duty to stand alongside poor people and to try to ensure that they are treated justly.

That ours is not a just society is apparent from the great and increasing inequality of wealth and income in Australia, the presence of serious poverty, unemployment and homelessness, and the growth of what is commonly called an `underclass' of gravely disadvantaged people.

It then goes on to make a statement around which our matter of public importance is phrased. Consequently, Australians need to change. We need to change those attitudes and structures which help to create and maintain serious imbalances in our society.

PARA.TAB: I would like to refer to a summary of the document, in chapter 6, which looks at the detail into which this statement has gone to analyse and critique the imbalances in wealth distribution. It looks at some of the causes and it presents a very clear setting out of areas that need to be addressed. There are recommendations in this statement towards the financial system of our country. There is a particular recommendation that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Commonwealth Government monitor the effects of deregulation more carefully, especially in the areas of banking, speculative investment and overseas borrowing.

The areas of employment, housing and social security also have recommendations and an analysis. Other items that are covered are: taxation, health, education, the pressure on families, Aboriginal people and many other signs of imbalance. Time is too short, unfortunately, to draw out the worth in this document, and I urge honourable senators to take the time to study it either in full or through the summary.

PARA.TAB: The inquiry does not subscribe to the conventional notion that governments should of necessity be constantly lowering taxes. The bishops obviously recognise that the services, the structures and the furthering of many of our society's goals require money in the hand of government. Otherwise, as the bishops point out, we will have no means of redressing the imbalances which are evident in Australia today.

It is worth while to reiterate a comment made by Senator Coulter in his debate on Monday, that economic statistics such as GDP indicate a level of economic activity but that it is a mistake to use these as measures of social welfare or well-being of a society. There is a real contradiction, for example, in including the cost of repairing environmental damage from an oil spill as an increase in economic well-being. The same is true of counting spending on the treatment of industrial health problems. This particular point is referred to in the preface of this statement in a very apt way.
The idea of common wealth is being discussed:

In its widest sense the idea of a common wealth refers to a society founded on its shared wealth where wealth is broadly understood. It includes notions of our common possessions or heritage and the general welfare and well-being of the whole population. This rich concept has unfortunately been devalued in more recent usage, being identified with purely monetary wealth and even the gross domestic product.

The idea of common wealth in its broadest and egalitarian sense is reclaimed in this statement, which avoids a double reduction of the humanity which common wealth represents to the purely economic and of the economic to the monetary. Increasingly in Australian culture the measure of worth and well-being has been reduced to an economic calculation and then to a bank balance with a consequent impoverishment for everybody.

As I said earlier, the bishops do not hold back from the necessity of looking at garnering the resources in government to address the problems in our society. They do not resile from recommending a wealth tax, nor from calling for adequate income for those for whom there are no jobs, in all age groups, nor for recommending that legislation be enacted which will protect workers from exploitation.

The Catholic bishops have done this country a great service. They have drawn our attention to issues in a manner consistent with their duty of care to the whole community and not just the rich and powerful—the policy makers. Furthermore, they have done so in a way which is not aligned to the policies and practices of any of our political parties. And, if we care to listen, they have given us all in this chamber a message about our duties as legislators. That message is that Australia's well-being is not to be measured by economic growth percentages, nor by its inflation rate, but rather by the decency in which people are able to live their lives and the compassion and care which is addressed responsibly by government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to make a contribution to this MPI. It is very refreshing to have the opportunity to address the philosophies behind the problem of the economy or the structure of society. I also welcome very much—probably more so than some others—this statement by the Catholic bishops of Australia.

PARA.TAB: Not everyone would know that I have done my little bit fighting the Catholic bishops within the structures of the Church to try to have them on the public record in this sort of way. I certainly do not want to take any claim for what the bishops or Michael Costigan have achieved. But for me it is wonderfully refreshing to find a statement like this coming from the Catholic Church. It has not been seen in this sort of way in recent times. Its statements have more concerned personal morality. It is very refreshing that we have this kind of statement from the Catholic Church.

As Senator Chamarette would understand, my emphasis and the way I might appreciate this could be slightly different from hers—and I am unashamed about that, coming as I do from the Labor Party. I take considerable comfort from the emphases of this document, although I will certainly not claim that it is a statement for and on behalf of the Labor Party; indeed it is not. But it is very clear that a lot of the Labor Party policies directly address the same sorts of philosophies that this document addresses.

It is good to have ex-Senator Chaney; what a contribution he is to a considered and thoughtful approach to things—calling a group of the Church leftist! In fact some of us might say, `Isn't that splendid? We have been looking for that title for members of the Catholic Church for a long time'. But a lot of the Catholic Church has always been leftist in the rightist sort of way. And I would suggest that one might just want to trawl through the history of the Catholic Church—for example, its deep divisions in Latin America, where liberation theology has been some of the thought that has emerged from catholicism in that area at the same time as a very conservative dimension of the Catholic Church was totally opposed to it.

So the battle between different elements in society is reflected very faithfully amongst the Catholic Church population. Mr Chaney, in labelling a certain group of people leftist, may—as Senator Chamarette says—merely be using a term of abuse, but I think also a term of some accuracy. What is inaccurate is to call them ideologues. To have a view that is nominally, in parenthesis, leftist does not mean that one is an ideologue at all. It may indeed mean that one has an emphasis on the importance of the community, the common good, as a priority or at least as being equal with the concern one would have for individuals.

Former Senator Chaney is remembered by me because of one statement he made in this place which I like to cite very often. He stood up in this place and said, `This Labor Government stands accused because its priority concern has been for the poor'. Thank you, ex-Senator Chaney—at least we have been getting some things right. Out of Fred Chaney's mouth came that comment—or should I say `Mr Chaney'? I do not wish to be rude about this man. He is ex-Senator Chaney, Mr Chaney.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wouldn't be yourself if you weren't.

—No, I am not; he was saying that this Government stood accused because it had a priority concern for the poor. Senator Knowles should not worry; I had great fun telling Senator Chaney, as he was at the time, what I thought of that kind of line. He was precisely right: this Government has a priority concern for the poor. This Labor Party grew out of a concern for people in society who were not represented in the decision making areas, a concern for people who did not have a voice, who did not have equity, who did not have a claim on any of the wealth or the opportunities of education or of health care. The history of my own State of South Australia in the 1890s makes excellent reading. I have trawled across some of it because in that time that State gave the vote to women. In earlier times women did not even have a voice in our parliaments.

PARA.TAB: A reading of this history also brought me in touch with the emergence of the Trades and Labour Council and the foundation of the Labor Party. The people whom the women were representing and whom the Labor Party were representing were all those who had no real claim on the common good. They had no voice to articulate or to represent what they wanted, who they wanted to represent them, or who they wanted to be able to make decisions about their access to the common good. It is a delight to find this document from the Catholic Bishops of Australia, although it is not without precedent.

For a long time the Catholic Church has been documenting, through its encyclicals, this sort of concern—the concern of balancing the rights of individuals against the need for the common good. In 1891 it was writing an encyclical of some considerable importance. It makes one interested to meditate on just what were the pressures as a result of which that encyclical emerged—a document that was not at all out of step with what was happening in the Australian society. The same issues were being pushed onto the public agenda.

One of the things this document is concerned with is social justice. As a child in primary school in a modest Brigidine convent in Victoria, I learnt about social justice; indeed, I learnt about encyclicals. So later on when I grew up and joined the Labor Party and people were talking about this exciting motion of social justice, I had to say to myself, `It's not the first time I've met it'. The first time I came across the concerns for social justice was in my home and through the Catholic Church's teaching. I am very pleased to see that in a public document and public debate the Church is now putting some of those issues back into the public arena with the weight of considered and deliberative thought on this issue.

It is important to recognise that it is the Labor Party and this Labor Government that has a policy of social justice. As a member of a Labor government, I feel very comfortable in taking great heart from this document, because there is a lot with which the Labor Party's philosophies concur or coincide in this notion of the common wealth for the common good. We are a Party that has a social justice policy; we are a Party that has concern for those people who are not able to represent themselves. If one looks at the policies implemented by this Labor Government over the last eight or nine years, one sees that they have very much gone to the heart of redistribution of the power, opportunities, and the wealth of this country so that we move towards a common participation of all people, or as many people as possible, in the society that we call Australia.

I do not take any comfort for the many, many people who are currently unemployed and enduring the hardships of that state, but I do take comfort from a Party that is concerned to provide educational opportunities for everyone, and that the education provided to our boys and girls is no longer to be distinguished. In times past, girls had many fewer educational opportunities. In times past, boys and girls from the wrong side of the tracks had little claim on a good education. We have seen those dramatic changes in education.

Senators in this place will not be surprised to know that I am very proud of the Labor Party's Medicare. It is founded on those principles of universality drawn out in this document; in other words, a place in the common good, of fairness according to people's means, not according to how much one can make, and of providing accessible opportunity for people to have the health care they need. Health care and education are probably two of the basic planks of a socially just society.

Last week I went to the Hills in Adelaide to open two homes for people with disability. These people will now be able to live in the community in homes specially designed for them. They are no longer dependent on the care of family or of institutions in the way they had been in the past. This Labor Government has been concerned, in collaboration with local government and local community, to enable people with disability to move into the community and live much more lives that provide them with more opportunity in a society that does not distinguish them or discriminate against them because of their disability.

This Government also saw it as right and proper to support people at the Paralympics. Of course, we are not entirely responsible for that movement; largely the opportunity for people with disability has been something those people have fought for and that is why it is so authentic. We have been delighted to support that because once again we are a society that says all people should have an opportunity to take a place in that society.

Any of us here who can cast our minds back to what it was like even as recently as 10 but certainly 20 years ago would know that people with disability were largely required to hide themselves from society, not to participate in it. Slowly, the people with disability have taught the rest of us that they have an equal place in society and are able to contribute in a whole variety of ways once they have that opportunity to participate. This Government supports that.

Our policies for people with disability are one of the hallmarks of this Government as a compassionate and caring government. So also are our achievements—of course not sufficient, but very remarkable—on behalf of Aboriginal people in this country. The history of how Aboriginal people have been provided for in this country is one of shame. The sooner we replace that history the better. I am very pleased that we have a treaty that is asking all Australians to come to terms with the rights and the claim to justice of Aboriginal people.

This document tends to ask us to look much more away from individual social policies towards what are the impacts of economic policies. It says that one does not actually address social justice by getting the economy right. What we must do is reframe our thinking so that we have principles of concern and understanding of the importance and value of individual people. We can then look at the importance of creating wealth and people's opportunity to participate in the creation of that wealth. Then, very importantly, we can look at just, equitable redistribution mechanisms. That is what I think this Labor Government has done. I have no shame at all and no discomfort as a member of the Labor Party in aligning myself with the broad principles contained in Common Wealth for the Common Good.
I note an article in today's Daily Telegraph Mirror called `Hewson's soft sell'. It states:
Opposition Leader John Hewson said last night he wanted to bring a `human touch' to his hard-line economic theories.
In a bid to soften his image of a cold-hearted economics professor, Dr Hewson said good economics should be devoted to promoting `human happiness and well-being'.

SPEECH.PARA: He goes on to say:

PARA.TAB: What is needed is a good understanding of economics and a disciplined economic thought process, tempered by a human touch—a sensitivity to the needs of the people—

SPEECH.PARA: I would say to Dr Hewson, `You don't add a soft touch after you've established your hard-hearted economic policies'. This document is saying that we have to move away and have the care and compassion, the philosophy, that actually drives the economic policies. I believe that is a very important challenge to the Australian society. How do we value people? Is it because they have $100,000 and a smart car; or is it because they are people, they are born and they live in this society? I believe it should be that. It ought to be that we value people and that we write our economic policies to take account of that value of people—not adding a soft touch or a human touch after the hard line economic policies have been established.

PARA.TAB: Anybody reading the Fightback package would have to be very concerned about whether those opposite could seriously claim to have compassion in their concern for the people of Australia. In the health area, the Fightback package is about redistributing the health dollar away from the public, away from the common good and away from access for individuals to the private AMA, to the specialists and to the private insurance industry. In every way, that health policy runs counter not only to Labor Party policy but also to a concern for universal compassion for people. I would have thought, just looking at the health policy, let alone at any other part of the document of those opposite, that we have to ask ourselves what sense they have of the common good.

It is very clear that the priority of those opposite is individualism: if people can make it, then okay, they will be supported; if they cannot, they will be dropped off and forgotten. That is exactly the opposite of what I, as a Labor Party person, stand up and say, of what I want to promote and of what values I hold as important. The Opposition, I think, does put the higher priority on individualism. One of the things we need to say to Australia is: what does it mean to take to one's heart the common good? What does it mean to take account of everybody's opportunity to participate in the wealth that can be created? Can we seriously say that we move away from the policy of greed, of individual achievements and success bought at the price of other people and the devil take the hindmost? I do not believe we can.

As a woman in Australian society, I have had the pleasure and privilege of being part of recent history that has seen a significant change in the achievements and recognition of women. Women have been a part of society that has been excluded in the past. Under this Labor Government, they have had extensive recognition of their rights and opportunities to participate, to contribute and to play their part for the common good. I am sure that Mr Costigan would know that within the Catholic Church the challenge about the rights and position of women is a debate that is ongoing—and that might be the kindest way to describe it.

In talking about the debate that is ongoing and recognition of the rights for all, whatever their gender, health status, disability or colour, I certainly also enjoy the fact that, if one is in Australia, the debate about one's claim on a piece of, and one's right to participate in producing, the wealth of this country ought to see no distinctions between people on any of those criteria. It is the Labor Party, the Labor Government, that has moved in its years of office since 1983 to extend dramatically the opportunities for all people to participate. It has extended dramatically the rights for people not to be discriminated against. These are matters that go to the heart of what is meant by `the common good'. Nobody can be excluded from participating. This Labor Government has made its policies to take account of its principal concern for the rights of people.

I notice that Senator Chamarette made the point that the statement of the Catholic bishops says, `Reducing taxes is not necessarily the way nearer to God'. I am pleased to note that. I was recently in Washington and, as I wandered along whatever street it was, I passed the Treasury building where chiselled in stone was a quote from Oliver Wendell Holmes: `Tax is the price we pay for living in a civilised society'. It would seem to me that we need to be reminded of that from time to time. What do we do when we pay taxes? We actually contribute to the common good. I think the argument of reducing taxes as low as we can go means that we reduce the opportunity for fairness and equity.

The goods and services tax is a classic example of getting that wrong. It is redistributive: it distributes away from the poor to the rich. On that ground alone, we would have to condemn the Opposition's policy as not taking account of what is the common good but what is the best for the most. It is based on individualism. It is celebrating the opportunity for those who can to get it and those who cannot to be forgotten.

This document is a very important contribution to the debate. I am very pleased to see that the Catholic Church has now bravely taken a step through this contribution into the public arena and into the public debate. I welcome it very much and I look forward to it actually making a difference over time to the way policies are formed and our society is prepared to look at itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to contribute to this matter of public importance. The subject matter of the debate is clearly one that should concern all thinking and caring Australians. I think in many ways it is a tragedy if debates about matters as serious as these are somehow turned into—

PARA.TAB: We know there is an hour for debate and I, therefore, have to say, unfortunately, that unless we all stick to the rules we end up in a situation where others are unfairly treated.
