TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Alston. Please continue.

—I was about to say that the least helpful contribution that one can make to a serious debate of this nature is to claim a monopoly on moral wisdom, particularly for those people to somehow claim—as I understood Senator Crowley to do—that left wing ideology is fine but right wing ideology is offensive. I do not think one can come up with any ultimate or perfect solutions in an imperfect world.

PARA.TAB: I prefer to rely on what I have recently read by Professor Geoffrey Brennan entitled The Christian and the State, in which he says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there is no salvation to be found in politics. No political system, however apparently good, can make an ultimate claim on the Christian's loyalty. There is no uniquely `right' system that can be given cosmic sanction in the sense that it is the single manifestation of God's kingdom on earth. Jesus himself makes this clear: `My kingdom is not of this world'. Political orders may be better or worse, more or less just, more or less peaceable, more or less humane—but none is the source of our hope.

That may be expressed in fairly dramatic terms, but the fact is that we cannot look to politicians, politics, economic systems or political parties for spiritual salvation. As policy makers we must content ourselves with ensuring that we promote a fair, just and democratic society which does take special account of the needs of those who are not able to care for themselves.

PARA.TAB: That is why I deplore those who would say—as Senator Chamarette tried to do—that somehow one political party, the Labor Party, was wrong in promoting deregulation and the alternative political party was engaged in a mad pursuit of pure market economies.

The tragedy of all that is that not one solution is offered. We simply heard statements that care and compassion for people are important and that somehow what matters is living in dignity. We all understand that. It is not debasing the commitment to say that they are truisms in Australian society. However, it does not help to discover a solution if one stands up, as Senator Crowley did, and rabbit on for about 20 minutes as though somehow the Labor Party did have a mortgage on social justice and, as a result, it had saved the vast majority of Australians and it had somehow delivered them into human dignity and out of poverty.

The facts flatly contradict all that. There are 700,000 children living without a breadwinner, 200,000 young unemployed and one and a half million people out of work, given up looking for work or simply underemployed. These are all tragic social statistics. As we well know, during the last 10 years those people on average weekly earnings have had their real disposable income cut by 4.7 per cent, whilst those on six times average weekly earnings have had their income increased by 6.7 per cent.

They are the tragic statistics of what we have been through in recent times. I do not think it is greatly helpful to say that somehow that means that Labor has got it wrong in every respect, nor does it do justice to anyone to argue that somehow Labor has got it right in every respect, as Senator Crowley was almost trying to do.

We ought to look at the limitations of politics and what can be sensibly achieved within the political system. From my side of politics one cannot do better than refer to a speech given as recently as last night by Dr Hewson, in which he said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no room for economic ideologues in economic policy making or in politics, just as there is no room for left wing ideologues.

What is needed is a good understanding of economics, and a disciplined economic thought process, tempered by a human touch—a sensitivity to the needs of the people—to move Australia towards the goal of a just and democratic society.

What the bishops have done—and I applaud them for doing it—is to address an issue which must be of great concern. If there are disparities of wealth and people are being left behind in society, then the first thing one does is acknowledge that and identify the problems. It may be necessary, but it is certainly not sufficient to then wring one's hands and pretend that somehow the current system has failed and anyone who in any way espouses market economics is impliedly lacking in care and compassion.

PARA.TAB: That was really the thrust of Senator Chamarette's contribution. She declined to put forward an alternative approach. Implicit in most of what she said—and in many of those people who would somehow condemn market based economic approaches—is that there is a fundamental distrust of the market and that somehow the solutions to these problems lie in more and better forms of welfare.

We only have to look at the classic welfare state of Sweden which has just cut back social welfare by about $10 billion. Senators will remember that Sweden has a smaller population than that of Australia. Sweden has done this because it can no longer afford it and it also recognises that there has to be a growing economy in order to provide for those needs.

One thing that should have become clear in recent years—and I think the bishops acknowledge it, although, quite clearly, the Commission on Social Welfare does not—is that there have been a number of false gods and socialism has been one of them. The collapse of socialism in eastern Europe is stark evidence of the fact that it was premised on a false system.
One cannot do much better than examine the words of Leo XIII in Rerum Novarum when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is impossible to reduce human society to a level. The Socialists may do their utmost, but all striving against nature is vain. There naturally exists among mankind differences of the most important kind; people differ in capability, in diligence, in health, and in strength; and unequal fortune is a necessary result of equality of condition. Such inequality is far from being disadvantageous either to individuals or to the community; social and public life can only go on by the help of various kinds of capacity and the playing of many parts, and each man, as a rule, chooses the part which peculiarly fits his case.

One would not even attempt to do better than that, but in terms of applying moral precepts to practical economic solutions, one simply cannot ignore the laws of economics, much and all as it may be distasteful to those who have a deep and abiding suspicion of the market place. They abound to this very day and, indeed, Professor Brennan talked only recently of one William Temple, a former Archbishop of Canterbury, who said:
For the Christian there are two options—socialism or heresy.
Professor Brennan refers to:

. . . an apparently widespread conviction that Christianity faithfully pursued leads inexorably to the primacy of `social justice' among political ideals, and that some form of socialism is the only way in which such social justice can be secured.

We all have a commitment to social justice, hard and all as it may be at times to define it, but the reality is that economic issues need to be addressed in a practical and sensible way, as again was said only last year in Centesimus Annus:

In recent years the range of such intervention has vastly expanded to the point of creating a new type of State, the so-called Welfare State. This has happened in some countries in order to respond better to many needs and demands by remedying forms of poverty and deprivation unworthy of the human person. However, excesses and abuses, especially in recent years, have provoked very harsh criticisms of the Welfare State. . . . . . By intervening directly and depriving society of its responsibility, the social assistance state leads to a loss of human energies and an inordinate increase of public agencies which are dominated more by bureaucratic ways of thinking than by concern for serving their clients and which are accompanied by an enormous increase in spending.

I cannot do better than quote Father James Sadowsky, a Jesuit who is a professor of philosophy at Fordham University in New York. He says in a very useful pamphlet, and some of the points will have to be skimmed over because of the shortness of time:
Of course Christians should do what is right by the poor—the question is how to help them. . .
There is no one, clear solution to poverty, no revealed economics. . .
Christians who propose schemes for poverty relief ought to know the laws of economics. . .

Where is the argument to show that over the long haul the quantity possessed by the poor would be greater if only the rich possessed less?. . . A very good case can be made to the effect that the market has made both the rich and the poor richer. . .
The only solution that fits economic reality is to raise productivity and profitability. That means less government intervention. . .
Christians who would really help the poor must work within the limits of economic laws.

All I can say is that I think the Catholic bishops well understand the realities of life. They are not in the business of preferring economic models. They have quite deliberately eschewed pronouncing that one or other political party has the preferred wisdom. They maintain their responsibility to ensure that moral precepts guide decision making, and we applaud that in its entirety.

PARA.TAB: We acknowledge that those who simply concern themselves with greater wealth, greed and consumerism are contributing to the evils of society and that poverty alleviation is an imperative for all decision makers, all concerned Christians, for the middle class and the rich alike; but it is the solutions to the problems that we argue over, and we ought to do that in good faith.

We ought to acknowledge that no-one has a monopoly on wisdom, that there are solutions that have to be addressed with a hard-nosed, not a somehow bleeding heart, approach, and that unless one is prepared to engage in sensible economic analysis one is not doing justice to the cause; one is in fact distorting the true picture which is that hard decisions have to be made. One cannot simply imply that somehow, with a bit more care and compassion, there is a pain-free solution that will commend itself if only people would discover it and put it into place.

The reality is that, in many respects, the Government will never deliver us spiritual salvation, let alone economic salvation. Much is required of individuals. That does not mean leaving behind those who cannot care for themselves. We are very much committed to a welfare safety net. We acknowledge the need for welfare, but we wish to promote a society which will create more jobs and will provide the human dignity that is so essential by giving people the opportunities to look after themselves as much as possible. If we go down that path, we are on the way to building an affordable and caring society—one to which we can all contribute and one from which we will get benefits that we have derived for ourselves.

To simply imply, as many do, that solutions lie with government and that somehow it is a lack of consideration on the part of decision makers that put us into the plight we are in at the moment is far too simplistic. I would hope that what the Catholic Bishops have done in this instance is raise the tone of the debate, and I only hope the Catholic Commission will start to do its homework and proceed accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance before us implies, I believe, a connection between attitudes and economic systems and that the darker characteristics of human nature such as greed are exacerbated by, for example, a choice of economic system—the one at the moment is called economic rationalism—because government bails out or opts out of a role in people's lives. I think the question we ask is: where does economics really fit? Is it the big part of which social justice is a smaller part or is social justice the big part of which economics is an important bit?

PARA.TAB: The matter of public importance states that all political parties need to take into account the importance of social planning in economics. I want to put on the record that Australian Democrat policies certainly reflect the belief that growth for its own sake leads to a waste of human and natural resources and that we should seek to achieve a sustainable economy providing a higher quality of life rather than merely the highest possible level of consumption.

We have rejected for the last nine years the rush of the Hawke and Keating Governments into deregulation, which we believe has put us at the mercy of international money markets. We believe that a totally deregulated economy has allowed the wealthy to get richer, the poor to be trapped in a cycle of poverty and hopelessness and our environment to be increasingly destroyed. Our national impoverishment has continued as our international debt has grown, pushed along by entrepreneurs borrowing overseas. To achieve a just and ecologically sustainable economy, we must compel our governments to give equal priority to social consequences and environmental values whenever economic decisions are made.

The matter of public importance also talks about structures. What are the structures which underlie our attitudes towards wealth, poverty, greed and consumerism? I think the obvious structures are the education system, the mass media, the legal system and the political system. We have a mass media, the worst of which trivialises and deals in stereotypes, such as the ones we always hear, which add nothing to the overall important debate. It glorifies confrontation, greed and consumerism and pays little attention to the outdated notions in its values of social responsibility and community service. We have a legal system which properly recognises private property rights but which is accessible much more to those with greater resources. Wealth is protected and reinforced by the legal system, especially in respect of taxation matters.

The political system is the worst structural impediment to fair policies on wealth and poverty. We have this absurd conflict model which inevitably brings tax auctions and promises of smaller government, irrespective of the real needs of the community. Major parties are dependent upon the wealthy for campaign donations. This is a structural problem which affects policy decisions. There is so much we can say about the good old days, the good old days when I grew up in Australia, of virtually no unemployment, fairly high real wages—

TALK.START.PARA: —Under a Liberal Government.

—Yes, under a Liberal Government; I remember it well—and employees entitled to legally binding awards. But that Liberal Government saw the nexus between industry and trade policies in a way that Liberal governments today do not necessarily recognise.
—The world has changed.

—The world has changed. We had a very progressive income tax system and a State-based system of wealth taxation; that is, State duties, land taxes and property value related water charges. These factors combined to yield a society where the distribution of wealth and income was reasonably equal.

PARA.TAB: Madam Acting Deputy President, how can I only have two minutes left when I am supposed to have 10?

TALK.START.PARA: —Only one hour was allowed, Senator Kernot.

—Today's most powerful symbol of failure in the economic system is the widespread poverty evident in this nation. The major cause of poverty recognised by the bishops is unemployment. We have had a decade of `greed is good', we have seen the pursuit of lower government spending and a massive program of privatisation which is still intensifying. Coupled with this, we have had a winding back of protection, irrespective of the state of the international trading environment, and a winding back of public spending which has seriously undermined Australia's public infrastructure. This has impacted directly on those without the capacity to pay for private replacements. I think it is quite farcical to attempt to deal with this in this way.(Time expired)
—I am very sorry, but the two first speakers exceeded their time limit and that is the end result.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent the time for discussion of the matter of public importance being extended for 25 minutes and that each Senator speaking to the matter speak for not more than 5 minutes.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion will give five minutes to each of the remaining speakers. Personally, I would have liked to see a greater time, but it is apparently felt that we should not extend this greatly. My motion is a minimalist position and it will enable each of the remaining speakers to speak for five minutes each.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand from speaking to Senator Harradine that he has discussed the matter with Senator McMullan and that Senator McMullan has no objection. It is our position that, given that the first two speakers for whatever reason chose to go for 20 minutes instead of 15, in the circumstances it is reasonable to extend that courtesy. Therefore, we would support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Government, Senator McMullan, who is the Manager of Government Business, informed me before he left the chamber and I entered it that prior to my arrival there was some understanding about time limits, that the time limits had not been adhered to, and thus we find ourselves in a position where we cannot fit all of the speakers who were intending to speak within the limit that was set by the Parliament. If that is a true understanding, we now move to the next question: having not been able to do that, should we extend the time available to accommodate them? The Government's position in this, I suppose, is best described as `We will go with the flow, bend with the breeze'—
—Are you insulting the Presiding Officer?

—No. Senator Bjelke-Petersen, otherwise know as Flo Bjelke-Petersen, is a distinguished senator in this place. But I do not think that she would want the Government to go with her in many cases of policy nor, with due respect, would we want to go with her.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—No. I can understand that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although her pumpkin scones are legendary, and in that respect we may wish to go with her. We have no objection to accommodating the motion.

—Before I put the motion, I will just say that I was speaking with the Clerk and was told that, unless a definite motion is made that the clocks be altered accordingly, they have to rely on the speakers themselves to keep a watch on the time. That apparently was not done today.

PARA.TAB: Amendment (by Senator Harradine)—by leave—agreed to:
At end of motion add: and that the clocks be set for five minutes for each subsequent speaker.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As everybody has said, this is a most important discussion, based on the statement of the Australian bishops. It could be fairly said that the statement has not been politicised, which is a very good thing. When people like the bishops make a statement about principles, it is proper that those principles be discussed and that the identities of the bishops not be elicited in a political way.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Alston said, a particular economic system is not proclaimed in this document. What the proper economic system is could be and is debated in this chamber. One thing that comes out of the discussion of the general philosophy that lies behind this document is that there is a very big difference between those on this side of the chamber and those opposite on the question of the position of trade unions.
As has been said by the present Pope, John Paul II:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the right of association is a natural right of the human being, which therefore precedes his or her incorporation into political society. Indeed, the formation of unions `cannot . . . be prohibited by the State' . . .

That means that the unions should not be prohibited not only in form but also in fact. Unions must be given their legitimate right to represent workers. That is brought out on the next page of this document that I am reading, which is Centesimus Annus. It says:
This is the right to a `just wage'—
the Pope is talking about another right—
which cannot be left to the `free consent' of the parties . . .

Another point that has been indicated from this side—indeed, Senator Cook, as Minister for Industrial Relations, has put the Government's position strongly in this respect—is this: in conformity with the general philosophical approach adopted by the bishops and the Pope, it is proper and right that unions be entitled to represent people, that free bargaining, as is being talked about by the Opposition now, is not in conformity with that philosophy and that what we ought to take from this, without politicising it, is that fundamental human right that unions must be given the ability to represent workers and to get them proper conditions. In so far as we deny those rights, we are not acting in conformity with the general philosophy that is behind the document Common Wealth for the Common Good or the papal statements.

PARA.TAB: I am conscious that other people want to speak. I will therefore read only one other quote from the encyclical by John Paul II, Centesimus Annus. Talking about the need to maintain workers' rights, it says:

SPEECH.PARA: This requires a continuous effort to improve workers' training and capability so that their work will be more skilled and productive, as well as careful controls and adequate legislative measures to block shameful forms of exploitation, especially to the disadvantage of the most vulnerable workers, of immigrants and of those on the margins of society. The role of trade unions in negotiating minimum salaries and working conditions is decisive in this area.
If we take one lesson from today's debate, it is this: trade unions are of great importance to the welfare of all people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pope John Paul II, in his encyclical, Centesimus Annus, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The State has a duty to protect the right of individuals to improve their economic well-being and create conditions which will sustain business activity and create jobs.

This is the very objective of Fightback. The goods and services tax is one part of a 20-point agenda for economic, industrial, structural and social reforms which comprise Fightback. Fightback is a visionary statement spelling out how living standards can be raised in the next 10 years. It is all about where we want to be as a nation. The bottom line is that we have to create the wealth before we can spend it. We must create the future rather than wait for it to overrun us.

PARA.TAB: Fightback addresses social concerns by substantial personal income tax cuts which will give priority to families on low to middle incomes—incomes between $20,000 and $50,000 per year. This will mean that 95 per cent of tax paying Australians will face a marginal tax rate of 30c or less. Taking all the Fightback benefits into account, the average wage earner will be at least $38 per week better off. It will also include raising the tax threshold from $5,400 to $7,000, which will free a further 320,000 low income earners from paying any tax at all. Fightback will cut the tax rate for those earning incomes of under $20,700 to 16.2 per cent from the present Government's 20 per cent rate.

There will be a doubling of the family allowance to $20 per child per week where the family income is less than $30,000 per year. There will be an increase of 50 per cent in family allowance payments where the family income is between $30,000 and $40,000 per year. There will be an increase of $300 per year in the dependent spouse rebate for all eligible families with children. Further, there will be an across-the-board 8 per cent increase in all pensions—over $24 per fortnight—and a 6 per cent increase in all other benefits and allowances.

Under Fightback there will be a government check for those over 65 of up to $2,500 and $5,000 for couples to compensate for the effects of the GST on savings. There will be special tax credits for low income earners. Private health insurance tax credits of up to $400 and $800 will go to low income families and pensioner couples respectively to help meet the cost of private health insurance. A huge reduction in the cost of petrol by about 19c a litre will mean more money in the pockets of millions of Australians.

Fightback more than compensates Australians for the goods and services tax. But more than that, it gives genuine opportunity, freedom and choice to individuals and protects the genuinely needy. I believe that it fulfils all the criteria that are encompassed in this matter of public importance. I can see that all of us should support the objectives behind the matter of public importance—and they are fulfilled by the Fightback program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to me that, with the exception of Senator Chamarette, most people who have entered this discussion have really missed the point that the Catholic bishops are making—that is, that fundamental to a human society are a whole lot of values which extend well beyond economic considerations. Economic considerations are but a subset of all those circumstances which should surround proper human relationships on which we build a society. Not only that, the economic rationalist model which underlies both

SPEECH.PARA: Fightback and the One Nation statement is only one model of an economy. So it is a sub-subset of all those conditions which should properly describe a fair, just, humane and human society. That is the essential point that the Catholic bishops are getting to. It does not matter what one does about this or that bit as one re-jigs the economy if one ignores the fact that these other things should be given a much higher priority. Out of that re-ordered priority, one then looks at how those issues can be addressed within the economic framework.

PARA.TAB: There is an excellent book written by an American economist, Herman Daly, in cooperation with a Professor of Theology, John Cobb, which is also called For the Common Good. It appeared in January 1990. One of the things that those two authors point out in that book is that the market system—the market system on which both One Nation and Fightback are built, the economic rationalist model—can never address the problem of equity and the problem of scale, that is, how big an economy can be allowed to grow before it impinges on the ability of the environment, again of which the economy is only a subset, to the point where the environment itself becomes damaged. That is the essential point which lies behind the bishops' statement. That is the essential point which has been missed in most of the debate. I saw John Langmore sitting in the gallery earlier. He was involved in a debate on Sunday night on John Cleary's program. I thought that program also missed that point very substantially.

When we look at the detail we find that since 1983, since the Labor Government came to power, there has been a belief that the market system, unguided by government regulation, would deliver the sorts of socially just outcomes that the bishops are concerned about—give more to the rich, the rich will then invest in productive enterprise and through the trickle down effect the economy will boom and therefore the poor by that process will also be involved in that materially enriching process. It has not happened and it will not happen because the model leaves all those other factors out of consideration. What lies behind the Fightback package is precisely the same philosophy. That philosophy says that if we simply re-jig the economy, lower the tax rate—I point out that of all the OECD countries, along with America, we share the second lowest tax rate in the world—and give more to the rich that money will somehow find its way into productive investment under a deregulated economy which simply has not happened and will not happen.

I wish to pick up on one point because there is very limited time to speak. A moment ago Senator Herron mentioned the decrease in the price of petrol. Senator Herron ignores the fact that Australia has some of the worst air pollution of major cities in the world, we have the second lowest rate of taxation on petrol and we have the third lowest price of petrol of all the OECD countries. He also ignores the fact that under a lower tax regime, plus 15 per cent GST on public transport fares, the poor would be very seriously disadvantaged.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—Well, Senator, 15 per cent GST on all public transport fares plus lower taxation will extend the public transport system rather than simply pull the chocks out from underneath the very poor public transport system that we have at present. That is just one example. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for the brief opportunity it has afforded me today to lend my voice of support and commendation for the statement by the Catholic bishops on the distribution of wealth in Australia. On many occasions since I came into this place in 1986 I have called for a wealth inquiry. A quick look at the Hansard, particularly in 1986, 1987 and 1988, shows that.

PARA.TAB: This statement is the product of a project, as we have heard in the debate, undertaken by the Catholic bishops who also held the view that such an inquiry should be undertaken. As I have said, I believe it is something that governments should have done and should do, as the bishops have now said. Perhaps the Government wishes that it had done it because it may be a little embarrassing for the major parties, as the motion before us says, to be told the awful truth by such an eminent and unbiased group.
I do not need to talk about how the project came about; that has been done in this debate. I agree with Archbishop Clancy when he says in the foreword to the report that many people recognise and:

SPEECH.PARA: consider that the churches are well placed to comment on socio-economic developments, and in particular to call for the insertion of moral values into the debate; to advocate a more explicit recognition by decision-makers that their policies require an ethical basis; and to urge members of the community at every level, inspired by the idea of solidarity, to promote the common good by taking remedial action against injustice and inequity.

I would do my fellow parliamentarians the credit of saying that most people come into this place at least with that motivation. I suppose it is a question of what happens to that in the process of performing our duties here, but that is something we could talk about another day.

PARA.TAB: There is very much that is valuable and timely in this report. Of course, time is very short. I refer to a point made in chapter 6 which is entitled `Imbalances in the Distribution of Wealth and some of their Structural Causes'. I will not quote the whole paragraph because I do not have time. I am referring to the issue of the trickle down effect, which is questioned in the report. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . but history does not show that the so-called trickle-down process either eradicates poverty and disadvantage, or results in a more equitable society.
It is the trickle down effect that is relied upon by the economic rationalists under whom we have suffered for the past decade or so, and it does not work.

PARA.TAB: The report goes on to discuss taxation. If there is one thing that might come out of this report that would be of enormous benefit to good government in this country it is that people would look at what the report says about taxation and would look at the reality about taxation on Australians—the reality that we are third bottom in the OECD ranking as a country in terms of taxation. According to the OECD report 1990 figures, the latest available to us, fairly recently reported, only the US and Turkey taxed their citizens less. If we could come to terms with that reality and if we could look at taxation the way the bishops ask us to look at it, better government might very well be ahead of us.

At the moment we have a situation where whatever the economic circumstances, and whether we can afford it or not, all too often the refuge of major political parties in their drive for government, which is what our democracy is all about, is the fistful of dollars—the tax cuts. Right at this very moment as we approach an election, in a gruellingly long unofficial election campaign, that is what both sides are offering each in their own way. The issue of tax cuts is being challenged in some quarters. I want to lend my voice to that. If from this report we can have a public which is less able to be appealed to by virtue of its hip pocket nerve and its selfishness, then I think this report will have achieved something in the common good.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate my view that this document, a copy of which I immediately bought when it came out, entitled Common Wealth for the Common Good, is most useful and welcome. It reminds us of the wonderful teachings and example of Christ, the founder of the church. It reminds us of the principles which flow from those teachings. Amongst those principles which have influenced me and quite a large number of people is the dignity of each individual human being—the recognition that each individual human being is created by God and has an eternal destiny. That is a destiny which is designed to ensure that that person has everlasting communion with God.

PARA.TAB: This document reminds us that individuals have rights of life and a whole range of other rights which precede the rights of the state—rights which the state is obligated to uphold. These rights include the freedom of the individual and the freedom of conscience of individuals. Another right is the fundamental importance of the family, which is the fundamental group unit of society based on marriage between a man and a woman voluntarily entered into for life. I remind the Senate that that is the definition in the Family Law Act—strange as it may seem.

The issue of social justice has, of course, been very close to my heart through my involvement with workers in the trade union movement. Other rights are the preservation of the common good and the principle of subsidiarity. That principle provides that power should reside with the smallest group capable of efficiently performing the functions for which power is required, so that those over whom the power is exercised have greater control over the people who exercise that power. This is called neo-democracy. The gift of the earth to all humanity is something that very often we forget in our troubled times within this country. People in many less developed countries have far more problems than we can ever think of or imagine. In terms of Christian charity, we have a duty to them. It is not just an option; it is a duty.

I have been somewhat disappointed in this debate for two reasons: first, we do not have enough time properly to discuss this matter; and secondly, the political point scoring that has gone on, from the sort of self-righteousness that was exhibited by Senator Crowley to some of the other comments that have been made in the chamber. I think the bishops would be offended by what Senator Crowley said. It is a relief to see bishops making comments about principles and the importance of morals when economic matters are being considered, rather than, as she suggested, dealing virtually only with issues of personal morality.

That is an insult to the bishops. Has she not heard of those great and recent documents of the Church? Has she not heard of the document that was issued called A fair go for Families? Perhaps she should look at that. Perhaps she should see how the Government's policies on families are offending against the principles that are in that document. I suggest that she does so before she starts that sort of unnecessary reference to the bishops' comments.

My time has already expired. I am sorry that there has been so little time in which to speak in this debate. I look forward at some future date to analysing and further discussing this very worthwhile document.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—Order! The discussion on the matter of public importance is concluded.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Madam Acting Deputy President, I wish to place on record my apologies to the Australian Democrats, who supported my matter of public importance on the condition, which I readily accepted, that it would delay their business for no longer than an hour. It was an error of judgment on my part. I looked at the clock and failed to realise that I should have moved a motion regarding the timing. So I place on record my apologies and I commend the patience of the senators whose comments were cut short.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement on behalf of Senator Bolkus on the data-matching program progress report for the Department of Social Security and the data-matching agency.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to inform honourable senators that this statement is also being delivered in the House of Representatives today by the Hon. Dr Neal Blewett MP, Minister for Social Security. I table a report on progress with the operation of the data-matching program. This report is required by the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act 1990 and has been prepared by the Department of Social Security, both as the data-matching agency and as an agency participating in the program.

PARA.TAB: The other agencies participating in the program—the Department of Veterans' Affairs, the Department of Employment, Education and Training, the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services in regard to the first home owners scheme only, and the Australian Taxation Office—will also be producing progress reports. I seek leave to incorporate the remainder of the statement in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, the Department of Social Security has one of the most sophisticated strategies for detecting incorrect payments and fraud in the world today. It aims to achieve three main objectives:
first, to prevent incorrect payments and fraud from occurring;
second, to detect discrepancies at the earliest possible stage; and
third, to deal decisively with the cases which are detected and to create public recognition of the consequences of attempting to defraud the system.
The Data-matching Program is an important part of the system of controls the Department has in place to achieve these objectives.

Mr President, in the 18 months that the Data-matching Program has been operating, substantial savings have been achieved and will continue to be achieved through the detection and correction of incorrect payments.

The Government expects to save $161.8 million this year rising to $204.2 million in 1995-96 from the Program. In social security outlays alone savings of $146.9 million, increasing to $193.1 million in 1995-96, are expected.

I am confident, Mr President, that the Data-matching Program is a cost-effective means of detecting fraud and incorrect payments, contributing to the framework of controls in place to provide Australia with a tightly controlled income support system.

The costs of the Program for the Department of Social Security, have been associated mainly with the collection of five million tax file numbers and with the implementation of the Program. The running costs of the Program in future years will be small.

Mr President, while most people are honest, there are a few who deliberately provide incorrect information so that they can get more than their proper entitlements. People's compliance with the law increases when they know that the Department of Social Security has effective controls in its system to detect incorrect payments and fraud. When voluntary compliance is taken into account the savings attributable to the Data-matching Program reach further than the directly measurable outcomes.

The Government has also provided for the use of the Data-matching Program to increase access to additional assistance to families in need. Families with children who already receive a Family Allowance payment and who may be eligible for increased assistance in the form of Family Allowance Supplement but have not applied for it, can be identified through data-matching. Since early August 1992 my Department has issued invitations to apply for Family Allowance Supplement to 50,000 families.

Some people were sceptical about how such a program could maintain a balance between protecting public expenditure and individual privacy. But it is clear that this balance has been achieved in the operation of the Data-matching Program.

My Department has fully integrated the privacy safeguards prescribed in the legislation into its operating procedures. Administering the Program within such a strict framework has not been without some cost. However, considered against the standards and procedures the Department would have adopted in the absence of externally imposed restrictions, any additional cost has been at the margin.
The Department is working hard in consultation with the Privacy Commissioner to ensure the protection of individual privacy. The costs have been more than offset by the benefits which have:
strengthened the safeguards already in place to keep personal information safe and secure;
ensured that the Program is conducted in a manner which avoids any unnecessary intrusion into privacy; and
enhanced the Department's capacity to protect public expenditure.
Mr President, the low level of complaints and appeals generated by the Program are evidence of the Department's careful implementation of the Program within the privacy safeguards set for it.

I am confident that, after honourable senators have had the opportunity to consider the agency reports, you will agree that there are substantial benefits to be gained from continuing with the Program.
I commend the Data-matching Program progress report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I also table the statement and seek leave to move a motion in relation to the statement and the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement and the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —After the 1987 election when the Australia Card was soundly knocked on the head by the ability of this chamber to disallow a regulation, the Government proceeded step by step to achieve by two methods what it had intended to achieve through the Australia Card: first, through the tax file number, and secondly through the Health Insurance Commission Medicare file number. We see, slowly but surely as time marches on, the aims and objectives of the Australia Card being achieved through other means.

PARA.TAB: When the former Treasurer brought in the concept of upgrading of the integrity of the tax file number, he made a promise which, like most of his other promises, he did not keep. He said that the tax file number would not be extended any further except for use by the Tax Office. What did we see? In the spring of 1990—I will not be held to that date—we were approached and told, `Well, what we really need now to ensure that people do not cheat on the social security system is to be able to extend the use of that tax file number to check those people who are in receipt of social security'. This chamber expressed concern and that Bill was sent to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, which examined it in detail.

The Government came to the leaders of the Opposition and the Democrats and said, `If you don't pass this, millions and millions of dollars of savings will be lost'. When we look at these reports we see that the savings that were to be achieved were not as great as the Government had said. But given that we accepted that, through the committee process and the committee stage of the legislation in this place we imposed more stringent requirements with respect to privacy on data-matching. I believe that it was evidenced that this chamber plays an important role in being able to put checks and balances on the Executive and the Government to ensure, in this instance, that the privacy of individuals who receive social security was recognised and respected.

Under that legislation, each of departments which are involved in data-matching are required to present reports, and today we are discussing such a report. I want to go through some of the things that are in the report of the Department of Social Security. I should point out I received the report only just before lunch time. Some things concern me as I flick through it. One can see on page 9 the slow, insidious creep of the infringement of our privacy. Somebody said that we lose our freedoms bit by bit. I have forgotten who it was. The other day I tried to look for the quote in one of my quote books—one of my hobbies is collecting quote books. However, I could not find the reference. But here is an example of us losing out freedoms bit by bit.

Later on in the report, the Department complains a little about having to make these reports; it is a bit onerous having to do so. But I will tell honourable senators why it is important that it does. The following statement is made on page 9 of the report:

SPEECH.PARA: A time and date for the delivery of data are scheduled for each agency. The data, in the form of computer tapes or cartridges, is securely sealed in containers and delivered by hand to the Data-Matching Agency. The deliveries are made by nominated officers of the source agencies, receipts are provided and the transactions are recorded.

This paragraph refers to when a data match is required, and the data is taken by transport—by truck or car, I suppose—in secured containers and delivered by hand to the data matching agency, which happens to be located in Social Security. We insisted on this. We asked that that be the method by which it be done, and we were told that was the way in which it was to be done—that the data would be taken physically. The report continues:
At the completion of a data-matching cycle, all data on the cartridges is destroyed before they are returned in the same manner to the source agencies.
While these arrangements ensure that the data is transferred safely and securely, they are administratively cumbersome.

I remember that at the time this was going on I visited Social Security and had a chat to people there. At one point, when the data matching was first starting, I went into one of the buildings and there were ranges of data on small cartridges.

PARA.TAB: The first question I asked was, `Could this data be dumped onto an IBM computer outside the Department and accessed?'. `Yes', was the answer. I asked, `Do you have some way of making sure that somebody doesn't pop one in their pocket?'. It is very useful commercially to have lists of data of people who are on social security. One may not want to send them mailings, for commercial reasons—they are less likely to be able to buy expensive video equipment, take out insurance policies or whatever. So mailings can be reduced. So this does have commercial value.

They said, `Well, no, Senator, we don't'. I said, `Wouldn't it be a good idea to think about having a mechanism so that if somebody takes it out a bleeper goes, the same as when somebody walks into a dress shop, fancies a dress, hasn't got the money and walks out with it, and a bleeper goes.' Yes, they could, and now they have a system. In the new Tuggeranong offices they have a system where the tapes are bar coded, and if somebody were to walk out with them they would make a noise. When I was visiting the new office one of the officers said to me, `Here's your arch'. I do not know whether he meant my arch, or `your arch' in the vernacular. I presumed it was my arch because that was one of the things I thought that they should introduce and even if it does not have an effect, I see it as my arch.

I also asked, `When you are shifting this data backwards and forwards between departments, do you have a log-on time when people leave the department and a log-on time when they get to the data matching source?'. `No', was the answer. I said, `I think you ought to, and it ought to be secure. People could stop off on their way from Tuggeranong to wherever they are going and dump the data down somewhere, and then take it on in'. I feel that, even as an Opposition member, you can have some influence on the great bureaucracy by keeping on asking questions. Now they have the data transferred safely and securely. But the report says to us:

SPEECH.PARA: It is both time consuming and resource intensive to transfer the data between source agencies and the Data-Matching Agency manually.
I do not have to read the rest to tell the Senate what it is going to say. It is going to tell us, `It would be so much easier if we could do it on line'. The report says:

The Department believes that it would be more efficient and more secure if the data could be transferred through on-line computer connections. It would be appropriate that a protocol for such transfers be agreed with the Privacy Commissioner.
Bit by bit they get their way.

PARA.TAB: If we did not have these reports how would we know that that is what departments were thinking of? The public thinks the Government tells us everything and departments tell us everything about the way they are going to do things, but they do not. We are the representatives of the people, and all those hundreds who are on social security in Clayton, where my office is located—they are the people I am concerned about. They give up some of their privacy when they take social security, but as much as of it as possible should be protected.

My maiden question here in this chamber was about social security microfiche floating around the streets of Toorak—dropped, with details of people's names and addresses and what their incomes were. That is an appalling lack of consideration for people's privacy, and here we have a little bit more. I can see the Department wanting to have an on-line connection. What does that mean? It makes it more accessible to hackers. It makes it more accessible to people who would use that data unscrupulously.

I hope that honourable senators in this chamber are with me. I am sure that Senator Harradine, and Senator Powell who has taken a particular interest in this area, and many colleagues on this side—Senator Vanstone and Senator Kemp, who were involved in the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee—will, with me, address this issue to ensure that we do not give away our freedoms bit by bit. If it is a bit onerous, and if it is a bit cumbersome, let it be that way, but do not let us always have technology driving what happens. Let us discuss as a community: do we have to accept the fact that it is technologically easier to do it? Should we be examining all these things?

I have said in this chamber before that I believe that one of the major issues of the 1990s will be the storage and retrieval of data, and the infringement of our privacy as that becomes easier and people say, `It's cheaper and it's more economical', and gradually we give away our freedoms bit by bit. One day we might regret that, when we cannot turn back the tide. Somebody will say, `You were in the chamber, you were in parliament in those days, why didn't you say something? Why didn't you stand up and make sure that our privacy was protected?'.
Page 10 of the report, under `Technical standards', states:

SPEECH.PARA: Under guideline 4 the Data-Matching Agency was required to produce a Technical Standards Report. This report outlines the standards to be adopted in relation to data quality, integrity and security. The guidelines required that all agencies complied with the report.
It says, gratuitously:

The effort put into production of the report was considered worthwhile because it serves to document the technical architecture of the Program. The discipline of producing the report was a useful vehicle for the identification and resolution of technical issues which would have had to be addressed anyway. It also meant that all agencies were involved in setting standards for the Program which were endorsed by the Privacy Commissioner.
It was an insistence by this Parliament that we have those standards, and I found that comment in that section of the report somewhat gratuitous. Page 12 of the report states:

The reporting requirements imposed by the legislation are stringent and a lot of time and effort is needed to comply with them. They have, however, generated useful management information for agencies as well as providing proof of compliance with the spirit as well as the letter of the law.

I would hope that all departments in data matching would comply with the spirit as well as the letter of the law. That is what we should expect of them. They should not just say, `We have to do this because this is what is set down in legislation'. They should be doing better than best in terms of protecting people's rights, and they should be addressing the spirit as well as the letter of the law. Listen to this:

It is the Department's view that if the Program is allowed to continue, greater reliance should be placed on the Privacy Commissioner's monitoring role and further reports to Parliament should be through the Annual Reports of agencies.

Sorry, I think no to that. I trust the Privacy Commissioner. I have been out to Tuggeranong and seen the Privacy Commissioner's officers working there, monitoring data matching and, yes, I think that is important. But a few pages in the annual report of the agency will not suffice to address the sorts of questions we are asking here. I do not think the Department would put the suggestion in an annual report of an agency that it really would like to have data matching on line rather than being taken physically backwards and forwards on tapes. That is not the sort of thing that comes out in an annual report.

PARA.TAB: I urge honourable senators, despite the fact that it is somewhat onerous, to ask that we continue to ask departments to produce this sort of information to enable us, as representatives of the people—especially those people who may be less likely and less able to protect their rights—to protect their rights through us and through this Parliament. I do not believe it is appropriate just to have this issue, which I see as major, appearing in annual reports.
The report goes on at page 13, in the conclusion of the chapter on privacy safeguards, as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: In the Data-matching Program great emphasis has been put on the protection of privacy and the security of personal information. Administering the Program within such a strict framework of privacy safeguards has not been without some cost. There has been some expenditure on equipment, printing and advertising, but the real cost has been in the time and effort of staff administering the Program.

However, considered against the standards and procedures the Department would have adopted in the absence of an externally prescribed modus operandi, any additional cost has been very much at the margin.
So they are saying that it is not all that much in terms of cost. It goes on:

It is considered that the costs have been more than offset by the benefits which have strengthened the safeguards already in place to keep personal information safe and secure, ensure that the program is conducted in a manner which avoids any unnecessary intrusion into privacy and enhances the Department's capacity to protect public expenditure.

Social Security, I believe, has tried to address this issue of privacy. The Committee procedure that went on here and the analysis of that Bill made that legislation tighter. The constraints on the departments involved in data matching were made tighter. I believe that this data matching is better for that process. As I said before, I think it is important that we see that information in this sort of form, not in the annual report.

PARA.TAB: This report confirms what the coalition has been saying for nearly two years. The financial estimates for the savings that would have been derived from data matching were never any more than guesstimates which, over time, have been proved to be totally inaccurate. When we sat in the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee, I was absolutely sure that the savings that the Department was saying that it would achieve would not be achieved because the basis of some of its figures was very rubbery.

Before I point out just how inaccurate these data matching estimates have been, it is important to point out that these estimates are Department of Finance estimates, and that is the same department whose work the Keating Government regularly quotes in its thoroughly unsuccessful attempts to blow financial holes in our Fightback plan. How accurate and how well informed are these financial gurus? If their data matching estimates are any indication, I can only conclude that they are atrociously inaccurate and not very well informed at all. So should we place any credence in their analysis of Fightback? Again, if these estimates are any indication, I would think we should place no credence in them at all.

Back in, I think it was, spring of 1990, when the data matching legislation was introduced by the Government, the Parliament was told that it would result in annual savings of approximately $300m. It was lauded as a centrepiece of the fraud identification techniques of the Department of Social Security. When we in the Senate proposed to change one mere word, what happened? Prime Minister Hawke wrote to the Leader of the Opposition claiming that $150m would be lost and that we would be held accountable for the loss. We were going to change one word in the Bill. Every time the coalition—and, I admit, Democrat senators as well—questioned the savings which would be derived through data matching, we were given assurance after assurance that the estimates were totally accurate.

Now the truth is out, and we see these reports. The Government's original estimate of the savings for the Department of Social Security during the 1991-92 financial year was $290m, but the actual savings were $23m. When the first data matching report was tabled in this place about a year ago, I again expressed my concern about the accuracy of the original estimates. After I had spoken—and I knew that that first report was not based on a full year, and I said that—I received a letter from the new Minister for Social Security, Dr Blewett, chiding me and claiming that it would be useful if `I corrected what appeared to be some misunderstanding about the matter'. He then told me in the letter that the annual savings estimates were based on the operation of a fully implemented program, and my comparison was invalid because the program was not yet fully operational. Then Dr Blewett stated in the letter:

SPEECH.PARA: As you know, action is proceeding to achieve these outcomes and the results so far suggest that when they occur actual savings will be those close to estimated.

We wait with bated breath, because they still have not reached the estimates. I am telling the Senate that Dr Blewett was wrong. The original estimate for the 1992-93 financial year was savings of $300m for the Department of Social Security. The revised estimated savings are now $146m, which is less than half the original claim.

PARA.TAB: I do not know when he thinks he will reach the estimates, but he cannot argue now that it has not been on a full data-matching year. The most outrageous estimate in the original savings figure, which was a savings from the data-matching retirees, has been revised downwards from $157m to $49m. Those estimates were wrong again. That information came from the Department of Finance which said it can analyse Fightback, get it all accurate, get it right, and it has been wrong on every occasion—about as wrong as the Health Insurance Commission was when it wanted to bring in the black box.

Later this year the sunset clause for data-matching legislation will come into effect. At that time the Parliament will have to decide whether it considers it appropriate and desirable to continue with this particular method of identifying welfare fraud. Undoubtedly, the Government will be up to its old tricks and will hold a loaded gun at the head of the Opposition saying, `You'd better agree to this because look at all the savings we will lose'.

Before going any further, I would like some clarification from the Minister on this. On the subject of savings, in the Estimates Committee I received an answer to a question and I asked Senator McMullan and my other colleagues if we could incorporate that in Hansard. I just happened to be sitting here looking at the answer I got in Estimates, which is the same table which appears on page 105 of the report, and there are some anomalies. For example, the actual savings in the Estimates answer for income security for the retired is $6.29m; yet in this table here on page 105 it is $5.2m. Under income security for the unemployed the figure is $8m. In the answer provided in Estimates it is $3.72m—only a difference of $5m but the attitude is that we need not worry about $5m here or there.

In this table it does not say that it excludes running costs; in the other table it says it excludes running costs. That might be the explanation, and if it I would appreciate the answer from the Minister. If it is not, I would

SPEECH.PARA: appreciate knowing which of these tables we ought to incorporate in Hansard as being the correct table of the actual savings of the data-matching program. However, I would seek leave to incorporate page 105 of the report in Hansard, which is the document we are talking about. I would appreciate it if the Minister would explain the difference between the answer I got in Estimates and the information contained in this table. It may be that one excludes running costs and the other does not. If not, I do not understand why there is a difference.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—Is leave granted to incorporate it?

TALK.START.PARA: —The usual procedure is that the Government be shown what is being sought to be incorporated, but I understand that this was cleared with my predecessor as duty Minister, Senator McMullan. If it was, then I have no objection to its being incorporated.
—I did actually say that, but I presume the Minister was not hanging on to my every word.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: [TABLE OMITTED FROM DATABASE - SEE HARD COPY PAGE 1969]

TALK.START.PARA: —That table shows exactly the change. The original estimate was $290m and the revised estimate is $146m—nearly half. The gun was held at our head. Honourable senators ought to be warned that whenever they are examining a proposal that is being put forward by the Government and estimates are being presented, they may be told, `If you don't do this, we will lose millions of dollars'.

PARA.TAB: There have been two perfect examples. One relates to the black box proposal and the Bill which was taken off yesterday—legislation which both Senator Tate and I thought was to come on—where the estimates of the savings were totally out because of two gross errors on the part of the Health Insurance Commission, I think it was. We were told, `You must have this because we will lose savings'. That was another intrusion and infringement of people's rights.

Anyone who went into a pharmacy with a prescription would have had the details of that prescription sent down on a computer line to the Health Insurance Commission for validation to make sure they were either entitled to a benefit—a lower benefit if they were health card holders or the higher benefit if they were Australian residents. So that they either got the $15 benefit, as it was then—now $15.90—or the health card holder benefit. One's rights were to be infringed and it worked out that in the first couple of years there would be a net loss.

In the case in point here the savings which the Government said would arise have not been achieved. I believe that every time we allow the privacy of individuals to be eroded, we need to examine the matter closely and ask whether the estimates are accurate. We need to ask those questions and to keep examining the issue. I call on honourable senators not to succumb to the Department's wishes and that they request that this sort of information be included in its annual report. I believe that it is very important. I, for one, every time a data-matching report comes in, will examine it very closely because it is absolutely important that the data-matching guidelines are adhered to and that we constantly evaluate whether the gains outweigh the privacy that is being invaded.

I appreciate the effort that the Department has put into preparing this report. However, I put the Department on notice that there are a couple of issues in that report with which I would argue. I hope honourable senators will support me on those two basic issues of requiring the Department to report to this chamber and ensuring that the information is transferred in a physical form, not in an on-line computer form between those two departments. It just makes it easier for the Department then to say, `We could do some other sort of data-matching' and gradually that process erodes our control over how that data is used.

TALK.START.PARA: —We recognise that data-matching is an important issue, but we have not had enough time to really look at it closely. We would like to adjourn consideration of this report until the next day of sitting. I understand that that is acceptable to the Government, but it would like to check a little further.

PARA.TAB: If I were to move the adjournment to the next day of sitting and that turned out to be unsatisfactory, then I understand that on the next day of sitting a further motion could be moved to redirect the business. I understand it is acceptable to the Opposition, so I formally move:
That the debate be adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I had exactly the same time as the Democrats—
—Senator Patterson, that is not open to debate. The motion is for the adjournment of debate.
—Are you opposing that?

—by leave—I had exactly the same length of time as did the Democrats to look at this. I might also say that this matter was not due to come into the Senate at all; it was not listed on the paper for today, and I understand the problem. How did I know about it? I was eating my breakfast or whatever listening to the ABC at the time when one is told what is going to be on today in the House of Representatives. I choked on my weeties again, as I often do, when I heard what he was saying on that program because I suddenly discovered what was to be on. I heard that this matter was to be tabled in the House of Representatives. So I came hurrying-scurrying in here to look at the red to see whether it was there and it was not there. Some negotiations then took place to organise for the matter to come on.

PARA.TAB: We did not have the time to look at this report. If the Democrats say that the matter should be postponed, I should be able to have another go at it if I choose to because I did not have the same time either. I will agree to it if I can have some more time on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think perhaps the matter could be adjourned by Senator Patterson to reserve her right to speak further.
—I seek leave to continue my remarks.

—I rise on a point of order. That might drop it to the bottom of the Notice Paper. I was keen that it not disappear and come up at some later time. I would like to see it adjourned until the next day of sitting so that it does get some priority. I agree with Senator Patterson that it is a very important report.
—Do we have the undertaking of the Minister that it will not go to the bottom of the Notice Paper?
—I think the normal process is that it would not happen that way. I expect it would not go to the bottom of the Notice Paper.
—I formally withdraw my motion.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: State and Northern Territory Local Government Grants Commission

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to say a few words about the annual report of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation. It is very refreshing to be able to look at something that is going the right way rather than the wrong way under this Government. It is great to see in the annual report that the wine industry has had a very good year. It set a goal for 1993 of annual export sales in excess of $200m and it has achieved that. It has increased its sales by a spectacular 35.9 per cent. That really is good news for our export wine industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you helped them build it up?

—I have helped a little bit, like most of us. I note that the industry is optimistically looking towards the year 2000, with its goal of exporting a billion dollars worth of wine. The recession has had an effect on the local consumption of wine, for obvious reasons. People cannot afford to buy wine due to the recession we had to have. Local sales have reduced by 3.3 per cent. The 550 wineries we have in Australia would quite obviously be looking to be exporting more. That is great for our balance of payments.

PARA.TAB: When I visited the UK Parliament in May, I spoke to representatives of the wine industry and found there has been a spectacular increase in our exports to the United Kingdom—something like 79 per cent. We exported something like $91.5m worth of wine to the UK. It is interesting to note that the English, who once used to laugh at the Australian wines, are now realising that they are the best value for money. From talking to some of the locals, I found that they are looking at our wines much more favourably than they are the French wines because they believe our wines have more flavour and are better value for money. It is also interesting to note that we are exporting a certain amount of wine to Germany—the home of the wine industry.

Julian Alcorso's father, Claudio Alcorso, virtually founded the wine industry in Tasmania. They are exporting their pinot noir to Germany. A fair amount of their production is being exported. Claudio Alcorso was very much instrumental in instigating, along with the Royal Agricultural Society of Tasmania—of which I am a former president—the Royal Hobart Wine Show. I am pleased to report that that wine show, which started in 1975 with very meagre beginnings, storing the wine under a galvanised iron skillion roof, has advanced to become one of the leading wine shows in Australia.

This year, for the first time ever, we have received in excess of 2,000 entries. Not only is the wine industry in Tasmania flourishing but so also is our wine show. As I said, it was commenced by the Royal Agricultural Society in cooperation with Claudio Alcorso, who promoted the local wines, and Len Evans and Max Lake. Max Lake is still the Chairman of the judging panel. That has ensured that our wine show is looked upon as being one of the foremost wine shows in Australia.
This is a very good report, a very optimistic report. It is good news amongst a lot of bad news that we read. I have much pleasure in moving that the Senate take note of this report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I have spoken before on the inappropriateness of efficiency audits by the Auditor-General in relation to the Department of Defence or any of its agencies because, quite simply, we are not dealing with a commercial venture which has a balance sheet and a profit and loss account. There is a degree of difference between the Department of Defence and its various agencies and any commercial activity. Nevertheless, I think it is important to read the Auditor-General's efficiency reports on defence agencies. I always read those with great interest.

PARA.TAB: This report is an efficiency audit into the Defence Science and Technology Organisation. The DSTO is the second largest scientific body in this country. It has about 3,400 employees and it is second only to CSIRO. It is a very important body. It has certainly been a very good investment, both for the nation and for the Department of Defence. This report notes that a year or two ago the Department of Finance had a look at the costs of savings introduced through research programs of DSTO when they were applied to the Department of Defence. In a certain period it showed that they covered 10 years' outlays in supporting the DSTO.

Whatever way we look at the DSTO, it has been very important. In a way, I do not think it is possible to overstate its importance. Australia is a country of vast geographic area—not to mention the surrounding sea over which we have a strategic interest—and our population is very low. We will never be able to defend this country adequately if we indulge ourselves in a defence philosophy that relies on human beings alone—or putting into the field armies of hundreds of thousands of troops on a continental scale.

We will have to use available scientific techniques in order to have a good surveillance program enabling us to know what is going on in the area of our responsibility; to be able to collect the intelligence that we need; and to be able to identify in time any threats—which hopefully will not emerge—in order to deal with them before they land on the mainland of Australia. Given the constraints of the size of the country over which we have to operate and the population, we must use technology to the limit.

Some of that technology we can get from overseas. If it is made available to us, and at a reasonable cost, we certainly should avail ourselves of it. But the geography of Australia does pose particular and specific requirements on its defence equipment. Therefore, we do need our own defence science and technology organisation to be able to improve equipment that comes in from overseas and adapt it to the very high humidity, the high temperature range, and even the dust, of the Australian environment in which it will have to operate. This is necessary because most defence equipment is designed for the European theatre. Most of it was designed for NATO, for operations in cooler and gentler climates than exist particularly in the northern part of Australia.

I have had a great interest in DSTO over the years. I also have had some concerns about it in recent years because a lot of change is occurring. The Government has shifted the DSTO's direction quite a bit. I accept that there was a need for change. I do not challenge that for one moment. I think DSTO was previously involved in areas of activity that are no longer a high priority. But it is also true that there has been a change in morale. Morale has been affected by the lack of a clear objective as to what the Government wants to do with DSTO.

The other area where I have concerns about DSTO is that of the priorities for its research activities. I do not wish to diminish the importance of divisions like the Aeronautical Research Laboratory or the Materials Research Laboratory, the propellants and explosives divisions and all the rest of it. They are all very important. But I have always argued in public that we have to put a great deal of effort into the electromagnetic spectrum. We must dominate and control the electromagnetic spectrum to the limits of our ability because that really is the vital ground in modern defence. It is the area that involves all of our communications and most of our sensors. We simply cannot put too much effort into knowing and dominating that area. One of the areas of great concern to me over the years has been the ratio of funds that we devote to it, particularly into areas like electronic countermeasures.

Having said all that, I would make the point that the purpose of DSTO really is to support the Australian Defence Force. While I would not want to rank priorities, I would certainly see Australia's defence as consisting of the Army, Navy and Air Force and DSTO; it is of that level of importance.

Turning now to the nature of the report before us, the Auditor-General's Report No. 2, I think it is important that the Auditor-General examines the DSTO, but in this report basically he is looking at its commercial activities. A couple of years ago the Government said that there were a lot of things that DSTO did that were saleable and that we should sell that intellectual property, those patents and those technologies which have an application in the private or commercial world. I do not have any argument with that at all. But what I do enter a plea for is balance. Reading the Auditor-General's report today, the feeling I had was that that balance is not necessarily reflected in their report.

This is a matter of commonsense. Sure, if we can sell something and the community can benefit from using it and the Commonwealth can benefit from it financially, by all means let us do it. But we certainly cannot design DSTO so that it puts a sizeable part of its resources into earning money from the commercial development of its products. The report of the Auditor-General talks about forming alliances and getting industry involved in the early stages of research programs so that the application of that research can be funnelled or directed more smoothly into commercial applications.

I come back to this matter of balance. The only reason we have DSTO is to do research that is not done by the commercial world; it is not done by the commercial world because the application of this particular research is specifically for the Department of Defence; and the primacy of the interests of the Department of Defence must be maintained. I noticed that one of the comments of the Department of Defence on this report makes that very point. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The concept of strategic alliances was being discussed within DSTO before the audit. Alliances along both technology and project groupings are being considered. However, their establishment is conditional upon Government requirements for probity and equity and Defence's right to unfettered access to DSTO-developed technology.

That is a very important point. Not only must the prime interests of the Department be protected, but also we certainly cannot have a situation where research is funded without the Department having complete access to that research to use it in whatever way it wishes.
