PARA.TAB: In conclusion, I just emphasise the importance of balance. By all means, let us recoup from the civilian world appropriate scientific and technological achievements that are made by DSTO. But let us always remember that we would not have DSTO if that work could be done commercially and that the commercial spin-offs are a secondary and, in a sense, fortuitous outcome. This organisation has been very important to Australia in the past and, given the way that technology will certainly go on developing, it will be very important to Australia and its security in the decades ahead.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the twenty-fifth report of the Standing Committee on Publications.

PARA.TAB: Report—by leave—adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a short statement on behalf of the Committee on Corporations and Securities outlining the Committee's program between now and the next election.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I felt it necessary to make these comments because of press reports based on some information about the Committee's plans for the period between now and the next election—reports which have led to more confusion than enlightenment, it seems to me.

PARA.TAB: On close corporations, the Committee is currently inquiring into a proposed new legal framework for the incorporation and regulation of small business. We are in the midst of a program of public hearings which will be completed in Perth next week. It is the Committee's intention to report to Parliament on this matter by the end of November 1992.

On audit committees, as part of its responsibility to monitor the general area of corporate law and regulation, the Committee has recently met with representatives of the auditing and valuing professions. Arising out of that meeting, the Committee will conduct a short investigation into the introduction of a requirement for audit committees on the boards of all publicly listed companies. The advantages of such committees are that they help to preserve the independence of auditors and ensure that supervision and knowledge of the audit function is vested in the full board of the company, not just the managers. The Committee will produce a report on this subject by the end of this session.

In regard to rewriting the corporations law, which has attracted a bit of attention in this morning's press, the Committee is also currently developing a proposal for a thorough redrafting of the corporations law. When introducing the Corporations Bill in 1989 the then Attorney-General, the Hon. Lionel Bowen, stated that the purpose of the Bill was:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . establishment of a national scheme for the regulation of companies. . . the Bill for the most part, re-enacts the existing legal requirements.

While some tidying up took place, it was essentially a consolidation of the law and reform was to come later. Since the passing of the corporations law there has been a steady flow of amending legislation. Five amending Acts of varying complexity have been passed and two major Bills, the draft Corporate Law Reform Bill and the proposal for continuous disclosure, are currently in preparation.

PARA.TAB: The Committee believes that this piecemeal process of reform will produce an increasingly cumbersome piece of legislation. This is something that we have become aware of as we have moved around the country speaking to business people and professionals who have to actually apply the law. For example, there are already 1,371 sections, including a section 1076ZC, and the Act has been in force for less than two years.

The advantages of a redraft are, firstly, that it would allow a thorough examination of the principles and concepts of corporate governance which underpin the law. For example, the relationship between ownership—that is, shareholders—and management has changed fundamentally, yet the law has not kept pace with those changes. The second advantage of a redraft is that practical experience gained in the working of the national scheme of corporate regulation could be built on to refine the law: for example, with regard to prospectuses and takeovers.

Thirdly, a review of the contents of the Act may enable some parts of it to be hived off into separate legislation. For example, would the insolvency provisions be better placed in an insolvency Act as they are in other parts of the world? Fourthly, advantage could be taken of developments in legislative drafting to produce a clearer and more accessible piece of legislation. For example, the Office of Parliamentary Counsel has been widely praised for its wholesale revision of the Social Security Act.

The Committee believes that this process should take place over a period of perhaps three years to ensure consultation with all interested parties, the States, the business community and the professions. The Committee will fully develop this proposal and table it in Parliament by the end of this session. I stress—and this is important—that the Committee is not planning to redraft the corporations law itself. Rather, it is suggesting the development of a proposal for a long, bipartisan, consultative process leading to a thorough redrafting of the law in due course.

I turn now to scrutiny of the ASC. As part of its continuing responsibility for scrutiny of the ASC and its associated agencies, the Committee will review their annual reports, hold hearings where necessary and report to the Parliament on any significant matters.

On institutional shareholders, the Committee is mindful that, with a general election imminent, it is unlikely that a new long term inquiry will be finished in this Parliament. However, the Committee will develop a reference on the emergence of major institutional shareholders, particularly superannuation funds, and their significance for corporate law and corporate regulation.

Issues which will be considered include whether the investor protection role of company law is relevant to these investors, the influence of institutional shareholders on the stock market and the influence of the large institutional shareholder on the governance of a company. The Committee will seek submissions on this reference early in 1993 and prepare the ground for its successor in the next Parliament to complete the inquiry.

Finally, in light of press reports drawing attention to calls by the Business Council of Australia and the Institute of Company Directors for an inquiry into criminal and civil law enforcement by the ASC, I refer honourable senators to the report of the Committee Relations between the ASC and the DPP which was tabled last Thursday in this place in which the Committee said at paragraph 1.6 that it would:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . not seek further hearings with the protagonists at this stage. [The Committee] believes that it is important that both organisations be given the opportunity to give effect to the Attorney-General's guidelines.
The Committee therefore rejects the calls of the business community as premature and believes that the guidelines established by the Attorney-General should be given a chance to work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—As a member of the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, I wish to make some remarks on the statement brought down by the Chairman of that Committee, Senator Beahan. Obviously, from the front page of the major newspapers in Australia this morning, there is a major focus by the business community and the legal fraternity on the matter of corporate governance in Australia. The matters referred to by the Chairman, Senator Beahan, in relation to the Business Council of Australia and other business groups for a major inquiry into the Australian Securities Commission and particularly its pursuit of white collar criminals are matters which have quite properly been responded to by the Chairman.

PARA.TAB: In fact, it is quite timely that we are able to bring down a statement today reflecting the Committee's views. The Committee met last night to consider its program for the next year. Of course, this Committee has quickly attained a high public profile in the Australian political debate. It is fair to say that the Committee has received general support from the business community and the legal fraternity for the very positive work it is doing 90 per cent of the time on a totally non-partisan basis. I can assure the Chairman, Senator Beahan, that the proposed consideration of the process of redrafting the corporations law will certainly receive wholehearted support from the Opposition.

It is also incumbent upon me to make some statements about the process of how this corporations law came into being. Back 18 months ago when the legislation was rushed through the House of Representatives in one hour and brought through the Senate in an almost ludicrous amount of time, the Opposition, and particularly the Opposition spokesman on corporate law, Peter Costello, made some statements which highlighted our concerns.

Indeed, Mr Costello issued a press statement at that time in which he said it was ludicrous to debate a 300-page piece of legislation in less than one hour in the House of Representatives and that there was a devotion of some 12 seconds per page. He said that no proper analysis or scrutiny of the legislation could take place. Of course, the Opposition predicted problems and problems have occurred. Mr Costello said in the last paragraph of that statement:

SPEECH.PARA: Enforcement of high standards of corporate management has been abysmal over the last five years. We hope that this scheme will work. It would work better if the legislation was adequately scrutinised so as to anticipate and prevent any problems from arising in the future. If it lurches from problem to problem that is the fault of the Government.

I think the Government, and the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) in particular, must bear some responsibility for the quite significant problems that the Australian Securities Commission and the new corporate law have had in the first year or so of life. That is not to distract from the positive work that this joint statutory Committee is doing and will continue to do on the reform of this law.

PARA.TAB: The redrafting process is one of the most positive undertakings of this Committee. There is no doubt that in every single public hearing held by our Committee the business community, legal fraternity, academic fraternity, the Chairman himself and all members of the Committee have come to the realisation that the corporations law has become a very complicated and complex piece of legislation which has added to the cost of doing business in Australia.

It has created an absolute bonanza for corporate lawyers who are paid highly to try to interpret the law. It is crucial for business in Australia, if it is to get on with business without having to work its way through a minefield of laws, regulations, interpretations and court decisions, that there is a simplification of the law. The law should be redrafted in a comprehensible fashion so that the business community can actually deal with corporate law in a sensible environment.

Indeed, at our hearings in Sydney into the close corporations Bill, one of the great factors raised by all of the people who gave evidence was that when the Edwards Committee was investigating such a Bill in 1985 many small business people thought there was not a need for a close corporations Bill. There is an overwhelming demand for a close corporations Bill, a corporate regulatory regime for smaller and medium sized businesses. The corporations law itself has become so complicated and so hard for small entities trying to get on with business. They want to incorporate but are scared off by the complexity of the corporate law. They need a totally separate regime so that they can get on and do business as an incorporated entity.

There is no doubt that there is a need for this and that it is long overdue. As I said earlier, I can assure Senator Beahan and the Parliament that the Opposition will support this process and the quicker we get a sensible corporations law, the better it will be for Australian business.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I rise to make a few comments on the statement that was made by the Chairman of the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities. I do so as a member of that Committee and on behalf of the Australian Democrats. On behalf of my Party, I wish to state our support for the program the Chairman has outlined. As previous speakers have stated, the Committee is currently coping with a substantial workload, but has shown in its operation that it can contribute substantially to the debate that is currently being carried out in this country about corporate matters.

PARA.TAB: In particular, I lend support to the project that the Chairman has foreshadowed, which is a complete review and redraft of corporations legislation. It is quite clear, as evidence to the Committee from a host of witnesses indicates, that the corporations law has grown to such an extent, indeed to hundreds and almost thousands of pages, that it is becoming difficult for anyone but the most specialised practitioner to cope with it. There have been numerous instances where even experienced practitioners have had difficulty not only in dealing with a problem but in finding the place in the legislation where a particular issue was being dealt with. The Australian Democrats welcome this program. I think it will be extremely useful and beneficial for the development of corporations law in Australia.

I wish to address also some brief remarks to one particular aspect which is included in this review and which has had some public profile in recent weeks, and I refer to the prosecution of white collar crime. While the dispute—one could call it a demarcation dispute to some extent—between the Australian Securities Commission and the Director of Public Prosecutions has to some extent at least been put to rest by the Attorney-General's statement setting down guidelines and directions for both bodies, I find that one aspect was missing, namely, the provision of additional resources to both of these bodies to catch up with the backlog of prosecutions for white collar crime.

I am somewhat disturbed by calls that have been made by the Opposition which indicate that it feels the Australian Securities Commission should not be concerned with the investigation of white collar crime prior to prosecution at all but should simply be a regulatory body. I would suggest that would mean we would probably have a void in this particular area because there has been an announcement from the NCA and its current Chairman that it is to reduce the priority which was given by the previous Chairman, Mr Justice Phillips, to white collar crime and that the Authority would return to its earlier focus of Mr Justice Phillips's predecessor, Mr Justice Stewart, to drugs and related offences.

If the NCA is turning its back on white collar crime, if the ASC is to be a purely regulatory body, the question must be asked: who is to investigate those people, commonly called the corporate cowboys, who have brought our corporate world into disrepute? I believe the situation put before the Committee by the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy), and indeed by a range of witnesses, that the ASC should continue its investigatory responsibilities and should then, through agreed guidelines, provide the DPP with sufficient material to prosecute our corporate criminals, is the correct way to go. I also believe, as witnesses have said, that it is clear that corporate criminals fear nothing more than a prison sentence. It is quite ludicrous to suggest that they will be deterred from their crimes by a monetary fine which they would simply view as a business expense.

In closing my remarks, I would again suggest that the Government, the Attorney-General more specifically, should give some consideration to providing additional resources to the ASC and to the DPP to bring to a conclusion the prosecutions that are currently under way and to carry out its investigations with increased intensity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I wish to speak to the statement made by the Chairman of the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities, which is a very important Committee. The Committee, of which Senator Beahan is Chairman, is a very well staffed and very well comprised committee. It deals with the company structure, which is a structure through which very much of our economic life is conducted in this country and indeed in many other countries.

PARA.TAB: It is important to get the right balance between proper regulation and giving corporations enough rein to perform their function, which is to produce the wealth to deliver those services and goods that we need for the good of this country. I think everybody understands that there has to be regulation, but latitude has to be allowed to corporations to enable the good that does come to the country through the corporate structure to come in as big a measure as possible.

It may be worth while to understand how corporations came about. The original idea was that people wanted to produce goods and services but, nevertheless, have their liability in doing that limited.It is only right and proper that people who enter into a venture go about it honestly and with competence. But, nevertheless, if because of misfortune they do not make a success of it, they should not be ruined. All they should be responsible for is the amount of capital that they have contributed to the venture.

What happened then was that a whole mass of people who wanted to devote money to a venture were able to do so through this corporate structure. Madam Acting Deputy President, Senator O'Chee, as a member of your Party and someone who is well versed in the area of corporate law, would be able to tell you about the growth of the public company.

TALK.START.PARA: —And some international law as well.

—And some international law as well. He is very good on the sledge. These people were able to come together through the corporate structure and devote their money to a venture. That venture, if successful, would return them a dividend on their money. Their purchase of that part property in the company was called a share; therefore, they became shareholders. What has become of concern to people, particularly in modern times, is that those shareholders be looked after.

PARA.TAB: What has developed is the separation of the ownership of a company from its control. In the early days of companies, people who owned the company also controlled it and probably carried out the work in it. More and more, the people who own the shares that represent the property in the company have become separate from the company itself with less and less ability, particularly if they are small shareholders, to have any control over how the company is conducted. It is right and proper in those circumstances that the law should come in and protect those shareholders, particularly in public companies. Therefore, we as a legislature have a responsibility to see that they are protected.

At the same time, the protection can become such that the people who have the duty to carry out the proper running of the company are so constrained that they cannot produce the wealth that we need through the companies. This Committee is intent on so arranging the law that there is the ability on the part of the managers, the directors and the managing directors to run the company profitably while at the same time giving the owners—the shareholders—reasonable protection.

The Chairperson of the Committee, Senator Beahan, mentioned the concept of closed corporations, which is a matter that this Committee is properly devoting itself to. Small business people want to take advantage of not only the limited liability that companies give but also the tax advantages that come with being the employee of a company. The idea behind closed corporations is that it gives a person who is running a small business—it is often said in this chamber that small business forms very much the basis of our economy—the ability to so arrange things that he or she in effect becomes an employee, and properly so, of the company. There is nothing illegal or immoral about that. Indeed, it is very much to the advantage of the people who are producing our wealth.

There is presently an inquiry into closed corporations. Senator McKiernan will be pleased to know that that inquiry will be going to Perth next week. No doubt we will hear him make a submission there on behalf of the small business people of his State.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately not. I'll be in Sydney looking after family law.
—Why, don't you care about small business?

—I will put that on the record. As Senator Boswell said, `Why is more care not shown about small business?'. I am sure that he did not include Senator McKiernan in that remark because Senator McKiernan is known for his regard for small business.

PARA.TAB: I do not know whether the Committee will go to Queensland, but we would be very pleased to hear Senator Boswell's thoughts about closed corporations, because he is a man—and I say this in all sincerity—who has shown considerable concern for small business. I am anxious to hear what he has to say about the closed corporations structure, which is intended to help the sort of people who Senator Boswell is concerned to protect.

Audit committees are mentioned in this context. It is important to develop that idea and to legislate for it in terms that would promote this concept: companies should have within their structures a committee devoted to auditing the functions that it performs. For example, there would be a finance audit, a production audit and so on. As Senator Beahan has said, the Committee is anxious to have that matter investigated.

It has been said that the Committee is on about rewriting the corporations law. I hope that this Committee does not convey the impression that it is rewriting the whole of the law in this area. The present Attorney-General, the Hon. Michael Duffy, has done a lot of very good work in this area. Amongst the very many contributions that he has made to this nation, he has given it a very good piece of legislation in this area.

Of course it needs to be amended, but certainly it should not be seen as the necessary task of this chamber and this Committee to rewrite corporations law because, simply, it is not a necessity at this time. In my view, substantially, the legislation will serve this community well for many years to come. That does not mean to say that there are not areas—such as loans to directors—that cannot be further looked at. Hopefully, some legislation will come down in that area soon. I make it clear that my view is that the legislation we presently have is, in substance, the sort of legislation that we ought to go forward with and that we should have not a rewriting of it but an amending of it—in the sense that any legislation needs to be amended—as the need arises.

Much is made of the issue of plain English. True enough, if plain English leads to an understanding on the part of everybody of what a piece of legislation is all about, let us look at that. But it is too simple to say that a piece of legislation, which has been written in terms of the law as we know it and the common law and precedents set in this area over many decades, should simply be rewritten without any regard to what has gone before.

What is needed in time is a look at how this legislation is working. If there is a need to amend it after discussion with the corporate sector, the shareholders and the Attorney-General's Department, it should take place, but not otherwise.

The other point I should talk about concerns the relationship between the Australian Securities Commission and the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions. The Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission, Mr Hartnell, is an eminent person in this field. The Director of Public Prosecutions, Mr Michael Rozenes, QC, is also eminent.

I do not think the relationship between the Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission and the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions should be seen as some sort of conflict between them in fundamental terms. Perhaps there have been some skirmishes on the periphery but fundamentally the relationship is good. It is not a question of whether one or the other should be prosecuting people; it is a question of whether or not the system, which includes both, can give us the sort of corporate sector we want so as to satisfy all needs. That is the real question. We sometimes get ourselves into all sorts of difficulties chasing down a particular path and discussing whether or not A or B should be doing a particular function, whereas the real issue is whether a particular result is being produced by the overall scheme that is in operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Lionel Bowen had it right, didn't he?

—Lionel Bowen was an eminent Attorney-General who has been followed by another eminent Attorney-General. All I can say about the present Attorney-General is that there might have been some as good as he is, but certainly there were none better.
—That's why the Corporations Act needs to be withdrawn.

—When Senator Hill says that the Corporations Act needs to be withdrawn, I noticed that he said it with a smile on his face. He has sat on many committees that have recommended change and he has brought his considerable legal mind to those issues. Indeed, we only have to go through the records of the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee of this House to see the number of times that Senator Hill's mind has got into a concept and that concept has been translated into legislation. Many pieces of legislation could be called the Hill amendment, and quite properly so.
—He's actually blushing.
—It is absolutely true.
—The only one they talk about in those terms was this damn electoral system amendment.
—Senator Hill did some work on it. I think it might have been his suggestion that we looked at the corporate sector; I am sure it was.
—It may well have been.
—Indeed, it was. It has led to this sort of thing.
—You're not going to blame me for the whole mess now, are you?

—It is not a mess. I know that Senator Hill says that as part of his function as the Leader of the Opposition. He has to say it and we take it in that vein but we fully appreciate that he has great admiration for the legislation that has been produced in this area. I noticed a headline in the Australian Financial Review this morning which I think rather overstated that decision.
—A bit irresponsible.

—I do not know whether it was irresponsible but it certainly overstated the position. By and large, as a parliament we are content to rest with the present corporate legislation with the appropriate amendments made at the appropriate time to achieve the appropriate result. It is an organic

SPEECH.PARA: concept. Society is an organic concept. As the corporate sector develops, laws have to be made.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to interrupt business to table a memorandum of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service which relates to matters arising out of yesterday's Question Time, and to make a few comments in relation to that document.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the contingent notice in my name, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill tabling a document and moving a motion to take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Deputy President, I seek to suspend Standing Orders because this matter is clearly urgent. The Government is apparently determined that this document not be put on the public file in this place. The document is in fact, astonishingly, another correction by AQIS of matters that have been of embarrassment to the Government.

PARA.TAB: I spoke on the adjournment last night about the fact that AQIS had to correct an earlier document that referred to prime ministerial discussions in relation to the importation of live pigs. That was clearly stated in a document of AQIS. It was denied by the Government and AQIS subsequently corrected it by saying that it was totally wrong. Mr Landos, a very senior officer in AQIS, said that although he inserted those specific words, he was in error in doing so and he could not explain why he did so. I said on the adjournment last night that I found that quite astonishing.

At Question Time yesterday we questioned Senator Button about what was apparently a misleading of the Senate in relation to the importation of genetic material from Denmark relating to pigs. Another memorandum said in fact that there had been ministerial discussions in relation to the importation of that genetic material. We asked Senator Button why he was continually denying that that was the case when, on an AQIS document, it was clearly stated to have been the case—that is, that there had been ministerial discussions in relation to that issue.

Senator Button hinted yesterday that perhaps AQIS had got it wrong again. It is fascinating that today, after we had pressed Senator Button on that issue yesterday, there comes to light yet another correcting document of AQIS, this time signed by Mr Gascoine, the Acting Executive Director of AQIS. Seeing that the Government does not want it tabled, I will read it. The document, which is dated 15 October 1992, is to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: John Landos, Director of Quarantine Division, provided a briefing note to you and Minister Griffiths on 23 June 1992 under the heading "Importation of Pigmeat and Pig Genetic Material from Denmark".

The note includes a statement to the effect that the Danish Minister for Agriculture (Mr Tournaes), at his discussions with you in April 1992, raised the matter of access to Australia for uncooked Danish pigmeat and pig semen.

This statement was not correct. The recall note on your meeting with the Danish Minister, prepared by an officer of the Corporate Policy Division of the Department, makes no reference to importation of pig genetic material. No AQIS officer attended the meeting with the Danish Minister.
AQIS regrets that this error was made in its advice to you.

This is absolutely astonishing, Mr Deputy President. This is not the type of issue where there can simply be a slip. It is specifically stated in this AQIS document that the matter was raised by the Danish Minister. It was discussed at ministerial level. How could the officer have put that in this memorandum if it was not correct or if he had not been told that that in fact was the state of affairs?

PARA.TAB: We have not got any explanation for that. We did not get any explanation for it in relation to the correction—the so-called correction—concerning the prime ministerial involvement. We now have no explanation in relation to the correction in relation to the ministerial involvement on the question of importation of semen.

There are further AQIS documents yet to come which are equally damaging, I would suggest, to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in this matter. I wonder whether in fact there will be further documentation from AQIS saying that it had got it wrong yet again. I refer to a memorandum dated 9 April 1992—and I will quote just a few lines. The memorandum says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . delaying imports of more suitable Danish genotypes until the quarantine control infrastructure is in place and the political climate is more favourable.

What is this political climate that has to be more favourable before this issue of importation of genetic material can be progressed? The Government has to give us an explanation as to that rather than seeking to avoid to face up to these issues.

PARA.TAB: I might say that before the suspension of the sitting for tea we had the experience of Senator Cooney having to come in here and filibuster because the Government did not want this document read out before tea time in the hope that it would be too late for the deadlines of the news media.
There is also the cablegram of AQIS dated 7 July, which is equally damaging. And that is going to require some attention as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.
—Do you want an extension?
—I would like just a moment. Obviously, I have been rushing.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, that was a pretty uninspiring performance. Our position is that if Senator Hill thinks this is a great issue about which he would like to make a long speech, we are relaxed about his motion. If he wants more time to speak now, we will give him leave to do so. If he wants his motion carried so that he can get up and expand for half an hour about this important issue in respect of which he thinks he has something to say of significance, we are prepared to vote for his motion and debate it. I suspect the easiest thing is to let the motion pass and get on with the debate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, could I make a procedural point. Obviously Senator Hill now has the call to speak. I do not want us to be in the position where everyone who wants to comment will have to seek leave to do so. This would be a bit of a farcical situation. I simply suggest that Senator Hill might move some sort of motion. We can then debate that motion and people will not have to seek leave in order to speak. The form of the motion can be as procedural as Senator Hill likes. I am only saying that for the simplicity of the debate. If he does not move a motion, we will all just have to seek leave in order to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Government is now being a little more cooperative, I seek leave to have that document incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service
Department of Primary Industries and Energy
MINUTE
Reference: (file ref)
Subject:CORRECTION OF BRIEFING NOTE
15 October 1992
Minister for Primary Industries and Energy
CCMinister for Resources
John Landos, Director of quarantine Division, provided a briefing note to you and Minister Griffiths on 23 June 1992 under the heading "Importation of Pigmeat and Pig Genetic Material from Denmark".

The note includes a statement to the effect that the Danish Minister for Agriculture (Mr Tournaes), at his discussions with you in April 1992, raised the matter of access to Australia for uncooked Danish pigmeat and pig semen.

This statement was not correct. The recall note on your meeting with the Danish Minister, prepared by an officer of the Corporate Policy Division of the Department, makes no reference to importation of pig genetic material. No AQIS officer attended the meeting with the Danish Minister.
AQIS regrets that this error was made in its advice to you.
D F GASCOINE
A/g Executive Director
AQIS

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I respect the fact that the Australian Democrats wish to deal with their general business and that they would like this matter to be as brief as possible. What I principally want to do is put this on the record. Senator Button should have done so himself during Question Time today. He should have come in and corrected the record yesterday because, on the face of information before the Senate as until now, Senator Button had misled the Senate. His way out tonight is apparently going to be this letter from Mr Gascoine which says AQIS got it wrong yet again.
—How many times is that?

—It is happening regularly, Senator Crane. What is interesting is that it is happening on such fundamental questions, and it is not happening in a way in which it could simply be a slip. We have never had an explanation from Mr Landos as to why he got it wrong and inserted in the previous memorandum the fact that there had been prime ministerial discussions on the issue of the importation of pigs. We have not today got an explanation from AQIS how it could have got it so wrong in this later memorandum which related to ministerial discussions on the question of the importation of genetic material.

—Senator Hill, it might be better if you table the document. You have sought to incorporate it in Hansard, but we are virtually discussing a document that we do not have before us. If you seek leave to table it we will have it before us.
—I seek leave to table the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said, matters arise from this that now require answers. How is it that it came to light today? How is it that this memorandum is a memorandum to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, whereas the principal memorandum was to the Minister for Resources? Why is it that Mr Landos himself is not the author of this correcting memorandum? Does Mr Landos agree that he was in error in this instance? We do not know the answer to that. It looks as if someone has gone over the top of Mr Landos now in relation to this matter. How can we be sure that that discussion did not take place simply because it is apparently not included within the notes of record of the conversation? Surely it cannot be said that that is evidence that it was not included? Although Senator Cook, in the Estimates Committee hearing, read part of that note into the record, it was never tabled in its whole form.
—It contained confidential information.
—It contained confidential information, did it?
—Between Ministers.

—Between Ministers is the whole point in relation to this. The Minister chose to selectively read part of that memorandum into the record in the Estimates Committee hearing because he thought it helped him in relation to this question of whether there was Prime Ministerial discussion on the importation of pigs. By reading part of it in he was unhelpful to his Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in that he read another part in that totally contradicted what the Prime Minister had said to the Australian people through the Age newspaper. That concerned whether or not the joint venture had been raised at ministerial level—or joint ventures but, as I understand it, there is only one joint venture, but that can be developed in this—
—What is the basis of that understanding?

—Anyone who knows anything about the history of this matter would know that to be so. What the Prime Minister said when he applied the heavy to the Age was that there was no discussion on the joint venture at ministerial level, when we know from what Senator Cook had read into the public record that that was not correct. In an effort to get his Prime Minister off the hook on this other matter he selectively read parts of it to show that there had not been other discussions, and we do not know what else is contained in that memorandum because he selectively now tells us that that is confidential and we are not going to see that.

PARA.TAB: I said last night that there are many pieces of this jigsaw missing but that we will continue to pursue it until we find where the truth lies. We have another part—a mysterious part—of that jigsaw today as a result of the memorandum of Mr Gascoine. No doubt, more information will be able to be elicited next week when the third member of the drafting committee—and I remind the Senate that it took a drafting committee of three to come up with this memorandum—will be called before the Estimates Committee to explain his part in it.
Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order on my right!

—I do not want to delay the Senate, but it is particularly interesting that the contact officer for the key memorandum that we are talking about actually was Mr Thompson, so his information in relation to the principal memorandum will be of interest—that is the one that is now being refuted by Mr Gascoine—and no doubt he will be able to give evidence on that matter. I also understand that Mr Landos will be called next week which will give him the opportunity to explain whether, in fact, he got it wrong again in relation to the second memorandum, and to put forward an explanation as to how that occurred.

PARA.TAB: If this is correct today, then I guess Senator Button will say that that gets him off the hook, and he will say that he did not mislead the Senate because the Quarantine Service got it wrong yet again. It certainly does not get the Prime Minister off the hook. He clearly misled the Australian people in relation to ministerial talks on the joint venture. We know that from what Senator Cook put into the record during the Estimates Committee.

We will get to the bottom of this matter in the end. We know that the Prime Minister, through this joint venture—what is commonly referred to now as the multi-million dollar pig joint venture—had an interest in the importation of live pigs and had an interest in the importation of semen, because that would be of advantage to this joint venture.
Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order on my right!

—The question is whether he used his position and his influence to advance that venture, and we will get to the bottom of that. It is like extracting teeth. It reminds me of the Marshall Islands affair. Was it not fascinating tonight, when the Government was trying to avoid this document being tabled in the Senate before dinner; who came into the Senate to run the procedure? Senator Richardson, whom we have not seen since the last event. He came in to manage the tactical decisions before dinner time tonight.

PARA.TAB: We will get to the bottom of this matter. We will get to the truth. It is like pulling teeth. We have only got this by a whole series of questions to Senator Button. If we had not asked those questions, if we had not pressed Senator Button yesterday, we would not have this document today, the Senate would not have this knowledge and we would have been left in the dark again. I appreciate the Government's cooperation tonight in finally allowing this to be tabled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —In politics there are high points and there are low points. Tonight we are watching one of the low points. We are watching a sleazy, slimy effort by the Opposition which is engaged in mud-slinging. The basic theory on which it is embarking on this excursion is that if you throw as much mud as you can possibly lay your hands on, you hope that some of it will stick. The trouble with this theory, in the execution of it in this particular case, is that none of it has stuck, and the very reason why none of it has stuck is that none of it is true. If the Senate was of a mind to deal with members of the Opposition by way of censure because they make inaccurate, misleading and untruthful assertions against Government Ministers or against the Prime Minister, there would be very few of those on the other side who would escape the censure of this chamber.

PARA.TAB: Be that as it may, let us just go to a couple of features of this. This started with a very bumbling, foolish, blustering effort by Senator Boswell. It was followed up by the real smart alec, `I know everything', schoolboy debater, Senator O'Chee. Now we have had a preening, posturing exhibition from the Leader of the Opposition—
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. If Senator Tierney is going to involve himself in smear and sleaze, ask him to interject from his own seat.
—While interjections are disorderly to start with, interjections out of one's place are extremely disorderly.

—Now we have one of those pompous, preening exhibitions from Senator Hill, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, which would have done Uriah Heep credit in the sleazy way it was presented. Many of the questions that have been raised in this excursion into sleaze tonight were answered in debate in this chamber by Senator Button in Question Time earlier this week. It is useful to remember what Senator Button said. Senator Button pointed out that there had been four different naked attempts at making allegations here, each of which has stunningly failed.

PARA.TAB: The first was that the Prime Minister in some way interfered with the foreign investment guidelines in order that this `project', so-called by the Opposition, could get through. Of course, as Senator Button pointed out to the Senate, there was approval before the alteration of the guidelines. The second charge was that the Prime Minister was trying to import live pigs or genetic material. That has been proved to be false by everybody who has had anything to do with this, as anyone will know who bothered to tune in to, or to attend, Estimates Committee F the other month, and the maintenance of that claim in the face of the evidence is basically malicious.

The third is an allegation by Senator Baume. One only needs to say that Senator Baume has made the allegation to know that that, ergo, is almost discredited. But this is an allegation that was scotched again by Senator Button. It was an allegation in which Senator Baume tried to obfuscate and confuse viewers or listeners to this place about company records on the pretence that he could score a point against the Prime Minister's company.

The fourth effort, of course, was the one that crowned it all, the king hit. I refer to the one in which Senator Boswell tabled one page of a document which contained several pages, but omitted to table the other pages until Senator Button nailed him. We can easily recall the familiar scene of Senator Boswell waddling up here and belatedly trying to correct the record by trying to get the pages that he had forgotten to table, had omitted to table, or had deliberately chosen not to table into the record, to pretend that somehow he wanted the record to be pure and clear.

I remind the Senate that when people tell the truth, it should be the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth. The tabling of one page of a multi-page document simply because that page suited the argument, but leaving the other pages out simply because they do not, is not the whole truth and it is not nothing but the truth. It is a way of trying to distort and configure the debate to make a political point unrelated to the facts or circumstances in this particular case.

It is surprising to me that Senator Hill should want to bring this matter on tonight. Everyone in this Senate knows that Estimates Committee F is going to meet again next Wednesday. There will be a further one hour of questioning before that Committee in terms of the last person involved in the three-person squad that dealt with the preparation of the letter that is, so-called, `under question'. That person will be questioned.

Let me go back to that. Tonight we have Senator Hill maintaining the truth of the fallacious—and if uttered outside of this chamber, libellous—allegation that somehow or other AQIS officers may have been interfered with by named or unnamed or inferred powers in the execution of their duty. What we ought to recall—

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you got it?

—And I saw Senator Hill sitting in the back of Estimates Committee F, so he knows these things to be a fact. What we saw was evidence from an AQIS officer that scotched those allegations utterly and completely. I refer the Senate to the Hansard of the procedings of that Committee. I recall that because we went on quite late that night; we sat through one of those nerve-grinding, long night sittings—as if effort and length of time would make any difference to the quality of the outcome. What we saw was the same question—

PARA.TAB: Senator Crane interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Crane will cease interjecting.

—What we saw was the same question being asked by the boy wonder from the National Party, who was not a member of the Committee, and the same question being asked by some of the other coalition members of that Committee, but in a different form all the time, and getting the same answer. That same answer was that there was no interference at all from the outside with AQIS and that the officer had made a mistake.

PARA.TAB: I must say that I give full marks to John Landos, the relevant officer of AQIS. He came forward in a public forum, under the scrutiny of the Estimates Committee, looked Opposition senators in the eye and said, `Look, I am not perfect; I made a blue and there was no basis for that comment that appeared in that letter'. He went on and said, `As soon as I realised that it was there, and as soon as my colleagues realised it was there, we put out a refutation immediately and corrected the record'. What can Opposition senators do? They asked, they probed, they cross-examined and they questioned, but here they are trying to deal with an honest man giving an honest answer who said he made a mistake.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you explain it?

—He said he could not explain it because there were three different officers involved. Senator Hill should read the transcript. He should not interject on me, asking me questions, when all the answers are contained in the Hansard record of that inquiry. The difference is that Senator Hill does not like the answer; the difference is that he does not want that answer; and the difference is that that answer does not suit his political purpose. The truth is that that answer is accurate and the officer said he made a mistake. He regrets making a mistake and he wished he had not made a mistake, but he is, after all, a human being.

PARA.TAB: It may well be that members of the coalition opposite have never made a mistake in their lives. It may well be that they are all perfect. But I can tell them that the rest of us do make mistakes. From time to time mistakes do occur and when they do we stand up, confess them and correct them quickly, which is what this officer did. On the basis of what has been presented by him, under several hours of scrutiny, there is one inescapable conclusion: he is entitled to be believed, and so he should be. Let us just set that record right. Now what do we get? We get an allegation that Ministers discussed Danpork Corporation or this so-called joint venture in New South Wales, which one is supposed to assume is some evidence of interference in the proper decision-making process.

TALK.START.PARA: —No!

—That is the implication that those opposite have invited us to draw. The implication they have sought to propagate abroad as being the only implication is that something wrong has happened here. Nothing wrong has happened here. What we have is a meeting between two Ministers from two different countries over matters of trade.

PARA.TAB: I read into the record—and I ask Senator Hill to listen to this explanation, because I tell him directly that he has it wrong and does not understand it—that two Ministers from their respective countries had discussions about matters of trade. That was not the only matter discussed; there were a range of matters. It is glad news for Australia and Denmark that we deal with one another across a broad range of fronts, not just on the pig issue, and that the Danes raise questions about these discussions as referred. I read all the references in the recall note prepared by the officers present to remind the Minister about those discussions. I read that all into the record. Now I am chastised: why did I not table the note? What else have I got to hide?

I answered that question on the night of the inquiry of Estimates Committee F. The answer I gave that night is the same answer that I give now and the same answer that I will give eternally. There were a range of trade matters discussed. Matters of commercial in confidence and matters touching on commercial dealings between businesses in both countries ought not be broadcast abroad in the quasi public forum of a Senate committee hearing and ought not be noted for publication and quotation in the Hansard.

People who confide in Government Ministers about their commercial interests in the hope that Ministers, acting on behalf of the nation, can advance the matter are entitled to privacy. I did not table the note because it contained some references that ought not be available publicly. If Opposition members think matters of commercial-in-confidence should be revealed publicly, let them say it. Let them tell the business community of Australia, `Never tell a government anything because if you do tell things to government that are confidential and touch your commercial rights, you will have them bruited abroad'. If Opposition members believe commercial-in-confidence matters ought to be publicised, they should say so. But if they do not believe that, they should drop off and accept the explanation that is made. They should accept the explanation that all of the relevant sections of that recall note that dealt with this issue are on the public record.

What has happened now? Someone has got hold of an AQIS note in which there is reference to pig semen. Those opposite run around waving this note on high like some new scalp on an Indian hunting party. `Look what we've got', they say. We have had a range of questions tonight from Senator Hill: `What does all this mean?'; `Is this the end of the world?'; `Does this portend doom?'; `What is the significance of this?'. The first thing that ought to be said—and Senator Hill well knows this—is that no AQIS officer was present at the meeting between Danish Minister Tornaes and Minister Crean. They were not present. In the notes and material prepared by people who were present, who were privy and who do know, there is no reference to semen or genetic material.

The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, like all big organisations, sometimes makes mistakes. Digby Gascoine, the Acting Executive Director of AQIS, says that this was one of them. This is the most responsible officer in AQIS. The allegation is that what AQIS says is right and what those who were present say happened is wrong. That is the allegation the Opposition is making. AQIS has put out, through its most senior official, a denial that the AQIS reference is factually correct.

We are criticised here because a more junior officer than the most senior officer in AQIS did not put out the note. `Why did Mr Landos not put out the note?', asks Senator Hill. Responsibility for the running of an organisation is always taken by the most senior officer. Because this matter was raised in this chamber, and it is a serious matter, why would one ask a more junior officer to reply?

Of course, it is proper and responsible for the most senior official available in AQIS to say, on behalf of the organisation, what the case is, and he has said so. He has said so clearly, openly and irrefutably. But that answer which he has written and published is not acceptable to the Opposition. It is not the answer it wants. It does not suit the sleaze that is being engaged in here, it does not suit the slimy manoeuvre that is being engaged in here and it does not suit the effort to blackguard and sling mud that is being engaged in here. Therefore, the credibility and the personality of this officer must be attacked and destroyed.

I remind senators in this place that we enjoy a privilege. We can say anything we want in here and we are protected. When there is an attack upon the credibility and efficacy—indeed, the reliability—of a senior public servant who is prepared to put his name to a document, people can get up in here and attack him and say that he must have done this or that. That public servant has no right of equal protection and defence—none. One of the reasons why people out there in the community hold politicians in low esteem is that they sometimes call places like this, given the use it is now being put to, `cowards castles'. Politicians can sling mud and ordinary citizens cannot enjoy the same privilege to protect themselves.

I happen to know Digby Gascoine because for a time I was the Minister responsible for AQIS. I happen to know he is a well conducted officer, a serious officer and an officer who is a pride to that service. I would have to say on his behalf and on behalf of the Government that to call his standing and his honesty into question is a reflection not on him but on those who happen to raise that type of allegation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who has called Gascoine's honesty into question?

—Senator Hill has asked a number of questions: `What happened? Why did he do it? What are the reasons behind it?' Mr Gascoine has made available, under his own signature on his official letterhead as the most senior officer, his position and he is entitled again to be believed. He is not entitled to be put in a position where the inference that others watching this are invited to draw—namely, that he has acted in some way improperly.
—We have not suggested Gascoine has acted improperly.
—So you are withdrawing any insinuation against him?
—I did not make any insinuation.

—If any insinuation against him is to be withdrawn, then his word is accepted and this document that Senator Hill has incorporated and tabled is accepted—end of case. That is the end of the argument because the whole argument Senator Hill is now putting swings on whether or not the AQIS minute of 23 June is true. He said it is not; Senator Hill accepts his word: end of case. Let us conclude this debate now and get back to work. If there are any other matters to be dealt with on this issue, deal with them before Estimates Committee F on Wednesday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —That was an astonishing speech by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook). The first part of the speech plunged the knife right in between Mr Keating's shoulder blades. Mr Keating says—and I will read this for the edification of the Senate—`The joint venture has not been the subject of any ministerial talks'. The Minister spent the first 10 minutes of his speech telling us about the ministerial meeting that Mr Keating said did not happen. Senator Cook just spent 10 minutes saying it did happen. Is Senator Cook misleading the Parliament, or is Mr Keating misleading the people? That is the crux of this argument. Someone is not telling the truth. Something does not smell right in the state of Denmark. Everything that has arisen has had to have a question raised about it.

PARA.TAB: The first letter we got was from AQIS, which clearly stated that there were ministerial and prime ministerial discussions. The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Danes first raised the possibility for access for live pigs in the mid-1980s. This request was not formally followed-up until 1990 when it re-emerged as an issue at Prime Ministerial level . . .
There was the first mistake. That letter was followed by another letter on 21 July that said that was a mistake; there was a retraction from the original letter.

PARA.TAB: We then questioned the officers who wrote that letter. We asked, `How could you make a mistake like that? How could you think that there were prime ministerial discussions if there were not?' In fact, Senator O'Chee said to the officer, `Do you often have visions of grandeur about the Prime Minister?'. We were told that three officers drafted that letter, and none of them could remember how the prime ministerial discussion got in there. That is the first mistake. Today, we are told in a memo that:

SPEECH.PARA: The note includes a statement to the effect that the Danish Minister for Agriculture (Mr Tornaes), at his discussions with you in April 1992, raised the matter of access to Australia for uncooked Danish pigmeat and pig semen.

This statement was not correct. The recall note on your meeting with the Danish Minister, prepared by an officer of the Corporate Policy Division of the Department, makes no reference to importation of pig genetic material. No AQIS officer attended the meeting with the Danish Minister.
AQIS then tenders an apology. That document was in response to a freedom of information request I obtained from AQIS. It says:

A joint venture between Danpork (Denmark) and the Australian company Brown and Hatton has recently been announced to establish an integrated industry in Australian based Danish processing technology, Australian pig genetics and, ultimately, with inclusion of Danish pig genetic material if possible.
The Danish Minister for Agriculture raised the matter of access for uncooked Danish pigmeat and pig semen during discussions with Mr Crean in April 1992.

This is the second mistake, the second retraction. What is going on over there? This note certainly came in after the Estimates Committee hearing where we had asked a number of questions on this issue. Surely, the Department head would have gone through it with a fine toothcomb to find out if it had any mistakes. But no, he did not. The freedom of information answer came to me, I then asked questions on it, and Senator Button denied that there had been any ministerial discussions between two Ministers on the importation of pig meat, semen and genetic material, yet yesterday for the first time after questioning over two or three months Senator Button said that there was a ministerial meeting and that at that ministerial meeting there was no discussion about pigs or genetic material.

PARA.TAB: So Senator Button has three times told the Senate there were no ministerial discussions. He then changed that yesterday to say that there were ministerial discussions but that they did not include the topic of genetic material. Today we have been told, despite what I had tabled—and, sure, I only tabled one page of that because I thought only one page was relevant and it is the only page that was relevant; I tabled the whole five pages yesterday—that the letter which came in under freedom of information is wrong. So both the first letter, saying that there was prime ministerial intervention, and the second letter are wrong.

There are mistakes and there are mistakes. As Senator Cook says, there is no person here who has never made a mistake. But to write a letter and put in that letter that the highest officer, the highest politician, in this land pushed for genetic material being imported and then to say it did not really happen is really extending the realms of possibility to the limit. That is followed up today with another retraction. Today AQIS wrote to Minister Crean stating that the briefing note to Minister Griffiths on 23 June about the ministerial talks on pig meat and pig semen was incorrect. The letter says that the recall note of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy on the ministerial meeting `makes no reference to importation of pig genetic material'. I suppose Senator Button will be able to come in and say, `I did not mislead the Parliament'. I do not know where he is tonight. I told Senator Button today that he had not answered the questions correctly.

This is just another example of where we have to question the competence of the Department. There are the prime ministerial discussions which did not exist, the ministerial talks which did not take place, and the AQIS briefings to the Minister which were wrong and needed to be corrected. What ministerial briefing papers will be corrected next? Either the Department is inefficient, to say the very least, or it is being pressured into covering up the Prime Minister's business activities. No-one can be as inefficient as this. Whatever the case is, the Prime Minister himself must come into the Parliament and tell us what in the name of goodness is going on.

We have been told that there were no ministerial discussions. The Age has backed out, but its article was correct. The Age said that there was no ministerial discussion. Senator Cook has just spent 10 minutes telling us about the ministerial discussion. The Age said that the Prime Minister had not tried or did not intend to bring in live pigs or genetic material. We are told today in a cablegram, which I will read into the Hansard:

SPEECH.PARA: The issue of pigmeat imports from Denmark has been among AQIS's list of priorities for quarantine risk assessment for some time. Assessment of market aspects has more recently been proposed by DPIE. . .
The relevant program is:

AQIS has also been approached by the Danish Government and the Confederation of Danish Industries to undertake assessment of imports of live pigs. . . Higher priority was, until recently, being placed on these tasks as imports of genetic material were linked to a joint venture proposal between Australia and Danish industry that was being forged between 1991/92.
Who owned the joint venture then? The Prime Minister was in the joint venture. However, it now appears that import proposals may be of a lesser priority.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did they send that to the Prime Minister?

—That document was sent to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. Why should that have been sent to the Prime Minister's Department? There is another little piece here that I think deserves to be read into the Hansard since we are being told that the Prime Minister did not want to import live pigs or genetic material. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Interest in the Danish proposal, although initially very strong, has waned considerably
-AQIS understands that Danish interests may choose to establish the integrated industry infrastructure to service less demanding South East Asian markets using Australian genotypes
-delaying imports of more suitable Danish genotypes until the quarantine control infrastructure is in place and the political climate is more favourable.

Can someone get up and explain that to me? In other words, we are to bring in genetic material when the political climate is more established. There are so many questions here that are left unanswered that the Prime Minister must come clean. He must put down a statement in the Parliament so that we can all understand it. The Prime Minister has invested in a company. No-one objects to that. What we object to is the misrepresentation that is going on between AQIS, the Prime Minister, Senator Button and Senator Cook. The only way that this matter will be cleared up sufficiently is if the Prime Minister puts down a statement and lets the Parliament and the people of Australia know what is happening with his business investment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Boswell has just asked the impossible of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). He has asked him to put down a statement that the Opposition can understand. That is asking an inhuman amount because it is not possible. If it were ever going to be possible to clarify this issue, the facts that have been put forward would have done so. Had Senator Hill indicated to us beforehand what the document was that he wanted to table, we would happily have given leave then and there, because it is a document that helps the Government's case substantially, as Senator Cook made clear.

—That is not what he said. He made it very clear that there have been a series of allegations that have fallen flat. One is some indication that the now Prime Minister sought to interfere in the foreign investment process—that allegation has fallen flat—and another is some indication that the Prime Minister is seeking to import live pigs and genetic material. That is not so. As I understand it, it is actually quite contrary to his commercial interests for him to do that. Why would he want to do it?

PARA.TAB: The third question is: was there some discussion of the import of pig genetic material? The people who were at the meeting say no. Some people who were not at the meeting think perhaps there was, but no-one at the meeting has given any indication that that took place; the exact opposite, they have all made it clear that it was not so. Then there is the question: was the joint venture with which the Prime Minister is involved discussed at the meeting? All those at the meeting say no.

TALK.START.PARA: —Apart from commercial-in-confidence.
—No-one says that. They say the specific joint venture was not discussed. No specific joint venture was discussed; not that one or any other.
—There was only ever one. You know that.
—Order! Senator McMullan does not need your assistance, Senator O'Chee.
—I think he does.
—Senator O'Chee will stop interjecting.

—I will resist the wonderful temptation to respond. It would have been fun, but I accept your guidance, Mr Deputy President. I should have said one thing in opening, and that concerns this reference to why Senator Button is not here.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, that is why this is a very inappropriate time to be raising this matter. Apart from the fact there is other business we ought to be doing, Senator Button is fulfilling a longstanding commitment as Minister for Industry at a meeting of the Business Council of Australia. It may be a big surprise to Opposition senators that he is attending that meeting, but it seems to me that that is a very worthwhile thing to do. That is where he is and why he is not here. That is why this is a very inappropriate time to be discussing this matter.

The fact is that none of these allegations holds any water at all. All the evidence makes it clear that it is simply a series of assertions looking for a foundation. Opposition members dash about and, if there is a document with the word `pig' in it, they wave it and think it must be important. However, when one reads it, one finds that it actually disproves the allegation.

When one talks to the people who were actually at the meeting, one realises that the allegations about what was supposed to have taken place fall flat again, again and again. However, Opposition members keep coming back because apparently they do not want to talk about the issues concerning Australians. They want to go crawling through the sewers to try to find some issue. They come up smelling as people do who have been crawling through sewers but, fortunately for the hygiene of the Senate, they are empty handed.

It continues to happen. There have been several occasions on which they have sought to make these allegations and not one has been found to have any evidence at all. They are allegations in search of evidence. Let us get on with dealing with the business for which we are paid and stop this persistent running around in circles which has got us nowhere to date and with which the Australian people are as bored as the rest of the Senate.

Each time the allegation has been made it has been examined here with great hyperbole, but there is no substance. That is the case again tonight. It is a waste of the Senate's time; it is a waste of taxpayer's money. Let us get on with the business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—There are two points I want to make. Senator Robert Ray interjected on me and said, `Why do you say that the Prime Minister has an interest in the importation of this genetic material?' I refer him to the AQIS document dated 23 June 1992 which states:

SPEECH.PARA: A joint venture between Danpork (Denmark) and the Australian company Brown and Hatton has recently been announced to establish an integrated industry in Australia based on Danish processing technology, Australian pig genetics and, ultimately, with inclusion of Danish pig genetic material if possible.
That is why I say that, Mr Deputy President.

PARA.TAB: I listened to the defence given by Senator Cook tonight. What I was expecting to hear from him was some explanation as to how AQIS could have got it so wrong. We got no such explanation. How could AQIS have got it so wrong when it clearly was not a slip? How could it have got it so wrong not once, but now twice? Is he going to address the other AQIS memoranda which are equally embarrassing to his case? He has not done so yet, so I guess we will have to wait until we return for the next sitting of the Senate to get some answers to those questions.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Board of Employment, Education and Training and its Higher Education Council

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 8 October, on motion by Senator Bourne:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the NBEET report entitled Minimum Fees for Postgraduate Courses. This NBEET paper is a result of a ministerial direction to the board of NBEET to examine further the issue of minimum fees for postgraduate students.

PARA.TAB: The report advises against the setting of a minimum fee for postgraduates. In the 1991 NBEET report on postgraduate fee guidelines it is stated that fees charged for courses will be determined by the institution, subject to a minimum fee being charged which is equal to or greater than double the discounted HECS charge. This advice supports the view that this matter be left to the institutions with minimal government interference, believing that there are in-built restrictions as to the level of fee that can be charged, such as the requirement that institutions return to the government the equivalent of the discounted HECS to each fee paying student within the funded load.

The report advocates commission surveys after two or three years to assess the effect of the new arrangements. However, in forging these new arrangements there has been no consultation between the national board and CAPA, the Council of Australian Postgraduate Associations, despite the strong opinion of CAPA that the Government impose a minimum fee for postgraduate courses.

CAPA has consistently argued for the setting of a postgraduate fee that is the equivalent of the discounted HECS charge. I find it surprising that only a small proportion of fee paying students are expected to claim course fees against taxable income and expect that this will increase as more people undertake further education to improve their employability.

According to CAPA data has shown that more fee paying students than other course work postgraduates change their work commitments, including giving up work, in order to study—in fact, the figure is 23 per cent compared with 15 per cent; and it is surprising that more are not employed. Consequently their capacity to claim fees as a tax deduction is limited as not all earn sufficient income or pay sufficient tax to lodge a return or claim course fees against their income tax.

The Taxation Office deems that self-education expenses can be claimed only if the course is being undertaken for the purposes of improving or maintaining them in their existing profession. However, evidence demonstrates that people enrol in postgraduate programs often to move on to a new job. For these students a HECS debt would be fairer.

Thus, there are many problems and inconsistencies with a fee charging system for postgraduate courses. CAPA has aligned the imposition of fees with an increasingly utilitarian view of education with reports that some students make their course choices on financial grounds.

It is interesting to note what has happened in the area of course fees for postgraduate courses as some research by CAPA has indicated some astonishing results. For example, at Monash University it now costs $20,000 per year to do a masters in business banking. At Monash University an MBA now costs $32,000 per year, which is a vast amount of money for most people. At Melbourne University a masters will cost $31,000 per year and at Macquarie University an MBA will cost $27,750. Of course, at Swinburne Institute an MBA will cost $26,000 per year.

The point I am making is that these degrees do not come cheaply, and today a press release was issued by the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) complaining about the Opposition's fee policy for undergraduate courses. He made an astonishing remark about the Opposition's policy, and that is a separate question which I will not address here. I know that the Opposition understands what my position is on their fee policy for undergraduate students. But the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services had the audacity to actually point out that under the Opposition's policies some degrees could cost as much as $25,000 annually. Yet already under this Government fees for postgraduate courses have skyrocketed and are really beyond the reach of many average Australians.

It is our view that Mr Baldwin's statements today have been totally duplicitous as he tries to point out that the Government is driven by equity and has a policy of ensuring that all students have access to higher education. This is clearly not the case in the area of postgraduate courses. The report states that fees can be set to the level which the market can bear, which indicates that we should also look at a maximum fee for postgraduate courses to prevent escalating fees and to remind institutions and the Government alike that the value of postgraduate research is not in the revenue it can raise, but for the skilled graduates it produces. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Board of Employment, Education and Training and its Australian Research Council--Commercialisation of Research

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 8 October on motion by Senator Tierney:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Board of Employment, Education and Training has presented this report on the commercialisation of research which supports measures to increase collaboration between higher education institutions and industry. This report is an advice to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) commenting on two recent reports into the commercialisation of research.

PARA.TAB: NBEET has not blindly accepted the recommendations of this report and has actually offered some very sound advice to the Minister, much along the lines that the coalition will adopt when we are in government. It has been recommended that both the Australian Research Council and the National Health and Medical Research Council set aside 10 per cent of their expenditure for projects which demonstrate commercial commitment by industry. NBEET has quite rightly not supported this proposal, concluding that universities should be free to determine the extent of their links with industry, and acknowledged that in most industries this target level of commitment would already be exceeded.

Another recommendation was that joint industry and university appointments should be encouraged by the Government. NBEET agrees, and the coalition in its Fightback policy agrees that these links should be encouraged, but it must be emphasised that specific institutional appointments should not be dictated by the Government.

It has been also recommended that a technology transfer and development company should be established to buy and sell intellectual property and to invest in and develop Australian technology.
