It was encouraging to see that NBEET expressed some reservations about this idea as it truly appears to be more government interference in an area which can be looked after by the universities with minimal guidance from the Government. NBEET quite correctly suggests that such a technology group should be developed to enhance rather than compete with existing successful and effective technology groups.

In conclusion, NBEET expresses its strong support for measures to enhance collaboration between higher education institutions and industry and stated that it would be pleased to contribute further to initiatives in promoting commercialisation of Australian research endeavours. This encouragement of the commercialisation of research has long been the policy of the coalition.

Substantial government support for research activities is justified by the fact that much research has the character of a public good that is available to us all. There is, nevertheless, the challenge to ensure that this basic research does not take place in such a way that it is isolated from the community in which it occurs. That is why the coalition very strongly believes in encouraging the commercialisation of research, and in Fightback we have introduced the industry higher education research initiative.

Under this initiative, the Commonwealth Government will provide matching grants of one as to five for industry contracts obtained by university researchers. This money is not to support the contract, which is expected to be fully self-funding, but to provide resources for basic research activities by the host university. These may or may not be relevant to the contract research. The scheme provides a mechanism for allocating additional research funds in a thoroughly decentralised process where the decisions determining the allocation of funds are those of the institutions which will, under Fightback policy, become increasingly responsive to market opportunities.

This is in stark contrast to the Government's emphasis on centralised research funding. The coalition policy aims to encourage researchers to seek out projects with industry by providing the reward of additional funding for basic research. It will be accessible to all higher education institutions and it will ensure that links with industry are not developed at the expense of the responsibility of the universities for basic research. Up to $25m a year will be allocated to this scheme.

The future growth of research in Australia should be through commercialisation. Australian research should be more responsive to market need. This has always been coalition policy and it is good to see that NBEET is moving strongly in this direction. I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Consideration resumed from 8 October on motion by Senator Brownhill:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the Senate is a document entitled The National Road Safety Strategy. This is a very useful document which has been contributed to by a very large range of organisations from the areas of medicine, transport, police, ambulance, local government and education. The report offers many sensible ideas, principles and objectives. It is unfortunate, however, that this Government—and, more particularly, the Minister for Land Transport, Mr Brown—is in reality acting in a contrary direction with a safety problem that it has created on the national highway near his own electorate in the Hunter Valley. I am referring to the planning debacle of the F3 freeway between Sydney and Newcastle and the intention of the Government to let a section of the national highway stop in the middle of a swamp, eight kilometres from the next part of the national highway that it is meant to feed into.

PARA.TAB: In this report, one of the objectives of the strategy, Objective E, is entitled `safer vehicles, safer roads and safer road users'. The concept is to seek coordinated use of best available practices in road safety, introduce safety auditing principles into road design, construction and maintenance, and use traffic management programs to address existing problems such as road hazards and attempt to avoid new ones.

Given the current plans for the F3-Pacific Highway traffic link, it is clear that the Government has given scant regard to the national road safety strategy, particularly this Objective E. The F3 is part of the national road system, Australia's highway around the country, linking the whole country. Unfortunately, the end of the F3 at the moment is the break in that link. Instead of stopping in the middle of a swamp, the F3 is supposed to connect with the New England and Pacific Highways, which are the major link roads between Sydney and Brisbane, but the two northbound lanes of the F3 out of Sydney are going to feed into a single lane of local road called Lenaghans Drive, eight kilometres short of the main intersection of the northern highways. Lenaghans Drive is in a residential area. It has several intersections and a large volume of pedestrian traffic. Clearly it is not a safe option to feed a dual carriageway into such a road. The plan as it stands means that there will be a most horrendous bottleneck of traffic in peak periods.
The authorities building the F3 are well aware of the fact that this bottleneck will occur. The RTA states:

SPEECH.PARA: The perception of inadequacy will be heightened for the northbound traffic coming from freeway standards to a relatively short length of two lane road, with entering traffic, before further dual carriageways.

The relevant authorities know that the result will be a traffic disaster. Why is the Federal Minister, Mr Brown, going to let it occur, especially in light of his new national road safety strategy? Funding is needed urgently to connect the F3 both to the New England and the Pacific Highways with dual carriageways so that traffic can flow smoothly, efficiently, safely and, ultimately, at less cost to private users and to the public purse. Lenaghans Drive is not meant to be part of the national highway. It is regarded as a temporary measure until such time as the final location of the last eight kilometres is decided and constructed, but this could be another 20 years away.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Land Transport must act quickly to ensure that the temporary link is replaced as quickly as possible because it is totally inadequate and contrary to the national road safety strategy campaign that he has just released. I commend this report to the Senate, but with the hope that the Government will do something about implementing the strategy effectively, particularly with the broken link to the national highway near Newcastle, which will be of real danger to lives unless the Minister takes urgent action.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion to take note of the document and I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 5 March, on motion by Senator Coulter:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Threatened Species Bill 1992, which is a Bill that provides an excellent model for threatened species conservation in Australia. The Democrat Bill has wide support from the community, particularly from environmental groups.

PARA.TAB: Australia needs legislation to protect threatened species as a matter of urgency. Australia has the worst record of mammalian extinction in the world. The figures represent a national tragedy. Twenty mammals have become extinct since European occupation, another 26 are now endangered, and a further 17 are considered vulnerable. Twenty-one birds, including subspecies, have become extinct, 24 are endangered, and 27 are considered vulnerable.

Australia's record of plant extinction is equally appalling. Ninety-seven species are presumed extinct and just under 1,000 are endangered or vulnerable. These grim statistics appear even worse when comparisons are made with other developed countries. A figure of 12.3 per cent of Australia's vascular plants are deemed to be threatened compared to 0.8 per cent of Canada's plant population and 0.5 per cent of the United States plant population.

The problem is not limited to Australia. Species are being lost at an appalling rate around the world. Just the other day, an article appeared in the Courier Mail about the release of a United Nations study on the destruction of tropical rainforests, where most of the world's biological diversity is to be found. That study reveals that tropical rainforests are being destroyed at the rate of more than one acre per second, a rate that is 50 per cent higher than a decade ago.
The impact on biodiversity is devastating. As Dr John Hemming, Director of the Royal Geographic Society, has said recently:

SPEECH.PARA: The planet is losing its biodiversity and we do not know what we are throwing away forever.
In other words, it is disappearing before we have identified it and we will never know what we have thrown away.

PARA.TAB: Australia is the only developed country in the whole world that is classified as megadiverse. We have an enormous richness of flora and fauna. Many of these species are endemic—individual and unique to Australia—and many others remain to be discovered. We have an obligation to future generations, who are entitled to share a planet as rich and diverse as the one which we now inhabit, to conserve species that are threatened with extinction.

Legislation is essential to conserve threatened species; even the Government recognises that. At the last election, the Australian Labor Party promised to introduce endangered species legislation. I am sure that the Senate is aware that the Government is in the final throes of preparing this legislation. It has been a long time coming. It was to have been introduced during the last session, but it somehow slipped off the legislative program. Now, with an election looming, the Government sees it as a high priority—or so we are told.

The legislation was to have gone to Cabinet last week for approval. However, the Government went weak at the knees in the face of extraordinary claims made by industry, particularly the mining lobby. We are told in the press that it accused the Government of rushing through the legislation. It said that the Bill of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) cut across the ecologically sustainable development, or ESD, process; that it bypassed the inter-governmental agreement; that it would damage investor confidence; that it would give the Minister for the Environment unprecedented powers; that it was ill-timed and ill-considered; that it would open the floodgates of litigation; and that it would openly encourage third party intervention—in short, that its draconian elements were of concern to everyone in Australia. That is particularly what the mining lobby convinced the Government was the case.

This sustained and concentrated barrage on what was already a weak Bill, and one that is becoming weaker by the day, is a very cynical attempt by industry to frighten the Government and bring it into line with industry's agenda. Industry groups have shown very clearly that they do not want endangered species legislation. But, thankfully, it appears that the ALP is reluctant to drop the legislation altogether. I say `appears' because we are not sure what is actually going on.

In contrast, the community has shown that it wants the Federal Government to act decisively and to set uniform standards for the protection of plants and animals. Sixty-eight per cent of respondents in the Australian Nationwide Opinion Poll's survey on the environment and the ESD process gave this response: they want the Federal Government to act decisively and to set uniform standards for the protection of plants and animals.

The Government now appears to be paying more attention to the scaremongering by big business than to the real issues of conservation. If we were to allow a compromise to be developed, it would mean a compromise for threatened species legislation. That would end up in a compromise for the protection of threatened species. As I have already mentioned, there is urgent need for that protection to occur without compromise.

I will look for a moment at one of the claims made by industry that threatened species legislation lies outside the ESD process. That is a claim but nothing could be further from the truth. The former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, in a letter to the three chairs of the working groups in the ESD process, said that one of the four fundamental goals of ESD was the protection of biological diversity and the maintenance of ecological processes and systems. The chairs, in the intersectoral issues report, said that ESD should aim at preventing the further loss of biological diversity. The three chairs recommended that the concept of conserving biodiversity should be integrated into legislation, thereby disproving the claim that this threatened species legislation would be outside the ESD process.

Threatened species legislation is an absolute requirement to the achievement of ESD, but to be effective the legislation must ensure that all species are protected, that the community has significant input and that the Minister for the Environment has sole power over certain decisions. In this respect the proposed Bill attributed to Mrs Kelly fails abysmally.

The contrast between her Bill and Senator Coulter's Bill, which we are now discussing, is stark. Of paramount concern is the extremely limited applicability of the Government's Bill. It purports to relate only to Commonwealth areas and Commonwealth agencies. That is an absurdity. Commonwealth land represents a mere 0.2 per cent of this continent. On the other hand, Senator Coulter's Bill recognises that endangered species protection requires a truly national approach. This Bill applies to every trading corporation and every foreign corporation within paragraph 51(xx) of the Constitution. In other words, this Bill applies to the whole continent—a far more logical approach to species protection.

Where States enact equivalent threatened species legislation, the Commonwealth would not interfere. However, where a State fails to make sufficient progress on threatened species conservation, the Democrat Bill allows the Commonwealth to take action which would override the States. This measure is absolutely necessary to ensure that species are not sacrificed to State inaction. The Democrat Bill would lead, firstly, to the identification of threatened species across the whole country. I have already indicated how ridiculous it is that we are losing species before we even identify them.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you know you have lost them?

—How do we know we have lost the Tasmanian tiger? Senator Panizza has indicated his ignorance by his very interjection. The identification is required, regardless of the artificial jurisdiction of boundaries, because these are the very boundaries which flora and fauna cannot possibly be expected to take notice of.

PARA.TAB: The Democrat Bill would require the preparation and implementation of species recovery plans wherever a threatened species is identified. This systematic approach to species protection would benefit industry, regardless of what it may claim, by improving the information base and thereby providing a greater certainty in decision making. All industries, as I am sure Senator Panizza would agree, require at least a certainty in decision making. Uncertainty is one of the greatest destroyers of business decision making. Industry would know, prior to a development proposal, the location of a threatened species and the conditions attached to development in a particular area.

Another stark contrast between the Government's proposed legislation and the Democrat legislation before us is the level of community input. Mrs Kelly's Bill does not propose to allow the public to nominate species or ecological communities for listing. Senator Coulter's Bill recognises that the public has a genuine and rightful interest in nominating species individually, populations or ecological communities for listing.

While Mrs Kelly's Bill does allow individuals to apply for an injunction in relation to Commonwealth agencies, it does not allow individuals to apply for an injunction from the Federal Court to restrain developers from undertaking an action which would adversely affect a listed species or community. Nor does it allow third parties to apply to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to review decisions made by the Minister in relation to permanent conservation orders or permits to take a species. The Threatened Species Bill, on the other hand, allows for any individual to seek a review by the AAT for any decision made in relation to an impact statement carried out under the Bill. This allows any person, regardless of social status or financial position, to seek a remedy from the AAT on the basis of merit only and not the constraints which would apply if the financial parameters were limited.

Prior to last Thursday's ministerial meeting, where the pro-development members of Cabinet successfully pushed through changes that significantly weakened Mrs Kelly's Bill, as has been reported in the press, the Minister for the Environment had a power of veto over actions that would lead to the extension of species by Commonwealth agencies and governmental approvals. Apparently, this power has now been removed. The action Minister is now a development Minister, as designated under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. Once the EIS is completed it is now up to Cabinet to make a decision to approve a proposal and attach conditions.

At this stage we can observe that we can have absolutely no faith in such a procedure. We have been given proof of this recently by no less a person than the member for fast-tracking, Mr Brereton, who, in describing the process for the establishment of a proposed gold mine near Katherine, said that the EIS will be submitted in January and the project will start—the project `will start'—in March. In other words, there was no suggestion that the EIS might be inadequate or unacceptable. Regardless of what the EIS might say, the project will proceed. The EIS is therefore just another page to turn; just another box to tick. It has no real opportunity to determine the progress of the project. What is it worth? Absolutely nothing. We can have no faith in such a procedure and no faith in its ability to protect what it is meant to protect. It is useless.

The Government's proposed legislation is far from an adequate model for species protection. The potential for economic considerations to dominate in the determination of the outcome of a Cabinet decision is very high. This is what industries wanted. This morning the Australian newspaper reported that industry groups are still pushing for economic considerations to be included in the listing process. It is absolutely imperative that Cabinet refuses to bend to industry demands on this issue. The Government's Bill would become an absurdity if the listing process included economic caveats, as is being proposed.

How on earth can economic considerations be brought into the actual listing, the identification, of a threatened species? It is either threatened or it is not. Economic considerations are irrelevant. If it is a species which is identified as being reduced in numbers and is threatened, what on earth has any other consideration to do with it? We are talking about a definition of whether something is threatened or not. I cannot understand how economic considerations can impinge on that definition.

The Democrat Threatened Species Bill ensures that the Minister for the Environment is the action Minister and that that Minister has the right of final determination. That veto power guarantees the effectiveness of the legislation. The veto, of course, would be a last resort option, used only where a threatened species, population or ecological community was being threatened with extinction, and species recovery plans would be inadequate to safeguard survival. I imagine that the use of such a veto would be a rare occurrence and that it would certainly not be a decision made lightly. The opportunity to remove the chance of its being used depends entirely on the species recovery plans which, if suitable, would militate against the necessity of the veto being exercised.

There are many other marked differences between the Government's Endangered Species Bill and the Democrat's Threatened Species Bill. For example, assistance to developing countries is accorded much greater importance in the Democrat Bill and the expertise required on the scientific advisory panel is, in the case of the Democrat Bill, clearly defined. But the differences do not rest here. Funding to maintain biological diversity is given a much higher priority by the Democrats than it is by the Labor Government.

At the last election the Australian Labor Party promised to give a major increase in funding for a comprehensive biological survey of Australia to be completed by the year 2000. Here, again, the ALP has failed to deliver. The allocation has been increased from $1.1m in 1990 to $1.5m in 1992. It has been estimated that at this rate of funding, the survey will take 1,000 years to complete, by which time we would have lost many species before they are discovered. The Democrats, as part of an integrated budget for species conservation, would increase funding of the survey immediately to $3.5m from the 1992 level. Only when we know the full range of Australian flora and fauna can we be certain how all species can be conserved.

In response in part to an earlier interjection by Senator Panizza, I think it is important that we consider a matter which was presented to the Senate Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts when that Committee recently visited the Freshwater Research Institute at Wodonga as part of its inquiry into the management of Australia's water resources. I would imagine that all members of the Senate would consider this inquiry to be of tremendous importance, even if only because of the graphic illustrations late last summer of the incredibly devastating effects that the emergence of blue-green algae in the Murray-Darling river basin was having on the prospects for farming, and even the prospects of living, in the region. The water that was available in certain towns was totally unusable. Even just knowing that should identify this inquiry as being important to all Australians.

When visiting the Freshwater Research Institute at Wodonga, members of the Committee were shown some zooplankton which were known to be grazers of blue-green algae—in other words, the little beasties that live in the water and eat up this material that can become toxic in our water courses. We were shown—and I am sure that Senator Crowley, if she were here, would remember it because it was particularly graphic—some zooplankton known as rotifers which engage in the process of grazing on blue-green algae.

These little beasties which live in the Australian freshwater system have not been sufficiently identified. Very little is known about their habits, their durability, their capacity to graze on blue-green algae, their breeding patterns, or how long they live. In fact, thousands of them have not been identified. These zooplankton have the capacity to contribute to the ecological balance in such a way that I would suggest there could be a direct financial value placed upon their very survival. If they do not survive, and if that is a cause of the blooming of blue-green algae, the immediate effect will be felt throughout Australia's inland farming communities.

I suggest, Senator Panizza, that even though we do not know what they are, we know that they are important. They are so important that they are crucial to the survival of Australian agriculture. We are not spending enough money on identifying them. We are not putting enough effort into ensuring that they are identified and that their survival is guaranteed. That is precisely the sort of project and activity which Australians will ignore at their peril. It is precisely that sort of project for which increased funding is proposed under Senator Coulter's Threatened Species Bill.

The Democrat Bill sets the agenda for threatened species legislation. It provides the best possible safeguards for threatened species protection, whilst providing secure mechanisms to compensate any land-holder affected by orders made by the Minister. I challenge the Government to analyse this Bill carefully and to incorporate the key features of the Bill into its own endangered species legislation. It is time to stop the further extinction of Australia's native species. If Australia's shame is its record of extinction, Australia's pride must be its resolve to end the further loss.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will not be supporting the Threatened Species Bill. There is no doubt that it is clearly a central part of Senator Coulter's strategy to position the Australian Democrats as the Green party at the next election, cashing in on the disillusionment of conservationists with the post-1990 performance of Labor and attempting to pre-empt the emergence of separate and effective Green political organisations. Geoffrey Blainey said in a recent article in ABM:

SPEECH.PARA: For the sake of the economy let's hope that the new Prime Minister—
as he was when this article was written—
is less a captive of the greens than his predecessor.
He went on to say:

PARA.TAB: The Democrats, when they emerged in the late 1970s, were not primarily a green party but now they are. As they are still seen mistakenly as a middle-of-the-road party—

SPEECH.PARA: I interpose there: I do not know what track they are on. They are certainly not middle-of-the-road, but they are masquerading as such a party. The quote continues:
a moderate alternative to the big parties, they presumably will remain powerful in the Senate after the next election.

Regrettably, some of them have long term seats. Even though their electoral support is falling apart for a whole range of reasons—along with their party, for example, in New South Wales—throughout the nation—

TALK.START.PARA: —In Victoria.

—And Victoria with South Australia being almost an eccentric centre of what could loosely be described as strength, I suppose. But they will, unfortunately, be in this chamber even though their electoral support has collapsed. Geoffrey Blainey goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: But their effective power will decline if Labor, under Paul Keating and John Dawkins, reverses Mr Hawke's aversion to new resource projects.

PARA.TAB: The year 1991 ended in economic farce. Both the Labor and the Democrat parties opposed a rapid increase in Australia's dominant source of exports. In effect, they opposed economic recovery while deluding themselves that they wanted recovery.

Half of Australia's commodity exports now come from mines, and some of the biggest manufacturing exports also depend on an efficient mineral base. But the search for new mines is retarded and the development of new-found orebodies is impeded by the federal government. Early in 1991, according to the consultants of Access Economics, a long list of export projects were held up by green complaints or allied Aboriginal objections.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a few getting through.
—A few are getting through, as Senator Panizza says—only a few. The article continues:

SPEECH.PARA: In timber and paper products, bureaucratic obstacles are also high.

PARA.TAB: Australian history offers no precedent for such a venture in economic suicide.

SPEECH.PARA: And here we have the harakiri kings in the Democrat corner killing off this economy, preventing its economic recovery and now coming out with proposed legislation which would be disastrous for any kind of major economic recovery in the area where Australia has its greatest opportunities.

PARA.TAB: The range of this Bill is extraordinarily wide. Its title really is a misnomer, not only because it deals with endangered species but also because it applies to ecological communities, defined as assemblages of flora and fauna that interact as identifiable functional and/or spatial units. We heard already tonight that, yes, it is a very broad Bill.

Other definitions are as broad and as vague. For instance, there is no attempt to define `endangered'. This Bill about endangered species does not define what `endangered' is. It does not define what the word `vulnerable' means. The basis for listing in schedules to the legislation species, populations and ecological communities, is to include any of these in a state of decline which is human induced, whether directly or not, and which could potentially result in extinction.

This open-ended approach asks us to try to look hundreds of years into the future. It envisages the creation of a range of committees and advisory bodies—no doubt populated with failed Democrat political candidates—to implement the proposals. The main such body is the Commonwealth Threatened Species Advisory and Management Committee whose nine members comprise five—that is a majority—nominated by conservation groups; one by the Minister; the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service; the Director of the proposed Threatened Species Unit; and a sole—one, single, solitary—non-government, non-conservation representative from the National Farmers Federation.

There is no provision whatsoever here or anywhere else for representatives from key industries that would be affected by the Bill, such as forestry or fishing, yet consistently in this place we have the Democrats demanding that conservationists be appointed to boards or authorities where there may well be some kind of impact on conservation. We have once again the double standards, the special pleading, that are the hallmark of Democrat policies—I cannot even call them populist policies, because they are not all that popular—desperately seeking to appeal to a narrow edge of the Australian political spectrum. After all, I suppose they really only want to get the support of 14 per cent of the people so they can get a quota in a Senate election.

The scope of the Bill is simply unacceptably wide. While seeking to encourage the States and Territories to introduce similar legislation, it provides that the Minister may introduce overriding legislation, recommend to the Governor-General that he make regulations which override State or Territory laws and `take any appropriate administrative action'. The Coulter legislation would apply to every Commonwealth agency and would rely on the foreign affairs and corporations power in the Constitution to extend its reach.

The proposal, naturally, along with all Democrat proposals, would involve considerable outlays estimated by 1994-95 to be $100m annually for a threatened species program, $24m for an Australian biological resources survey, and $170m for land care. But we need not worry, it will all be paid by the higher taxes that the Australian Democrats want to impose on an Australia already suffering so severely from the combination of taxes and recession.

There is real doubt about the ability of the various bodies to comply with the tasks given them under this legislation, particularly the practicality of making the assessments necessary to determine the status of species or communities. In administering the legislation the Minister is bound to consider only the objects of the Act. No reference is made to any consideration whatsoever of any other impact such as a social or an economic impact. This is one-eyed, one purpose legislation, and that one eye and that one purpose is set on getting the green vote to get back into parliament.

It provides for unlimited third party access to either the Federal Court or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and requires that the Minister must provide legal aid to assist such people. There is one thing this Bill does promise: an area of significant natural growth. That natural growth is a bonanza for the legal profession and has the potential to add major extra delays to approvals processes, adding enormously to the cost and burden to be faced by those industries trying to get Australia out of its economic crisis.

Additionally, all appeals, with the exception of those applying to compensate for interim and permanent conservation orders, and matters relating to one other form of agreement, can be based only on the grounds that decisions are not in accordance with the objects of the Act. This would seem to allow the overturning of a decision on the grounds that it was not stringent enough but not if it were excessive or unnecessary for the conservation of a particular species or ecosystem—an extraordinary situation where, again, there is this one-eyed approach which is simply unreasonable and unfair to the rest of Australia.

The Government has published a discussion paper on its own promised endangered species legislation, and there has been considerable discussion on it. I will not go into that at great length at the moment because we will have the opportunity to discuss it at a later stage.

There is no doubt that the Coulter legislation is too broad and too vague and cannot be supported by the coalition. I should mention in concluding that there has obviously been a lot of heartburning in the Government about what the Coulter legislation is trying to do, because the Government is trying to recapture some of the lost Green and far left support that has drifted over to the Democrats which once was a middle-of-the-road party and now is a backtrack party.

The attempt by Mrs Kelly, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, to take on a veto power was clearly in response to that kind of pressure. It is interesting to see that her ambit claim—as I think it was called—in her draft legislation has sensibly been knocked back, I understand, by the Keating Cabinet. That ambit claim would have given her the most extraordinary, incredible power—almost the sort of power that this Bill is wrongly trying to give to the conservation movement by giving it a majority on the key committee that is part of this legislation.

It is interesting to note the re-drafting of Mrs Kelly's environment Bill, which was, of course, a trying-to-buy-votes Bill. After a meeting between Prime Minister Keating, Mrs Kelly and industry Ministers, Mrs Kelly's veto power to stop projects if they threatened an endangered species was removed. Now, I understand—and we have yet to see it, of course—the revised endangered species legislation to come from the Government will enable Mrs Kelly only to issue an interim conservation order to stop such projects, but Cabinet will have the final say.

That may, of course, be exactly what the Democrats want. Greenpeace spokesman Ian Fry said that bowing to business pressure and allowing industry Ministers to decide the future of Australia's endangered wildlife was:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . like putting the fox in charge of the chicken coop.
He said of the legislation:
It was weak to start with and it's even weaker now.

No doubt that is why the Democrats are bringing this legislation on now. It was first brought in back in May of this year. Now it is being brought forward because the Government, of course, is coming up with its legislation. This is a clear political attempt to try to drag Green support away from this Government and, of course, to pre-empt those separate Green parties that have indicated that they intend to stand for the next election because they are dissatisfied with the efforts of existing political parties.

PARA.TAB: Like industry leaders, the coalition was very concerned about Mrs Kelly's veto power, saying that it put investment in Australia at risk and attacked private property rights without compensation. We still have some problems with that legislation, and it will be interested to see it when it comes up. But we certainly have no problem in deciding what to do with this proposed legislation from the Australian Democrats, this politically oriented effort—we will be voting against it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —(9.51 p.m.)—I am pleased to join in the debate this evening on the Australian Democrats' Threatened Species Bill 1992, introduced by Senator Coulter. As has already been pointed out, this is clearly a central part of Senator Coulter's attempt to pick up the Green vote and put the Democrats in the Green position for the next election. This move by Senator Coulter and others in the Democrats has not started just recently. Going back at least 12 months ago, when I was in the company of Senator Spindler in Eastern Europe, he was introducing himself as a member of the Green Party. I took him aside and asked, `Aren't you a Democrat any more?'. He said, `We are attempting to move towards being Green'. He was so adamant that he pulled out a card that said, `Senator Coulter, Green Party of Australia'. He showed it to me. So let him come into this place and deny that he ever said that.
—Was that Senator Coulter?

—No, I said Senator Spindler. Let him come into this place and deny that he told me those things. That is one of the first reasons that this legislation has come on now: because the Greens were given promises by the Government at the last election, the Government dropped the Greens like the proverbial as soon as the election was over, and the Democrats hope to pick that constituency up now.

PARA.TAB: The second reason it has been brought on now is that they are trying to gazump the Government, which will be bringing in its endangered species legislation any time now. The third reason, of course, and the reason that I am most interested in, is to create that catch-all clause against mining and rural development—mostly against mining development.

Honourable senators would probably know that in the taxation Acts, and various other Acts, there is always a catch-all clause at the end so that, if everything else fails, people can be caught with that clause. Senator Tate would know that because he is a solicitor. That is what the Democrats are attempting to do in this case. As honourable senators have probably noticed in the last couple of months, there are a few mining developments that have gone past, say, the thirteenth report—Marandoo was the thirteenth and I believe that Yakabindie was the fifteenth report—and the Western Australian Government, which is about to fall in a couple of months time, has seen the light: that if it wants to get the Western Australian economy going again, it has to start some new developments. So it has let Marandoo and Yakabindie go. Now this Greens-Democrat party here is trying to put this catch-all clause in. Senator Chamarette can laugh as much as she likes. If she knew as much about mining development as I do, or had ever been to a mining development, she would not be smiling so much. That is what the Democrats are intending to do in this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't care about jobs.

—No, jobs are nothing to them. The Democrats are trying to put in a catch-all clause—`If everything else fails, we will use it'. First, one cannot develop a mining site as a resource because of its beauty; secondly, it may be in a national park, or if it is not in a national park, try to make it one; thirdly, it may be a sacred site; and, fourthly, it may have Aboriginal heritage. If an industry can manage to get past those, the Democrats say that there must be a catch-all clause to knock it out.

PARA.TAB: We may as well have a look at Senator Coulter's legislation and see what it is about. As Senator Baume pointed out, the title `Threatened Species Bill' is really a misnomer because the Bill deals with not only endangered species—and who knows what endangered species are because Senator Bell said that they are not even identified—but also ecological communities. The legislation defines `ecological community' as:

SPEECH.PARA: an assemblage of flora and fauna that interacts as an identifiable functional unit or identifiable spatial unit, or both.

Other definitions are broad and vague. There has been no attempt, as Senator Baume said, to define what endangered or vulnerable species are. So we are looking forward with a totally open-ended approach to the next couple of hundred years. I presume that Senator Coulter also has a crystal ball to go with his legislation. Perhaps he could tell us whether he has.

PARA.TAB: What I am most interested in about this legislation is that it envisages the setting up of more committees. The main body would be a Commonwealth threatened species—unidentified threatened species—advisory and management committee comprising nine members, five of whom will be nominated by conservation groups. The Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, would know that a jury is selected to get a fair trial. That is why the jury process is there. If the jury contains five members of opposing families, I do not think that there is much chance of being found anything but guilty.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about if the foreman is a member of the Young Nationals?

—We will debate that famous Queensland jury at another time. One would expect that one would get a fair go with a jury, but not if five members are nominated by conservation groups. It gets worse. The committee also has a representative nominated by the Minister—I presume that nomination would be fair and equitable—and the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. I can just imagine how he or she would go. There is also the director of the proposed threatened species unit—unidentified of course—and a sole non-government, non-conservation representative from the National Farmers Federation. There is no provision for anyone else from key industries such as fishing, forestry and mining. Where has mining gone? It is certainly not represented here. Of course, they are the ones who have said they would be there to slug.

PARA.TAB: The legislation encourages the States and Territories to introduce similar legislation. Senator Bell said that, once the States and Territories have introduced their own legislation, the Federal legislation, if we were unfortunate to get such legislation through this Senate—I doubt that anyone would be silly enough to do that—will override it. Proposed section 67 (b) states:

SPEECH.PARA: (b) recommend that the Governor-General make regulations which will override any existing State or Territory legislation;

The Democrats want the States and Territories to make these laws, but then they want the Federal laws to override them. They do not really know where they are going. This applies to every Commonwealth agency. What chance is there of any industry or resources being developed under this sort of legislation?

PARA.TAB: The Democrats will rely on the foreign affairs and corporations powers of the Constitution to extend its reach. We have the Franklin River dam, Kakadu and Shark Bay—that is the one that Senator Richardson had not heard of when the deal was done—foisted on us again, as if we did not have enough of that without having any more.

This legislation, if it were ever to see the light of day, would involve considerable outlays. The Democrats' budget estimates for 1994-95 would be $100m annually for the threatened species program—unidentified threatened species—$24m for the Australian biological resources survey and $170m for Landcare. The Landcare program is the only sensible suggestion in the whole legislation.

There are doubts about various bodies complying with the tasks given them and there are doubts about the practicalities of making the assessments necessary to determine the status of species or communities. In the main body of the legislation we find that in administering the legislation the Minister is bound to consider only the objects of the Act.

Senator Bell made a big noise about this. Will Senator Bell and Senator Coulter ever tell me where the economic provision for this country is to come from? There is no reference in the legislation to a consideration of social or economic impacts. The economic impact is the one that I am most interested in. It is one big slug to the mining industry. As I said before, if one has a jury, one expects to get a fair trial. Under the Democrats, the mining industry would not get one.

Let me put it this way: when the Democrats cannot find anything else to stop development, the situation is just like that in a criminal trial. If one knows one is going to be found guilty, there is only one way to lessen the penalty and that is to plead insanity. That is about all the Democrats are doing here—pleading insanity.

I will give honourable senators an idea of what has been happening in Australia in the past 10 years under this Government, helped by the Democrats. Although we are coming to the plateau and are going over the edge now, we have been living on development in the mining and resource industries which was put into action in the 1960s and the 1970s. That was ably led by Sir Charles Court of Western Australia who commenced development of the Pilbara in 1963 or 1964.
Senator Coulter interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coulter will even argue about that. Developments which have been put aside for environmental reasons include Coronation Hill, where every excuse on earth was used. The project went through every stage, but finally the former Prime Minister had to agree to put it to bed—hopefully not forever—in order to help him win the last election. We had the sacred sites bit, the fragile environment bit and the unique species bit. The Government went through everything.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the forgone opportunities during the past 10 years in Western Australia—my part of the continent. A $150m investment in a rare earth project which was proposed by Rhone-Poulenc at Pinjarra was lost. The revenue would have amounted to $100m per year. There was the silicon smelter development by the Barrack Group, now Simcoa. The cost of State delay amounted to $100m. For the Canning Resources project at Hill River, the exploration and feasibility studies cost $30m; the proposed investment was $1.5 billion. That is one-third of the amount that went into the gas project on the North West Shelf. The feasibility studies on the Yakabindie nickel mine have cost $10m to date. Delay costs have not yet been defined, but are probably in the vicinity of $100m. The Beenup mineral sands project was deferred for 12 months with the cost in deferred investment amounting to $135m. These are only some of the projects that are around the place. The list goes on. Nine hundred applications for exploration licences have been stopped or delayed. Of these, 497 were on private land, let alone public land. There are 173 applications on conservation estates and 235 on Aboriginal land or land considered to be environmentally sensitive which are currently delayed. Some applications have been pending for five years.

The total cost in lost investment in Western Australia alone amounts to $2.5 billion. How many jobs would $2.5 billion worth of investment have created? We may not have had the one million unemployed in Australia or, worse still, 1.7 million under-employed. The total annual revenue lost is probably about $1 billion per year. I remind honourable senators that these are the figures for Western Australia alone. That is why this legislation is before us—to try to stop more and more of these projects. As I said, we are still living off the results of the development of the 1960s and the 1970s. But we are now seeing it going over the hill and on to the horizon. We have to get more developments going if we want to get out of the mess we are in.

As Senator Baume pointed out, the legislation provides unlimited third party access to either the Federal Court or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. It requires that the Minister provide legal aid. That is the bit I like. We are going to have another Aboriginal Legal Service. The only difference is that it will be called the `Green Legal Service'. Some unkind person in my office made a notation in my speech notes that this legislation is going to be a bonanza for the legal profession. I am not a legal profession basher at all. I do not look upon it as a boon for the legal service because it generally has enough to do as it is with all these royal commissions into corrupt governments around Australia.

The point is that this legislation is going to be a bonanza for the radicals, educated on the public purse, who will do nothing but rip the public down by stopping projects from going ahead. The legislation will have the potential to add extra delays to the development approval process. As someone has already said, Senator Coulter's legislation is too broad and too vague, and I say it is too stupid as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Threatened Species Bill 1992 is very interesting. I attended the promotion of this Bill in Hobart when Senator Coulter came down to Tasmania to speak. I went along to have a look and I thank him for the invitation. I was delighted to look at all the posters and paintings that were on display. The more I see of this legislation and the more I hear of it, the more it leaves me in no doubt that this is one almighty political stunt. The more I see of it, the more I hear of it, the more I believe it is education, not legislation that we need to protect our flora and fauna. I repeat: it is education, not legislation that we need.

PARA.TAB: The issue was summed up to me when I was listening to Senator Panizza's speech. I could hear the snide remarks made by Senator Coulter about Senator Panizza's wealth. Senator Panizza made his money by working hard. He pays his taxes and those taxes go towards paying for social welfare. Do these greenies and conservationists who go around stopping all these projects in Australia pay any taxes to compensate the people who have lost money and who have gone broke because of the things that have happened?

My colleague Senator Tate on the other side of the House would know about the effect of the Greens in Tasmania. A lot of it has been good because they have educated people about the environment and all that sort of thing. But it has just gone too far. It caused the downfall of the Green-Labor accord. The Labor Party down there soon found out what the Greens were all about. The once proud State of Tasmania that relied heavily on agriculture, mining and forestry has been reduced to an economic wasteland.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is true—by the forestry industries.

—Rubbish! There is hardly anything left for forestry to cut because it has all been locked up by the lunatic greenies like Senator Chamarette. We only have to look at the sorts of things that well meaning journalists bring forward. I well remember when I first came to this place talking to Senator Walsh. Senator Walsh is no friend of the greenies, as we all know. But he said, `You people in Tasmania are going to have to suffer these greenies and show the rest of Australia just what they're all about'. We certainly have done that in Tasmania—we have suffered the greenies and shown the rest of Australia what they are all about. Unfortunately, the majority of people in Tasmania have suffered because of it.

PARA.TAB: Tasmania has the highest level of unemployment in Australia, and in particular the highest level of youth unemployment. We cannot blame the loss of jobs purely and simply on the previous Government or on this present one. It has happened because the things that we used to do best—agriculture, mining and forestry—have been severely curtailed by some well meaning conservationists but particularly by the lunatic ones.

So what is now being put forward is the Endangered Species Protection Bill—a political stunt. The only endangered species this Bill is out to protect is the Democrats themselves. They are endangered, they know it and they want to be seen as the people who are looking after the endangered species around Australia.

The Democrats are not the only ones who are concerned about endangered species around Australia. I think all people, whether farmers, miners or whatever, have certainly become more and more aware of their environment over the past 10 or 20 years. We can all remember the ethos of the early settlers of Australia: if it stood up, one cut it down; if it moved, one shot it. But that has changed.

TALK.START.PARA: —If it is in the ground, you dig it up and flog it off to foreigners

—A lot of people have benefited from that. If we cannot continue to mine and downstream our resources and all the rest of it, we might as well pack up and go back to the dark ages. Let me quote from P.P. McGuinness going back to 16 August 1991. He makes the point:

SPEECH.PARA: I have often wondered whether it would be possible to design a scheme whereby people could be levied an environment tax, so that those who are most obsessed and determined to prevent virtually any economic activity, such as forestry, could be made to pay compensation to those who will suffer from their activities.
He continues:

There is no way in which the environment fanatics can be made to pay for the damage they inflict on the economy, nor be made to compensate for the lies they tell which have direct and considerable economic costs—
to the country.

PARA.TAB: As I have said, we have seen what has happened in Tasmania. I was most concerned to hear Senator Bell say that an important part of Senator Coulter's legislation was to allow the Commonwealth to take action over the States. If ever a State has suffered because of Commonwealth legislation, it is Tasmania. We have had our spy flights; we have had Senator Richardson coming in and overruling the State Government; and we now have the situation with Mrs Kelly and all these environment studies which just go on and on and on.

I noted one article that related back to the days of Helsham where the State had had more than 10 inquiries over the past 15 years. But because the results of those inquiries did not suit the conservationists' agenda, they called for another one. This has happened in even more recent times with the Wesley Vale mill. Inquiries are still going on up there, and the process just goes on and on and on. The conservationists are never satisfied unless the information elicited at an inquiry suits their purpose.

I well remember the day when Senator Walters brought a map into this place showing the areas of Tasmania which had been locked up. Well, more and more areas have been locked up. I do not argue with some of our more important areas being locked up and preserved, but it is now at the stage where they are inventing names and areas. I think the other week Senator Coulter was down at place so called the Tarkine. The Tarkine is Bob Brown's invention; he made up that word and invented that area. It is all supposed to be pristine wilderness when in fact we have the Savage River mine in the middle and the town of Corinna. There are a few areas of forest in there but a lot of agriculture too. Are we going to lock all that up as well? It just goes on and on and on.

The most recent effort down there was Bender's quarry at Ida Bay. I remember very well when Senator Bell first raised the matter here. There was a bit of press about it down home, and of course I said, `We're onto a good one here'. That has been continually bashed along. We have now got to the situation where closure of that mine will affect not only the last major industrial producer in Hobart, the Pasminco EZ, but all the local farmers and orchardists who rely on that particular source of limestone. It fits in with the conservationists' method of things. It is not a fertiliser; it is a natural soil conditioner which is essential to increasing production for horticulturalists, orchardists and local major industry in Hobart. But no thought is given to those aspects. It was a good idea at the time.

That area is to be locked up and kept for posterity. I have not yet turned off the lights to check out Senator Bell, even though these caves are supposed to be radioactive. If that is the case following a statement by an eminent scientist that these limestone caves have radiation 800 times above what is considered normal, I think perhaps the industry has been doing people a favour by mining this limestone and putting it to good use rather than locking it up and getting people like Senator Bell radioactive.

The way this issue has been attacked would make one think that the mining industry in particular is the villain of the piece. Granted in the early days, and even as recently as a couple of decades ago, very little was done about rehabilitation and encouraging reafforestation and the regeneration of native flora and fauna. But I would recommend to Senator Coulter, if he has not already read them, a couple of magazines which were put out by the Mining Industry Council. One cannot fake photographs to the extent that they can been seen in this particular magazine. I think this magazine is a credit to the industry. It sets out in great detail, for instance, rehabilitation after bauxite mining at Weipa. In fact, I hope to have a look at that operation when in a few weeks' time I am up there with the Public Works Committee.

There is also a good article in the magazine about collecting native seed for mine rehabilitation; reconstruction of the wetlands after the mineral sands have been extracted; an article headed `From sands to ducks' about returning life to the Pilbara in an area that was once a waste dump. There certainly has been a big awakening in industry and mining in the area of flora and fauna. But do we really need to use the heavy hand of legislation to ensure that the right thing is being done?

From my observation in the four or five years I have been in this place and from my involvement in what was formerly the Select Committee on Animal Welfare and what is now the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs—and on many occasions Senator Bell has accompanied me—I believe the fauna of Australia are under much greater threat from feral animals than from mining industries and developers. The fact that the bilby is disappearing from large areas of Australia is not because of mining. It is because of the competition it is getting from feral horses, feral donkeys, foxes and the like.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill is designed to tackle that.

—Do we need legislation to do it? When the Committee investigated feral animals, we ran into all sorts of trouble with well-meaning animal welfare people who were disgusted that horses had to be shot from helicopters, when in fact it was the only economic, safe and humane way to do it.
—I agree with you entirely.

—I thank the Senator. Farmers in my own State of Tasmania—I will not name them but some of them are my relations—are trying to put their farms back into forestry but get into all sorts of trouble with well-meaning conservationists. We have plagues and plagues of wallabies which are eating all the young seedlings. The only effective way of reducing the numbers to a sufficiently low level to allow the trees to grow is to poison the wallabies. But, no, they are not allowed to use 1080 poison.
—Shoot them.

—That is not effective. They cannot shoot them. One particular person in the area wanted to shoot them, but he got into all sorts of trouble because he was keeping people awake at night. So what do they do?

PARA.TAB: In addition, all sorts of weeds have been introduced into Australia which are competing with our local native flora. There is only one effective way to get rid of most of these weeds and that is to spray them, but the farmers are not allowed to spray them. That is just not on. It does not fit in with the environment. Senator Bell knows that we have to be practical. Even his radishes that he is so concerned about have to be sprayed.

The Democrats are putting forward this legislation in order to curry favour with the conservationists and give them power. The Government, and in particular the Minister for Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly), has decided that it cannot let the Democrats have it all to themselves and has brought in its own legislation. Now we have two sets of legislation and, at the end of the day, if the Democrats do not get their legislation through, they will turn around and support the Government's legislation. As a result the Commonwealth Government will ride roughshod over the States and we will return to the position of confrontation that we have come to know so well in this country.

Any well-meaning investors who are thinking about coming to Australia to develop an industry of sorts will immediately turn their backs on the place. There is no question but that that will happen. One only has to read comments in today's Canberra Times. I note that the mining industry has identified the problems that have occurred in the United States since they brought in endangered species legislation. It has caused all sorts of problems. The article suggests that we find a better way to go about this matter in Australia.

As I said earlier, what is wrong with education? We have educated our people into not littering the country as they used to. There is still a bit of littering occurring, but the position is much better than it used to be. That was achieved by education, not legislation. That is the answer. Obviously it is not the sort of sexy answer that the Democrats want because there are no votes in education. Certainly there are plenty of votes to be gained if they can be seen to be putting through legislation.

As Senator Panizza said earlier, we have seen legislation being used for the wrong purposes. Senator Bell would have to admit that this is correct, but probably the last hydro-electric scheme in Tasmania, the King scheme on the west coast, had almost reached the stage where they were ready to fill up the holes and let the water flood in, when all of a sudden Michael Mansell decided there were a couple of sacred sites there. They had five years to raise this matter, but after fighting the conservationists and carrying out environmental impact studies which went on for years, they were ready to breathe a sigh of relief and get the scheme moving. It was a nice non-polluting, hydro-electricity producing scheme, but they found so-called sacred sites there. In Tasmania we have had sacred sites, World Heritage areas, National Estate, so-called rainforests like the Tarkine and the Franklin Dam debacle.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you had the Wagul yet?

—We have not had a Wagul yet, but that is what will happen with this endangered species legislation. Honourable senators can bet their lives that every time an area of forestry is to be cut down or a native forest that may be of some use, someone will see a Tasmanian tiger in there.
—Ha, ha!
—Senator Tate knows what will happen. They will see a Tasmanian tiger.
—What is an estimate of the cost of a Tasmanian tiger?

—When I first stood for the Senate and I went around the west coast with a couple of friends of mine campaigning, one of them informed me that this was a place where he used to see plenty of Tasmanian tigers. I said, `If I can find one, put it in the boot of my car and take it back to Hobart, there is no question but that I will get elected'. I was talking about a live one, of course. Then he informed me that the only time he saw one was when he was coming back from the football at New Norfolk on a Saturday night.
—The Cascade tiger.

—Yes. So let us get practical and forget about this ridiculous legislation. I would have supported the Democrats and the Government if they had come forward with a national education scheme aimed at protecting our wildlife. This would educate people about the effects that feral cats in particular are having on our bird life, that feral animals are having on our native wildlife and that introduced species of weeds are having on our flora. We do not need legislation for that. This has just been a great PR exercise that is going nowhere and doing nothing.

—The Government, being very strongly committed to action to protecting endangered species, nevertheless does not find itself able to support this particular legislative measure put forward by the Democrats tonight. It is quite clearly a measure which is designed for a very short term political promotion for the Democrats via those wonderful posters, which I also have seen.

PARA.TAB: We believe that what is proposed will not advance the cause which we share in common in the way that the Democrats claim under this Bill. In fact, when one looks at it one tries to envisage a more cooperative basis for the protection of endangered species across Australia, including all governments, and particularly in the States where on-the-ground management of schemes, plans and protection regimes to ensure the survival of endangered species is essential. The Democrats Bill seeks to view the States as antagonists, and the legislation contains provisions which provide for an overriding of the States in a way which the Government does not think is conducive to the inter-governmental cooperation which is essential if the objective is to be achieved.

It is also the case that the three separate community committees involved in the administration under the Democrats Bill—the management committee, an advisory committee and a scientific panel—will once again lead to an inevitable bogging down in excessive coordination requirements, and I believe that the money could be better spent on practical programs protecting those endangered species.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question resolved in the negative.
Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for giving the chamber an opportunity to conclude discussion of the second reading of this particular Bill. As I was saying, the Government is very strongly committed to taking action to protect endangered species. If this were just a rhetorical flourish, then I guess it could be dismissed, but in fact there is real substance to that claim already. The endangered species program has current spending of $4.3m for this financial year and there is an additional $1.5m allocated for feral animal control, which will assist in the protection of endangered species. I think Senator Calvert was right to emphasise that as a most important strategy—part of any attempt in Australia to protect our indigenous, endangered species.

PARA.TAB: The Endangered Species Advisory Committee has developed a national strategy which will be used as a basis for development of a national approach by the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council. This is totally in harmony with the intergovernmental agreement on the environment. So I believe that there is already a sound basis and foundation for an acknowledgment of the good faith of the Federal Government in this area of national importance.

There is a need for legislative action. That can be conceded and, indeed, the Commonwealth is involved in devising such legislation in order to have a statutory foundation for the strategies necessary to ensure the long term survival of Australia's endangered species. There are many objectives of the legislation, but amongst them ought to be emphasised the promoting of the recovery of species and ecological communities that are endangered or vulnerable, preventing other species and ecological communities from becoming endangered, reducing conflicting land management through readily understood mechanisms relating to the conservation of listed species and ecological communities, and providing for public involvement in and public understanding of the conservation of such species and ecological communities.

Once again, I think Senator Calvert made a very important contribution in emphasising the need for such education to promote public understanding of the need to conserve such species, to enable people to consider, in a less emotional way, the very real vulnerability of some of these species and ecological communities and to acknowledge that there will be occasions when economic development cannot be the idol which takes as its sacrifice these particular species. Of course, there will be a need to encourage cooperative management for the conservation of such species and ecological communities.

The cooperative approach will be the underlying theme of the Federal Government's legislation when it is brought before the Parliament. The Government believes that that will be a more balanced Bill. There is a common objective, but we do not believe that the Democrats' Bill will actually achieve this in a lasting way, in a way which engenders the full cooperation of all those constituents of the Australian community who have an interest—from individuals to those who may be interested in the development of a particular project, those who have a particular concern for the protection of an endangered species, or the local authorities and State governments in whose jurisdictions strategies will have to be put into place and whose cooperation will be absolutely vital. All of these persons and bodies have a real interest which we believe ought to be harnessed to meet the desired objective in a cooperative rather than in a punitive, antagonistic and adversarial way.

We believe that the legislation which the Federal Government is developing will commend itself to the Parliament in a way which this legislation cannot. For that reason, the Federal Government does not support this legislation and I believe that it ought to be rejected at this second reading stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—Let me begin where Senator Tate has just left off because it seems from what I have heard tonight that there has been quite a lot of confusion about both the contents of this Bill and the processes which have got it to this stage. Senator Tate has just charged that the Threatened Species Bill is not one which has resulted from or will engender a great degree of cooperation and consultation. The Opposition also charged that this Bill has been brought on at this time simply as a political ploy. Let me put the record straight.

PARA.TAB: This Bill was first drafted last year, and it was introduced into this Senate as a draft Bill in September of last year so that not only honourable senators but also people more widely in the community could have a look at this legislation, make criticism of it and, as a consequence of that, allow the draft legislation to be amended.

That draft legislation was sent out to over 2,000 groups, and not just conservation groups, let me remind Senator Panizza and others, but to mining interests, forestry interests and farming interests. It was distributed very widely in the community, as a result of which submissions were made about suggested amendments. Those suggested amendments were taken up specifically in that the NFF was included on the committee to which Senator Panizza referred and compensation would be payable should land need to be acquired or should the use to which land can be put need to be changed to defend a threatened species.

The legislation envisages far wider cooperation than we have seen in the Government's draft legislation in that the community is able to submit the names of species for inclusion on threatened species lists. This is something the draft of the Government's legislation does not allow for. Of course, a submission to that effect would not necessarily include the species on the list. The Scientific Advisory Committee would then review those suggestions to see whether they should be included. Quite contrary to what both the Government and the Opposition have maintained, a long history of consultation has gone into the preparation and the presentation of this Bill to the Senate and the Bill envisages a continuation of that consultation and cooperation in the operation of the Bill.

Senator Tate indicated that the Bill is confrontationist with respect to the States. It is exactly similar to legislation which is frequently passed in this place at the instigation of the Government, in that it places a backstop behind the States if the States refuse to pass adequate legislation to protect threatened species or, having passed legislation, fail to activate that legislation to defend the species which are under their control.

One would hope that all of the States would pass adequate legislation, and then this legislation would not be necessary, except in so far as this legislation does allow the Commonwealth to give assistance to threatened species overseas—because we have experts in this country who can assist in that capacity—and the powers of the Commonwealth extend, through the external affairs powers, in ways the powers of the States do not. So there is a complementarity of the powers of the Government which would be granted under this legislation and the powers of the States which we do not find in the draft of the Government's own legislation.

It has been charged by Senator Panizza and Senator Baume that this legislation would result in confrontation with industry. This legislation is designed to avoid precisely that sort of confrontation. We have seen—I would have to agree with Senator Panizza in this respect—in many decades recently occasions when considerable sums of money have been expended on plans to develop various things, whether they be forestry, mining or urban developments, perhaps EISs prepared, various studies done, and somewhere down the track a concern is raised on conservation grounds, as a consequence of which there is a Mexican stand-off; there is an argument which perhaps gets into the courts or which perhaps gets before a committee. The stand-off takes a long time to resolve and is never resolved to anybody's satisfaction. Either the proposal does not proceed and perhaps millions of dollars are wasted or the proposal does proceed and environmental damage that might have been avoided is caused.

This legislation is designed to put in place a series of management plans which would avoid that. So those who would want to mine, conduct forestry or carry out some other development in an area would know beforehand, for example, that they can go into area A, they cannot go into area B or they can go into area C under certain specified conditions. Surely that is a far more productive way of approaching the proper sustainable development of this country. That is exactly what this legislation is designed to do. Quite the reverse of what Senator Panizza and Senator Baume were arguing, this legislation is designed specifically to avoid those very problems.

It was interesting to hear Senator Calvert quote P.P. McGuinness, who is a marvellous expert on the environment, my gosh! It was interesting that he quoted him as saying that the environmentalists should pay the foresters if they stop them chopping down the trees. Senator Calvert should jolly well know that, with the exception of South Australia, every forestry commission in this country has run up enormous debts running into billions of dollars. In his own State of Tasmania, the Forestry Commission ran up a debt of $400m, which was written off by the Field Government. The community at large has paid the price very dearly for the foresters. It has been subsidising the foresters to go in and chop down the trees. So it is a pity that neither P.P. McGuinness nor Senator Calvert knows the facts in relation to that.

I also refer Senator Calvert to the Public Accounts Committee in New South Wales, which identified the billions of dollars of debt which had been run up by the State Forestry Commission due to the fact that it had never properly charged for the infrastructure of roads and various other things. I also remind him that my State of South Australia is the only State which has a forestry operation that is not in debt. Because we chopped down all our forests so many years ago, the forestry is entirely based on plantations.

Senator Calvert also pointed to the rehabilitation which is being carried out by mining companies. He said that he had a photograph of the rehabilitation of Weipa in front of him. I have been to Weipa and seen the rehabilitation, and I have been with the Aboriginal people who have been there collecting the seeds. The fact remains that the company there can rehabilitate the ground cover and the middle storey extremely well. But after the bauxite has been removed and the top soil is put back without that bauxite layer, none of the tall trees grow back. So the ecology after mining is totally different. Sure, the mining companies can get some cover on there, but they do not get back what was there before.

In relation to sandmining in Senator Panizza's own State, the fact remains that if 10 per cent of the species of plants can be put back into a sand mined area, that is regarded as adequate rehabilitation of the area. To the untrained eye—and I hate to reflect on Senator Calvert's botanical ability—that might look very good. It might make a very nice photograph, but it is not returning the area to the state that it was in or returning the indigenous species to where they once were.

Senator Calvert made the point that the mining companies are behaving better. That is certainly true; they are behaving a lot better than they were 20 years or 30 years ago. But why are they behaving better? They are behaving better precisely because the conservation movement has been very active in pointing to their very poor record in the past. Thank goodness they are behaving better and that we now have some better restitution than we had in former times.

I return to what we are talking about here, which is building an essential element in the plank towards a sustainable civilisation in this country. It is an approach, an attitude and a change to which the Government itself has assented. Under Prime Minister Hawke, the Government set up nine ESD committees to attempt to define the way in which this country might move forward towards sustainability.
What does that mean? The International Union for the Conservation of Nature has said that we need to adopt these principles for sustainable living:

An ethic based on respect and care for each other and the Earth is the foundation for sustainable living. Development ought not to be at the expense of other groups or later generations, nor threaten the survival of other species.
The benefits and costs of resource use and environmental conservation should be shared fairly among different communities . . .

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, it is referring there not just to human communities but to the wider community—the living community. The IUCN continues:
among people who are poor and those who are affluent and between our generation and those who will come after us.

That is one of the significant points of conflict which has now arisen over the Government's own legislation.
