The emphasis by the so-called development interests are on the demands of this generation at the expense of the future. The conservation movement is saying that we must emphasise more strongly the rights and demands which future generations have on the resources of this planet.

PARA.TAB: The IUCN also points to the need for change in personal attitudes:
To adopt the ethic for living sustainably, people must re-examine their values and alter their behaviour.

SPEECH.PARA: We are indeed in a period of very significant cultural change. As some authors have suggested, we are in a change no less profound than that which marked the agricultural revolution of 10,000 years ago or the industrial revolution of two centuries ago. We need to change yet again and adopt different values.

PARA.TAB: The IUCN says that we need to adopt an ethic for living sustainably. People must re-examine their values and alter their behaviour. There is little sign of that in what we have heard from the Opposition tonight. The organisation continues:

SPEECH.PARA: Society must promote values that support the ethic and discourage those that are incompatible with the sustainable way of life. Information must be disseminated through formal and informal education so that needed actions are widely understood.

The IUCN goes on to define what it means by ecological sustainability. Again, I stress that this is something to which the Government has paid a considerable amount of attention and on which it has expended a great deal of money. The IUCN says of ecological sustainability:
A society is ecologically sustainable when it:
*conserves ecological life-support systems and biodiversity—
that is the point we are arguing tonight—
*ensures that uses of renewable resources are sustainable and minimises the depletion of nonrenewable resources
*keeps within the carrying capacity of supporting ecosystems.

As long as seven years ago, the Government made a promise that it would introduce legislation to protect threatened species. At each election we have heard that promise repeated. The Government has simply failed to deliver. In 1990, it made a very specific promise to the conservation groups when, in answer to a questionnaire which was put together by the ACF and several other national conservation groups, it specifically said that it would introduce legislation into Parliament during this term and invoke the use of the corporations power to ensure that there was comprehensive national legislation which had teeth.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition objects to the use of section 51(xx) of the Constitution, but we should note that it is very willing—this is on the record repeatedly in recent weeks—to use that corporations power to screw the workers of this country as hard as it possibly can to the boards. It has specifically said it will use that corporations power in relation to industrial relations. It is not that it is not prepared to exercise that Federal power, that power in the Constitution—it is prepared to use it for economic ends—but it is not prepared to use it to protect the environment.

We in Australia live in a continent which for 40 to 50 million years has been floating across the Southern Ocean developing an absolutely unique flora and fauna. We have a responsibility in Australia to ensure that that unique flora and fauna is there not just for our own use and enjoyment, not just for the use and enjoyment of our children, grandchildren and succeeding generations of Australians and not just for the enjoyment of people in other countries in later generations, but that that unique collection of animals and plants will be able to go on evolving and remaining in a biologically intact state into the indefinite future for its own sake. Nigel Calder, who at one time was the Editor of New Scientist, a very respected scientific journal, said of conservation:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the primary aim is to sustain diverse and active living communities, in which non-human life can resume in comparative tranquillity the ponderous process of evolution which has been so disrupted and confused by the irruption of man.
That lies at the essence of the new ethic. It contrasted very markedly with what we heard from the Opposition tonight. We have an absolutely disastrous record in this country.

PARA.TAB: I think Senator Calvert mentioned the bilby. If we look at the record, we find that the author of that very well-respected tome, Mammals of South Australia, which was published in 1923, said that 30 years ago—in other words, he was referring to roughly 100 years before today—rabbit trappers in the Adelaide hills were catching more bilbies than they were catching rabbits. If I go into a classroom today anywhere in this country and show children a photograph of a bilby, they do not know what a bilby is. Most Australian adults do not know what a bilby is. We have an absolutely atrocious record. We have the worst record in the world when it comes to extinction of species. We have lost large numbers of species and the rate at which we are losing species is in no sense declining.

I agree with Senator Calvert: it is not just things such as land clearance and so on which have threatened species of animals; the introduction of feral animals has played a very significant part. The control of those feral animals—the feral cats which are destroying the bilby populations—must be an essential part of the process of preserving those species into the indefinite future. My legislation makes no prejudgment whatsoever about what protective measures would be put in place. That is left, as it should be, with the scientific committee to advise on and with the management committee to recommend to government the appropriate processes to use. It might be that it involves going out and shooting feral donkeys, horses or cats, as the Army did in south-west Queensland recently. That might be the best method of doing it. In other cases it might be fencing. In other cases it might be protecting whole areas. It might mean a whole lot of things. It might mean, in an extreme case, bringing animals in and having protective breeding programs before they can be reintroduced into the wild. Those things are all on the possible list.

Before we even get to that point, we need to very significantly increase the rate at which we are carrying out the biological survey. Senator Bell has indicated that at the rate at which we are currently carrying out the survey, it is likely to be the year 3000 before we even know what we have in this country. For the Opposition to guffaw and joke at the suggestion that we need to spend more money to find out what we have here, I find quite despicable. We are the custodians of these animals and plants. Nobody else can look after them. They will be gone if they disappear.

We have a responsibility. We are taking the wealth out of this country. We have a responsibility to put some of that wealth back into finding out what is here and properly looking after it. One of the first requirements is to substantially increase the rate of that survey so at least we will know what we are trying to look after. We need to know something about the relationships—that is what the word `ecology' is about—between the animals and plants so that we know better how to protect them. We are quite incapable of protecting an isolated species. We need to protect whole ecologies. I found it quite depressing to hear Senator Panizza go on in the way that he did, indicating that he has little knowledge of the biological processes.

It is certainly true that we have been running a very active campaign in the Democrats to encourage support for this legislation. In the last few days we have presented petitions signed by over 4,000 Australians, including about 450 individual letters which I tabled today. There is widespread concern for threatened species. As Senator Bell said, in the recent survey for which the Australian taxpayer paid a quarter of a million dollars—the survey conducted by the Minister—68 per cent of Australians expressed great concern about threatened species.

We were fortunate in having a large number of very prominent Australian painters present to us a collection of paintings on threatened species so that we could run an art exhibition around Australia. I would like to put on the record our appreciation of Shane Pickett, Michael Leunig, Neville Weston, Ken Done, Julie Vivas, and Tjyllyungoo, and of Brett Whiteley, who unfortunately died after the exhibition was mounted. That exhibition went to every capital city in Australia. It was seen by many thousands of people. Senator Calvert was at the launch of that exhibition in Hobart. That exhibition has done a great deal to raise the awareness of Australians about the plight of our threatened species.

I would like to make one point that I should have made earlier in relation to mining, because that seems to be a particular concern of Senator Panizza's. Mining of itself does not create wealth. I repeat: mining of itself does not create wealth. Senator Panizza will know, as a very wealthy businessman, that if he owns a truck or a bulldozer and he sells the truck or the bulldozer he does not become more wealthy. He simply shows in his accounts that he has shifted a capital amount from the capital account to the cash flow account. That is exactly what we are doing when we are mining and sending our minerals overseas without value adding. There is little advantage to Australia in the long run in a sustainable sense for mining iron ore in the Pilbara, as Senator Panizza mentioned last night. The value of that operation to Australians comes from carrying out that operation and then value adding. It is in the value adding that we add real wealth to this country. That is why I have strongly supported the proposal which Compact Steel in Western Australia is trying to promote, precisely because it is a very good value adding project.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, turning zinc ore into finished zinc and, better still, turning it into galvanised steel and other galvanised products. The more value adding the better. One does not get wealthy simply by mining it and flogging it off without value adding to it.

PARA.TAB: In summary, I can only repeat that this legislation, unlike the Government's legislation, is comprehensive and national. It has involved a great deal of consultation. The processes which the legislation envisages are ongoing in the area of consultation. The legislation involves the public generally. It does precisely what the Government has promised to do. In view of the promise that the Government made to electors in 1990, I am very disappointed to learn that it cannot find it within itself to support this legislation. This is exactly what it promised it would do.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senators are reminded that the Asia Pacific Regional Colloquy of the Strasbourg Conference on Parliamentary Democracy is to be held at Parliament House next week. The theme of the colloquy is `Democracy and Economic Development in the Asia/Pacific Region—the role of Parliamentary Institutions'. Its major aim is to examine the role of parliamentary institutions in maintaining and promoting parliamentary democracy in the Asia Pacific region. Parliamentarians from APEC countries and the Pacific Island nations are expected to be among the principal participants at the colloquy.

PARA.TAB: Senators are welcome to attend the sittings and other events to be held in connection with the conference. Any help that senators could extend to our international visitors in making them feel welcome would be appreciated.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to address a matter of serious public concern which I regard as having assumed the proportions of a first-class scandal. I refer to the activities of one Mr Fred Gazal and the former employees of Caldaden Pty Ltd and Zallag Holdings within the textiles, clothing and footwear industries.

PARA.TAB: I refer to the events earlier today when over 100 unemployed textile workers came to Canberra along with representation from their union—with Anna Booth, the General Secretary of the TCF union, and Kevin Boyd, the New South Wales Secretary of the union—to put their case to the Government. These are people who have seen the factories which employed them close in circumstances which can only give rise to concern. They have been cheated of all their entitlements relating to leave, superannuation, redundancy payments and the like. In total, some 200 workers have been cheated of the best part of $800,000 in entitlements.

A campaign is being waged not only by the TCF union but also by the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Labour Council of New South Wales, the parliamentary Labor Party in New South Wales, and now I believe the Federal parliamentary Labor Party and, I hope, after this address tonight, by the Parliament. The circumstances are that we have seen paper shuffling on a scale not witnessed since the bottom of the harbour scandals of the late 1970s and early 1980s. In one case, the Caldaden shuffle, in another case, the Midford shuffle.

In the case of the Caldaden shuffle, beginning with Ideal Products, the company passed through Gazal Industries, Crystal Clothing International to Kent Productions. We see F.S. Gazal Pty Ltd enter, and the company ends at the point of Caldaden Pty Ltd. I will make a point about those transactions in a moment after I have referred to the Midford shuffle beginning with Midford Paramount, passing through Gazal Apparel to Zallag Holdings and again to one Mr Fred Gazal. In this circumstance also, as with the Caldaden shuffle, the Midford shuffle produces the extraordinary result by which the assets go off in one direction and the obligations to the employees in another direction.

As this chamber is aware, the bottom of the harbour scandals of the 1980s resulted in the Commonwealth being defrauded, cheated and denuded of revenue to which the Commonwealth had an entitlement. The Midford shuffle and the Caldaden shuffle result in the employees being defrauded and cheated of their entitlements. We are talking about ordinary working Australians, some of whom have given more than two decades of dedicated service to their employers, working in the textile industries.

We saw today the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Peter Cook, and Parliamentary Secretary Peter Duncan, speak directly with the union and the unionists. It was a first-class dialogue and it was needed to draw the attention of the Government directly to this problem. Minister Cook made it clear that he had discussed this matter with the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) personally, he viewed it so seriously.

I have no doubt that the response of the Government will be both appropriate and effective in terms of a review of the Crown's priority in matters of tax and a review of the corporations law, and in terms of making certain that the Australian Securities Commission and other appropriate agencies, including the relevant law enforcement agencies, look at the events surrounding the closures of these companies, one of which also, curiously, had a fire at one point involving a substantial insurance pay-out to Mr Fred Gazal. The pay-out is now nowhere to be located.

I believe that the Government response will be very timely. Mr Duncan made it clear that he was looking to a decision on some complicated matters of law prior to the end of the year. I know that Minister Cook wants to see action taken even more urgently on the industrial relations questions. Of course, one of the issues that needs to be looked at is the whereabouts of Mr Fred Gazal, now believed to be located in Lebanon.

What also needs to be determined, of course, is just where all the money has gone—money which supposedly was set aside to cover workers' entitlements such as long service leave, superannuation and the like. This was money which was supposedly set aside in order to provide for just this kind of eventuality with the respective companies going out of business. Of course, there is also the question of the insurance payout related to the fire which affected Caldaden in 1990. One thing that we can say with absolute certainty is that the workers have not seen that money. In some cases workers are owed in excess of $10,000 for years and years of faithful service. No-one has suggested that they have been at fault in any way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Individuals are owed that?

—Individuals are owed in excess of $10,000. That is conceded. There is a track record involved here, as Senator Bell knows. There is an incident involving a Tasmanian company which may well be related to these kinds of circumstances. Certainly, we can say, again without fear of contradiction, that the common point in the beginning of these matters is the Gazal corporation's purchase of companies. Other matters seem to flow in ensuing years.

PARA.TAB: We have had a grave injustice done to 200 working Australians. I have no doubt that every senator would share my concern and that the Parliament would share my concern. Certainly, the trade unions have waged a campaign of vigour and determination. But I think that it goes beyond that. I have no doubt that every Australian, including people in the business community, would be outraged at the behaviour of Mr Fred Gazal, now somewhere in Lebanon. The injustice and the disservice done to working people really needs to be addressed as a matter of urgency. It can certainly never be allowed to recur. We really need to change the law as a matter of urgency to make certain that this kind of shuffle cannot result in this manner of theft again.

A number of questions need to be answered. A briefing paper has been prepared by the Labor Council of New South Wales and by the TCF Union of Australia. I seek leave to incorporate that paper in Hansard.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: WHERE'S THE MONEY FREDDIE?
SOME QUESTIONS THAT DEMAND ANSWERS

The ACTU; the Labor Council of NSW; the Textile, Footwear and Clothing Union; and the Labor Opposition in State Parliament have all called for the Caldaden and Zallag cases to be referred to the Director of Public Prosecutions and the Australian Securities Commission.
There are many unanswered questions that can only be resolved by formal investigations into these company closures and the behaviour of the companies' Directors.

Many of these questions go beyond `Where's the money, Freddie?', however in the course of trying to recover the outstanding entitlements for their members it has become obvious to the Textile, Footwear and Clothing Union that there were other important issues worthy of urgent investigation. The Union is preparing a full dossier which will be submitted to the Director of Public Prosecutions and the Australian Securities Commission.
From 1987-88 onwards the workers were employed by Caldaden Pty Ltd, a company in which Freddie Gazal is a Director and major shareholder.

It appears that Caldaden Pty Ltd was a company with very considerable liabilities but few, if any, assets. For example, Caldaden Pty Ltd was supposed to provide workers compensation cover for the Kingsford workers, but it would appear that the company did not keep up-to-date in paying the premiums.
Question: Did Freddie Gazal's company, Caldaden Pty Ltd, provide workers compensation cover for its Kingsford workers as required by law?

From 1988, another of Freddie's companies, F. S. Gazal Pty Ltd, had taken over the lease of the Kingsford factory site. F. S. Gazal Pty Ltd was established in September 1975 as a clothing manufacturer; the two shareholders were Freddie and Hyatt Gazal.

F. S. Gazal Pty Ltd is Freddie's family company. In the past it has made large unsecured loans to Freddie and his family. At one time Freddie and his wife were loaned more than $170,000 by F. S. Gazal Pty Ltd.
Question: Where did the money come from to pay for Freddie's house in Bellevue Hill?

It appears that all the business's valuable assets were transferred into F. S. Gazal Pty Ltd, Freddie's family company. Those assets are likely to have included the stock, the machinery and the insurance policy covering the businesses that eventually ended up being based at St Peters.
In 1990 the workers were transferred from Kingsford to St Peters and shortly afterwards fire burnt down the factory.
Question: Exactly when were all the company records damaged by fire and how many times were they burnt?

At the time of the fire the land and buildings at the St Peters site were owned by Londonaire Pty Ltd., a company whose shares were owned by Freddie, his wife Hayat Gazal and the family company F. S. Gazal Pty Ltd. Hundreds of thousands of dollars were paid out by insurance companies to compensate for the fire damage to the building.
Question: What happened to the fire damage insurance pay-out?

The insurance policies which were paid out included a component to cover the workers' legal entitlements such as redundancy pay and long service leave. Freddie Gazal or any of his companies have never paid the workers any of the termination entitlements to which they are legally entitled.
Question: Where's the money for the workers' termination entitlements?

Zallag Holdings Pty Ltd, another of Freddie Gazal's companies, also failed to pay termination entitlements to 75 Wollongong clothing workers sacked in July 1992. These workers are still owed more than $220,000.
However other money remains unaccounted for by Zallag Holdings. Many workers had payroll deductions for a local charity and health funds. Those deductions never reached their destinations.
Question: What happened to the workers' money deducted for local charity and their health funds?
In the months before Zallag Holdings closed its Unanderra factory various machines were sold. It appears that some of these transactions happened at night or at the weekend.
Question: Where are the records of those machinery sales?
Many important questions remain unanswered in the chequered history of F. S. Gazal Pty Ltd, Caldaden Pty Ltd, Londonaire Pty Ltd and Zallag Holdings. It is difficult to ascertain:

PARA.TAB: Which companies owned which assets and at which times?
When the workers were transferred from one business to another did any other assets go with them?

SPEECH.PARA: Only full investigations by the Director of Public Prosecutions and the Australian Securities Commission can resolve these matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I conclude by asking these very specific questions. Why should Fred Gazal live in luxurious circumstances in Bellevue Hill and elsewhere when his workers have been the victims of fraud? Where did the money finish and with whom? When will Mr Fred Gazal face his former employees and explain to them precisely what happened? When will restitution be made to the former employees of Caldaden and of Zallag? When will justice be done for them? As a final note, why did this scandal appear to begin—in both the circumstances I have mentioned tonight—with the purchase of companies by the Gazal corporation?

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 18 August 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware that 1993 has been designated by the United Nations as International Year of Indigenous People, with an official launch scheduled in New York on 10 December 1992.
(2) What activities have been planned to mark this year which focuses on human rights and social justice for all indigenous people.
(3) Has a departmental officer been nominated to work with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission in planning and coordinating activities for International Year of Indigenous People.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Minister is aware that the United Nations has designated 1993 as International Year for the World's Indigenous People.

(2) Activities to mark the Year within the Minister's portfolio have most relevance to the Local Government area; other areas of the portfolio are not involved at this time. The Office of Local Government has written to the Australian Local Government Association (ALGA) seeking consideration by the Secretariat for the Reference Group on the Relationship Between Local Government and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples of the development and implementation of activities to promote the Year. The Reference Group will consider these activity proposals at its October 1992 meeting.

(3) A departmental officer from the Office of Local Government has been nominated to work with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission in planning and coordinating activities for the Year. This officer represents the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs on the Inter-Departmental Committee established to develop the Commonwealth's contribution to the Year.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, upon notice, on 28 August 1992: With reference to the listing of Port Kennedy in Western Australia on the register of the National Estate:

PARA.TAB: (1) Have any objections been received to the listing; if so (a) who are the objectors; and (b) what are the grounds for objection.
(2) Does the Australian Heritage Commission propose to review the nomination; if so, who will conduct the review.
(3) Who nominated Port Kennedy for listing on the register of the National Estate.
(4) Have all parties to the nomination been advised of the choice of reviewer; if not, why not.
(5) Has the Western Australian Government requested a review of the interim listing of Port Kennedy on the register.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian Heritage Commission has received nine objections, from:

(a) The Western Australian Department of Planning and Urban Development, Carioca Pty Ltd, Ardross Estates Pty Ltd, Secret Harbour Pty Ltd, Landcorp, Fleuris Pty Ltd, the City of Rockingham, the Urban Development Institute of Australia (Western Australian Division Incorporated) and a private landowner the disclosure of the identity of whom would be subject to Principle eleven of the Privacy Act 1988.

(b) Objectors submitted their objections on one or more of the following grounds: the alleged secretive nature of the listing procedure; the implications for planning, residential land supply or land use in the area; the implications for private and public sector costs; inappropriate boundary; insufficient significance; alleged undue interference by the Commission in the land use of the area; the alleged failure of the Commission to adequately consult interested parties; possible conflict of interest by Commission members or staff; the alleged subjective procedures of the Commission; parts of the area are zoned residential, commercial or industrial; and key elements of the area are allegedly protected in proposed or existing reserves at Port Kennedy or elsewhere.

(2) The Australian Heritage Commission is required to give due consideration to objections. The Commission has recommended that I appoint independent assessors under section 23B of the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975, to assist and advise it in its consideration of the objections. I have agreed to the assessors put forward by the Commission which were selected following consultation with all objectors. The appointed assessors are Dr P Hesp, Geomorphologist and Manager, Environment Department, Rottnest Island Authority; Dr E Mattiske, plant ecologist, E M Mattiske and Associates; Mr G Connell, zoologist, Ecologia Environmental Consultants or, if unavailable, Mr K Youngson, Principal, Ninox Wildlife Consulting and Dr M Mulcahy, retired soil scientist and former member of the Western Australian Environmental Protection Authority.
(3) Approximately half of the area listed was nominated by the Conservation Council of Western Australia Inc. The Commission determined the listed boundary after assessment and advice by its staff.
(4) See (2). The Conservation Council of Western Australia had been advised of some of the potential assessors that were under consideration for recommendation to me.
(5) There has been no formal request from the government for a review. The Western Australian Department of Planning and Urban Development and Landcorp have made objections and submissions.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Defence: Torres Strait Staff

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 9 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many staff are based in Torres Strait.
(2) How many staff are indigenous.
(3) What strategies are being implemented to ensure more Torres Strait Island staff move into senior positions.
(4) How is housing allocated to prevent discrimination against Torres Strait Islanders.
(5) What processes are in place to ensure regular communication and liaison between departments and with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and the Island Coordinating Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) There are two Permanent Naval Force personnel and five Naval Reservists on Thursday Island.
There are two Regular Army positions and 133 Army Reserve positions in Torres Strait.
There are no RAAF or civilian members of the Department in Torres Strait.

(2) I understand the question is referring only to staff based in Torres Strait. One of the Permanent Naval Force personnel and all the Naval Reservists are Torres Strait Islanders. 109 of the Army Reservists are Torres Strait Islanders.

(3) All members of the ADF compete equally with their peers for promotion, which is on merit. Extensive career development training, including participation in promotional qualification courses, is available to members as a matter of course.

The Department of Defence is currently developing an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Recruitment and Career Development plan for implementation in early 1993. This plan will specifically address the career development needs of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders so that they may have more opportunity to move into senior positions.
(4) Housing for ADF members is allocated according to single-Service administrative instructions. The criteria by which housing is allocated are marital status, number of children and rank.

(5) The Department of Defence communicates and liaises with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission through membership of the inter-departmental committee coordinating activities for the International Year of the World's Indigenous People in 1993. Communication and liaison also occurs between the Commission, the ADF and the Department as required on specific issues.

The Naval and Army units in the Torres Strait have an excellent working relationship with the Island Coordinating Council. Training activities and visits are cleared through community leaders and they are invited to observe training where appropriate. Mr Getano Lui, Chairman of the Island Coordinating Council, recently addressed the Army Reserve unit and presented it with the newly recognised Torres Strait flag. Several Council members are members of the unit.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters, upon notice, on 16 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is there any estimate of the percentage of people who acquire a disability during their working life in the Australian Public Service (APS).

(2) Can information be provided about what types of disabilities are acquired; if not, has any information been obtained through early retirement or reduced work hours data on the most common reasons for people to change their work hours or levels.
(3) Has there been any analysis of sick leave to determine if there is a period of declining or changing performance before a permanent change is made in people's work patterns or hours.
(4) How many people in the APS have retired early because of a disability—by age, by gender, by level and by time in the APS.

(5) Has any estimate been made by any department as to the number of people in the department who have not met the work requirements they are paid to perform, and the cost of this to the department and other staff who have to perform the work instead.
(6) Is there an intention to determine whether some of these people have a disability which limits their capacity.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)-(6) Information in respect of the matters referred to in the senator's question is not readily available. To collect and assemble it would be a major task and I am not prepared to authorise the expenditure of money and effort involved in assembling such information.

No estimate is available on the percentage of people who acquire a disability during their working life in the APS. Data on disabilities is collected on a voluntary basis on appointment to the APS. While it is possible for this information to be updated, it is not done on a systematic basis. Information on the date at which a disability occurred is not recorded.

Although some consideration is given by the Commission for the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation of Commonwealth Employees (Comcare) when assessing lump sum payment entitlements to APS staff, it does not hold details regarding disabilities for compensation claimants in its database. A costly and time-consuming manual search of Comcare files would be required to extract data on such cases.

Some information about the incidence of disabilities among APS staff (both work-related and non work-related) and the strategies adopted by the APS in respect of disabled staff is included in the individual annual reports of departments and authorities, the annual reports of the former Public Service Board, the annual reports of the Commonwealth Superannuation Boards of Trustees, the annual reports of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission (Worksafe Australia) and the annual reports of Comcare.

Statistical information relating to the resignation, on invalidity grounds, of staff employed under the Public Service Act 1922 is contained in the Public Service Board Statistical Yearbook published annually until 1985 by the former Public Service Board; the Australian Public Service Statistical Yearbook published annually from 1986 to 1988 by the Department of Finance; the Australian Public Service Statistical Bulletin published twice yearly (Bulletin A for calendar years; Bulletin B for financial years) from 1988 to 1991 by the Department of Finance; and the Australian Public Service Staffing Statistics Report 1991 published by the Department of Finance. Table 14 of the Australian Public Service Staffing Statistics Report 1991 contains information, by classification and sex, on the number of permanent APS staff who retired on invalidity grounds in 1991. No information on type of disability is held on the Continuous Record of Personnel, which is the statistical database for the Australian Public Service Staffing Statistics Report 1991.

Section 76X of the Public Service Act 1922 stipulates instructions to be followed by departmental Secretaries to manage under performing officers. Before action under inefficiency provisions is commenced, supervisors are expected to identify and overcome factors that may be affecting an officer's work performance.
